PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—the petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. the petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: maintained national unity in a federation

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from 15 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 37 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from four citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that the new rates for registered articles under Australia Post's Print Post arrangements are unfair and discriminate against rural residents. The new arrangements will significantly increase the cost of magazines and newspapers for those who wish to receive them by mail and has the potential to threaten the viability of country newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Government's main economic forecasting group has confirmed that the Government's One Nation forecast of 4.75 per cent growth in Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in 1992-93 is not achievable, and

(ii)the 7.5 per cent increase in total Commonwealth net payments to the States and Territories and the likely Commonwealth Government sector deficit of $15-20 billion, or 5 per cent of GDP, in 1992-93 will contribute inevitably to an increase in interest rates in 1992-93;

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns the Government for this enormous drain on Australia's national savings at a time when an increase in national savings is of the highest priority; and
(c)urges the Government to endorse the Liberal and National parties' Fightback! policy proposals for reform to rebuild Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)condemns the Government for presiding over unprecedented youth unemployment levels, as high as 46 per cent in some regions; and
(b)calls on the Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)to host its proposed Youth Summit in an area of high youth unemployment, such as Sydney's western suburbs, to give young people maximum access to this forum, and
(ii)to invite young people to set the topics for discussion and to refrain from imposing its agenda on young people or risk the Summit being a token gesture of support for Australia's youth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the hypocrisy and empty rhetoric of this Federal Labor Government in claiming to be concerned about housing affordability while pushing through this Parliament the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 which will increase the cost of housing by about 25 per cent,
(ii)that the Australian home building industry, without this legislation, has been universally regarded as one of the most efficient in the world, and
(iii)that, by contrast, New South Wales Royal Commissioner Gyles concluded that the activities of unions added 27 per cent to building costs in the commercial building industry in Sydney;

PARA.TAB: (b)deplores the fact that, while the Government's proposed review of real estate agents' fees, lawyers' conveyancing charges and financial charges by banks would save homebuyers only one or two thousand dollars on an average priced home of $100 000, the unionisation of labour in the home building industry, which will result from this legislation, will increase the cost of that same house by $25 000; and
(c)urges the Government to cease its empty rhetoric and genuinely act to improve housing affordability.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been able to accumulate considerable wealth while a parliamentarian; and
(b)calls on the Prime Minister to conduct a series of seminars for Members and Senators to show them how to accumulate large scale wealth on a parliamentary salary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)that, while recognising the good relationship that exists between Australia and the United States of America (US), the US Government is still discriminating against Australian producers of beef, sugar and dairy products,
(ii)that this is in addition to the damage done to Australian grain producers by the US Government's use of export subsidies, and
(iii)US Government restrictions on the service industry, including telecommunications; and

PARA.TAB: (b)seeks the co-operation of the US Government to change those practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes that—
(a)the Federal Labor Government continues to ignore the plight of one million Australians who are looking for employment and an unknown number who are under-employed;
(b)notes that there are more people out of work than at any time in Australia's history;

(c)the Government continues to pursue tactics contrary to employment creation in its legislative program by the inclusion of measures such as the superannuation package which will substantially increase salary costs and force additional retrenchments by employers to avoid bankruptcy; and
(d)in Tasmania, over a third of the youth and 12.2 per cent of the total work force are unemployed and these people have no short-term prospect of being able to obtain employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the orders of the Senate, agreed to on 4 and 6 May 1992, requiring the Select Committee on Superannuation to present its report this day on the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 and related Bills and the provisions of those Bills, be modified to provide that the Committee present its report on 18 June 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee seeks this extension for the following reasons: firstly, the Committee already has a set of terms of reference on superannuation which, amongst other issues, address matters pertinent to the superannuation guarantee legislation. Therefore, unlike a number of other Bills' reports, there is a need for the Committee to write a detailed report.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the superannuation guarantee legislation is a matter for which considerable time is needed in order that an agreed view may be reached. Honourable senators will be aware that the Bills have been the subject of considerable public comment and that parties represented on the Senate Select Committee have been involved in intense negotiations which as yet have not reached conclusion. I look forward to tabling the Committee's report on the superannuation guarantee legislation Bills on Thursday morning should the Senate agree to this motion.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on Tariffs: Proposed Establishment

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that General Business Notice of Motion No. 843 standing in my name, relating to the establishment of a Senate select committee on tariffs, be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to Senator Coulter's contingent notice, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Coulter moving a motion relating to the conduct of business, namely, a motion to give precedence to General Business Notice of Motion No. 843 standing in the name of Senator Spindler for this day, relating to the establishment of a Senate select committee on tariffs.

SPEECH.PARA: I and more than one million unemployed ask the Senate to give this motion its urgent consideration. Well over 100,000 jobs have been lost in manufacturing industries in the last two years and we can easily increase that two or three times by the flow-on from those jobs which have been lost. Total unemployment is edging towards 11 per cent and the greatest shame of all is that 46 per cent of youth is unemployed in Victoria. Nationally, 120,000 young people are not in training and not in work. That figure can be doubled by counting all the street kids and other young people who are not lining up to be registered as unemployed and to receive unemployment benefits. So the question must be asked: what is this Government and what is this Opposition prepared to do to change it?

PARA.TAB: We have had ACOSS pointing to the fact that 600,000 children are living in poverty. We have had Professor Ronald Henderson pointing to 44,000 families without public housing—an industry which could be geared up if we really meant to get this country out of the depression. We have had Archbishop Peter Hollingworth calling for a scheme that would get those 120,000 young people to do something useful.

It is indeed urgent that this matter be put into place by the Senate to investigate what action can be taken in the industrial area to achieve more employment, to get people out of the misery which they are now in. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that this motion, in its terms of reference, does not ask for high protection across the board. It merely asks for a pause, but then asks for a considered, deliberate approach in lieu of the economic policy—I should say the apology for an economic and industry policy—that this country is following at the moment.

Both the Government and the Opposition are heading rapidly towards further tariff cuts, which will further decimate our industries, which will further reduce jobs. This motion to establish a Senate inquiry would enable us to assess the effects of varying levels of protection on employment, on public revenue, on social security expenditure and on regional communities dependent on particular industries.

The committee would also be in a position to assess the level, duration and type of protection that would be needed to allow action to be taken in various industry sectors to enable them to better penetrate overseas markets and to replace imports or, if that decision was made, to permit an orderly phasing out or a redirection of resources by employers and retraining and relocation of employees.

We may well decide that certain industries are socially or geographically important enough to warrant longer term protection, and that may apply to the sugarcane growers in Queensland and the dairy farmers in Victoria. It certainly applies to the TCF industries in Victoria where 80,000 jobs were lost, where 80 factories are now at risk, and where 16 were closed last year alone. This committee should also investigate the additional tax incentives, depreciation allowances, cost of entry assistance, and research and development support which should be provided to industries most likely to succeed.

We should look at the effect of the use of energy and natural resources in each of the industry sectors, and we should look at the potential for the development of alternative products or industries. We should also look at the exploitation index, the unacceptably low wages, work safety and environmental safeguards which enable international competitors to undercut Australian products. We should further look at the capital and expertise required to implement such strategies and look to the development of a framework for education, training, and research and development. Last, but not least, we should look for a toughening of anti-dumping measures. It is indeed urgent that this be done by the Senate now and I regret that the Government and the Opposition are not prepared to even look at industries' problems.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long because I know that a number of people want to express a view on this matter. There are only two points that I want to make. The first is that it is incredible that this proposal comes before us a day after the Democrats conspired with the Government to impose a guillotine on the Senate because they said the burden of legislative business before the Senate was so great that there could not be proper debate on each of the Bills that are before us—Bills of a major consequence. The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, with a clause on subcontractors, needs much more time than it is going to get; there is the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Levy Bill; and there are the reforms to the wholesale sales tax Bill to provide further imposts on Australian business. These are matters that should be debated in full, and properly, by this House of review, but they are not going to be so debated because of an agreement between the Australian Democrats and the Government.

PARA.TAB: Yet the first day after we have that guillotine imposed upon us, the Australian Democrats come in here and seek to suspend Standing Orders in order that they might pursue one of their items of general business. What hypocrisy! How often do they lecture us, saying, `Your matters are of no importance. Ministerial standards are of no importance in relation to the Marshall Islands'. What this chamber should be debating is the legislative program and yet, the first day after they imposed the guillotine, they come in here and want to set matters aside so they can debate one of their motions; that is entirely unsatisfactory.

Before I sit down, I want to make one point on the merits of this matter. The answer of the Australian Democrats to the terrible situation of Australia now, with mass unemployment and recession, is that they would put up the barriers again; they would try to isolate Australia in some way. I say to Senator Spindler that he should go back and read the Hughes report, the Garnaut report, and all those reports of experts that have told the Government what needs to be done in this country, and that is, to get the imposts off business—bring down the costs that have been imposed by government on Australian business so that it has the potential to be profitable again and to employ Australians. Over 10 per cent of Australians are unemployed. In my State, 46 per cent of young Australians who want a job cannot get one because this Government has imposed burdens upon Australian business under which it cannot survive and it cannot employ.

That is what the Australian Democrats should be concentrating on, instead of putting up more barriers, trying to isolate Australia from the rest of the world, and forgetting about those huge market opportunities that are out there in Asia if we can be domestically competitive. They should be concentrating on the reforms that are necessary in this country to enable Australian business to be competitive again. They should get those fairies out from the bottom of the garden; recognise the opportunities that are there for Australian business if government can reform in a way which can reduce imposts on business; free up the labour market and reduce taxation; adopt the Fightback package, for example; and take $20m a year off the tax impost on Australian business—then they will be doing something constructive for young Australians by giving them a chance of getting a job again. I commend that to the Australian Democrats for their careful consideration.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not agree with anything Senator Hill said. It is one of those situations where I disagree with all his arguments but agree with the conclusion. I do not believe that we should be suspending Standing Orders. In case anybody happens to be listening, that is what this motion is about: it is not about the substance of the motion, but about whether we should be suspending Standing Orders to deal with it. My view is that we should not.

PARA.TAB: From time to time in this place it is important to remind ourselves that there is a significant distinction between talking about important things and doing something important. The issues listed in this motion are important issues, issues for important debate. But we are having a debate here about whether we should set up a committee to look at these matters between now and October—matters that have been reviewed by very important government bodies and debated in public as a response to those inquiries for the last 70 years without reaching agreement.

There are important differences between all of us in this chamber about the conclusion, but those differences do not arise because we do not know the facts. The facts have been reviewed and assessed by official bodies and by academics in Australia and internationally. If we needed to set up a committee, it would be because of a lack of information and because public debate on this important issue required additional information.

It is true that we disagree about the conclusion. Some people believe that setting up a committee between June and October will provide an agreement and a consensus. I am now talking about the period in which we have had official tariff board and its successors policies, although for reasons such as the Harvester judgments we could go back 85 years. In 70 years of informed debate in Australia, the one issue that Australians can be satisfied there has been a lot of discussion about, is free trade versus protection. It was one of the key issues in the debate about Federation. It is not exactly a new issue for Australia.

There is no blinding revelation that we have suddenly discovered a new cause of concern. The facts are well known. We apply different policy perspectives to those facts. That is what we are about in here. Let us have the debate, but let us not sit around talking about whether we should set up a committee to try to do in four months what the rest of the Australian population has been doing comprehensively for at least 70 years, and arguably for longer. For that reason I do not believe this is an appropriate matter to which we should give priority in these last two weeks of sitting. Therefore, we do not support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear Senator McMullan's words of condemnation of this motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. I want to speak very briefly because the serious thing for this chamber to do is to get on with 62 Bills. The Australian Democrats did a deal with the Government yesterday to apply a guillotine to those Bills so that fundamental Bills which go to the whole core of the future of young people, old people and unemployed people in this country can be debated. That is what the chamber ought to be about. What we are about, as a result of the sleazy deals that this hypocritical bunch of Democrats has done with the Government over recent days and weeks—and they are obviously still in train—is being denied the opportunity to debate those issues that are of great moment to the future of this country.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill said that his State has 46 per cent of its young people unemployed; my State has 46 per cent of its young people unemployed. Thirty-four per cent of young people throughout Australia are unemployed. Senator Spindler wants to go down this track. Someone said earlier that he was in a time warp. He sure is in a time warp. He wants to set up a committee of the Parliament to look at matters that, as Senator McMullan said, have been looked at for 70 or 80 years, and turn back the clock in relation to the whole trend of sensible, rational movement in tariffs that we have fortunately managed to maintain over the last few years.

It is the hypocrisy of the Democrats' attempt to bring this matter forward that every honourable senator in this place, other than the Democrats, must find absolutely sickening. Senator Spindler talks about wanting to do something for the unemployed and for the economy. I will tell Senator Spindler what he can do: he can support the Fightback proposals that take $20 billion off the taxes on doing business in this country; and he can stop supporting Government legislation that imposes more and more costs on business, such as the superannuation guarantee arrangements, the industrial relations legislation, the training guarantee levy—one can name more and more—and the whole industrial relations system, in which he is opposed to providing flexibility and an opportunity for people to have jobs in this country.

I think the Democrats went into the last election as a party with policies that were proposing to increase taxes and government spending, basically on business and therefore on jobs in this country, by $20 billion to $25 billion. This is the party that talks about wanting to try to do things for people. This is a proposal of the greatest hypocrisy. I am very pleased to see that both major parties are treating it as what it is—a shabby, sleazy attempt to divert attention from the way that the Democrats have prevented the proper processes of government and the proper consideration of the real issues facing this country. They deserve the fate their motion will suffer today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every time one drives off or onto a freeway, on the other channel one sees a large sign, `Go back: you are going the wrong way'. It seems to me that there is a clear lesson here for both the Government and the Opposition. As we have just heard in the last few minutes, they have adopted a policy which is leading to massive unemployment. In Victoria alone—Senator Spindler's State—one saw a major headline only a few weeks ago, `40,000 jobs lost in the clothing, textile and footwear industry as a direct result of tariff reductions'. To continue with tariff reductions at a time when we already have massive unemployment and to throw more people on the scrap heap is absolutely unconscionable. Contrary to what Senator Hill said, we are not suggesting that we build up high tariff walls; we are simply saying that at this stage the Government and the Opposition should stop where they are and review the situation with this Senate process.

PARA.TAB: Also out of Victoria in recent weeks have come figures in relation to the benefits from buying Australian compared with buying imports—retaining industry in this country. They showed that for every million dollars which was spent on home manufacture, rather than on imports, roughly a quarter of a million dollars was garnered back by various levels of government in taxation, another quarter of a million dollars was saved in not having to pay unemployment benefits to unemployed people and there was a further very considerable benefit in the other employment which was generated.

This is a clear indication that very substantial protection of Australian industry actually pays in terms of government taxes, revenues and savings in unemployment benefits. It is precisely because these figures are coming out at this time—it does not matter what has happened over the last 70 years—that it is urgent that this matter be debated and fresh consideration be given to it, rather than simply continuing down this doctrinaire road adopted by the Government and the Opposition which says that we should remove all tariff barriers and that somehow miraculously these dead industries will get up like Lazarus and become productive. It is not happening. The evidence is out there, if only the Government and the Opposition would open the window and look. We need to bring that evidence to bear on where we go in relation to this tariff matter. It is absolutely appropriate that that be properly investigated at this time.

The conditions are very different from conditions which have obtained throughout the last 70 years. We are in the deepest recession; we have the highest level of unemployment and there is every indication that that level of unemployment is increasing. We have a large and growing foreign debt, and the interest rate on the debt is escalating out of sight. These are unusual circumstances. One simply cannot rely on things such as the Garnaut report, which is totally unrealistic. It is just not of this world at all. It is important and urgent that this matter be set straight now; that this investigation be got under way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —So far the Australian Democrats have not said one word which indicates that there is anything urgent about the motion that they have presented to the Senate this morning. The urgency of it is indicated quite clearly by the fact that all they want is a report by 30 October 1992.

PARA.TAB: If any of the 76 senators in this chamber are seriously interested in and concerned about unemployment, I invite them to look at the Notice Paper and see the legislation that is being guillotined through the Senate. I invite them to vote against the Government's legislation on superannuation, industrial relations and the training guarantee, just to mention three of the Bills. That can be done urgently; Democrat senators can vote against that legislation this week and next week and they will have actually done something to help industry in this country, instead of sitting talking until October and not achieving a thing.

I remind Senator Spindler of his words at 6.07 last night. This morning he has come into the chamber telling us that his motion is urgent and should be given priority in the Senate. Yesterday, at 6.07 p.m., we were discussing a matter that had been raised by Senator Parer on which a number of senators sought to speak. It obviously had some significance. Page 3687 of the Senate Hansard shows Senator Spindler saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I shall not detain the Senate long. I am concerned, in contrast to Senator Parer, about the substantive business that this House should be conducting.

He then went on to discuss the matter. He has one standard for one issue and another standard for another issue. I invite Senator Spindler to consider that. I remind him of his opportunity to regard unemployment as urgent in the next two weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the last State election in Victoria, Senator Spindler put out a newsletter which pointed out to the newly elected Cain Government that it was in office because of the preferences and support from the Australian Democrats. The worst Government in Victorian history, and arguably the worst Government in Australian history, got into office because of the support of Senator Spindler and his colleagues. How many jobs have been lost through that Government's high taxes, high spending, high borrowing and gross mismanagement of the Victorian economy in the wasteland that was once the great State of Victoria—once the jewel in the crown of Australia—because of the Cain and Kirner governments and the support, aid and comfort that Senator Spindler and his colleagues gave to them?

PARA.TAB: For Senator Spindler to come in here and tell us that he is concerned about jobs—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is about time Senator Spindler was concerned about jobs. We have been talking about jobs for a number of years as the recession has hit. Senator Spindler should remember that it was Democrat preferences which elected the Hawke-Keating governments which created the recession which has caused the one million unemployed. He is right to be concerned about the unemployed but he should recognise his own miserable role in the creation of this unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler gets up and says that the issue is jobs. He is absolutely right—the issue is jobs. We can ask Senator Spindler and the Australia Democrats: if that is the case, why are they proposing in their alternative vision—the proposed Budget that Senator Spindler brought down last year—50 new revenue measures which would raise taxes in this country by some $6 billion, much of which would be imposed on industry? Senator Spindler believes that this will help create jobs.

Senator Spindler has spoken about the TCF and expressed concern about that great industry. If Senator Spindler is so concerned, why has he just agreed to impose another heavy tax on the TCF industry: the superannuation levy—in effect, a payroll tax? He is so concerned about jobs and the TCF sector that last night he agreed with the Government to impose yet another tax on the TCF. Why did he not stand up and confess to that?

I have gone through Senator Spindler's policies to see how they will create jobs. I ask him: how will the $6 billion extra taxes that he wishes to impose on this country create jobs? Can he name the great mining developments that have been created in this nation in the last 10 years which he has supported and not tried to stop? Which of the major developments in the great State of Tasmania has Senator Spindler supported? He and his colleagues have gone out of their way to stop every major development. What will the inheritance and wealth taxes he is proposing do for the incentive of farmers and rural people to invest in those great industries? They will do nothing positive; they will continue to cause losses of jobs.

Senator Spindler, in one of the grossest acts of hypocrisy I have seen, has come into this chamber and started to bleat about jobs. He and his colleagues bear a very heavy responsibility for this recession because of the support that they have given this Government. They should not come in here and finally wake up to the national tragedy that we have. We have a national tragedy and we have a program to deal with that tragedy—that program is called Fightback!

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to oppose the motion to suspend Standing Orders and to make some comments on the efforts of the Australian Democrats. This motion is the worst form of politicking one could possibly have. It is misleading the Australian public. I believe that the way to address the employment problems that exist in business is, firstly, to get rid of the imposts and, secondly, to clean up the work practices. Only one other area has had more inquiries than tariff reform: waterfront reform. We have not gone very far down the track with waterfront reform.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at tariffs, what they have done to this country and the problems we have. There are some factual things that have to be accepted. This motion gives people false hopes. The highest level of attrition is in the textile, clothing and footwear industry. When protection was at its highest, the industry had its greatest attrition levels. Senator Spindler mentioned the sugar industry. The sugar industry's major problem today is its high levels of protection. It has lost 25 per cent of the sugar market to imported sweeteners. That has occurred purely and simply because of that level of protection. The sugar industry has become non-competitive. Tariffs have cost Australians jobs. People have been locked in a cocoon which has protected them from the reality of the marketplace; they have lost jobs for that reason.

Let us go further and compare the levels of protection in a number of areas. One could refer to a number of reports. Let us compare the levels of protection in the farm sectors of the United States, Europe and Australia. In Europe, with its high levels of protection, the attrition rate of farms has been 16 per cent per annum; in the United States, 14 per cent; and in Australia, 6 per cent. Protection does not protect jobs; it does not protect business. As I said in my opening remarks, this motion is totally misleading the Australian public. It is time there was a little honesty in the tariff debate, instead of dishonesty, and time people were told the truth about the impact of tariffs and what they do. Tariffs have cost Australian business its market share in Australia.

I oppose this motion very strongly. As has been mentioned by other speakers, all the evidence that has been collected for over 70 years in this country and the evidence that can be collected out of other countries where protection levels have been very high is that it has not protected business or jobs. As other speakers have mentioned, we will not change this country until the excesses of the various imposts that business has on its head such as payroll tax, fuel excise and training levies—one could go through a whole list of these up-front taxes—are removed and until work practices are cleaned up.

I say to Senator Spindler in particular that, rather than cocooning things in the industrial relations legislation or the contractors' Bill that we now have before us, we should vote against that legislation and allow for payment to be based on productivity, where contractors get paid for what they do and not for time. That would be one way of sorting out some of the employment problems in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Senate is debating the motion of Senator Spindler to suspend Standing Orders in order to debate his motion No. 843, which in effect is for the establishment of a Senate select committee to consider the impact of tariffs on employment. The motion contains a considerable number of terms of reference. As Senator McMullan said, it probably is a tall order for such a Senate select committee to examine those matters and come back with a report by 30 October 1992. But we are not debating that; we are debating the suspension of Standing Orders.

PARA.TAB: I will vote for the suspension of Standing Orders because I believe that it would enable us to have a wide ranging debate on employment, which would be useful at this time. Other matters relating to employment would be able to be brought in. People talk about restructuring industry, but very few people look at the structure of the paid work force itself. That is a danger. If we now had the participation rate that we had 20 years ago, there would be hardly any unemployment. That is a matter that has escaped most people's attention.

There are now hundreds of thousands of people in the paid work force who would rather be out of it doing socially constructive alternatives. For example, the Australian Institute of Family Studies recently published a survey of mothers with small dependant children. Most of them would rather be out of the paid work force nurturing their children at home, yet they are being forced through economic pressures to stay in the paid work force. That is scandalous. Their jobs could be taken by the unemployed. They have been kept in the paid work force because it is most difficult now for a family to subsist on one income. That is because of the substantial drop in the real disposable income of a one income family in the last eight years, and the anti one income family policies and the economic and taxation policies that have been adopted by the Government. Those are the sorts of things that I would like to debate. That is one reason why I propose to support the suspension of Standing Orders.

I understand the concern expressed by Senator Short on behalf of the Opposition when he asked why the Australian Democrats, having supported the guillotine, should now come in here and debate a matter that they want to debate. Frankly, I do not think a debate on Senator Spindler's motion would affect the hours that have been allocated to the various Bills. But members of the Australian Democrats and the Government who voted for the guillotine and limited the debate will have to bear the brunt of it.

One example is the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992. Those honourable senators will have to bear the brunt of complaints by viewers and parents after the results of this broadcasting Bill become effective in the community. Because of the codes of practice developed by the industry itself, the Broadcasting Services Bill will undoubtedly result in far more violence and far more offensive material relating to depictions of sex on free to air television; not to mention the fact that the explanatory memorandum says that it is intended that there be no standards for certain other broadcasting services.

I warn people that I am not going to cop it any more. If people come to me complaining about programs on television, I will tell them to see Senator Coulter. Senator Coulter might vote for my amendments; I do not know. But I will tell them to see somebody, perhaps from my State, who has voted against the amendments that I will be proposing. If they do not do that and say, `Oh, we have not got time to debate them', that is their fault. They are to blame for that and that is where we should lay the blame, rather than denying what I think is an important debate which we should have on the motion that will be before us if this suspension is adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering clause 4 of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and Government amendments Nos 1 and 2. I remind the Committee that the time remaining for the consideration of this Bill is 47 minutes. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

—When the debate was adjourned last night, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, raised a number of questions. One of these questions was what the Opposition's position was in regard to amendment No. 1 and subsequent amendments as proposed by the Government.

PARA.TAB: In view of the fact that this important Bill—which is aimed at making it easier for unions to force the 800,000 subcontractors to join a union against their will—has been guillotined by this Government, with the support of the Australian Democrats, at a time when we have record unemployment and have a great need to improve the productivity of this country, I think anyone listening to this debate will recognise the sham that it is.

However, the Minister asked what our position was on this issue. I want to put the Opposition's position clearly on the record. We consider that this Bill is lousy legislation which never should have been introduced. It was introduced in the face of opposition from every employer group in this country. It was sparked off because of the Troubleshooters case, and the ACTU—the organ grinder—tapping the monkey, the Minister, on the shoulder and saying, `You must amend the industrial relations Bill to counteract the court decision of Troubleshooters.'.

In view of the fact that we have decided that this legislation is so bad and is the wrong legislation to bring into this country at this stage, we will not be opposing any of the amendments, whether they be moved by the Democrats or the Labor Party. We do not believe one can actually create a silk purse out of a sow's ear. That is what this legislation is—a sow's ear. We will be voting against it. We have already voted against it at the second reading stage; we will vote against it at the conclusion of the committee stage and also at the third reading stage. I put on record the Opposition's position on this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —In spite of what Senator Parer says, this is very good legislation and it is needed. But I do not want to take up the time of the chamber on that point. I wish to correct a matter which I raised yesterday. When talking about this legislation I referred to Troubleshooters and to the contract under which—and it says it does not employ people—it makes arrangements for people to work for others. I quoted from a case relating to a person who was injured while working under a Troubleshooters contract, as I put it, and who received no workers compensation.

PARA.TAB: I spoke to Mr Bosa from Troubleshooters who said that that did not relate to any person who worked for Troubleshooters. I told him that I accepted his statement on that point. It would appear from the source of my information that he is correct. To make it quite clear, he says that, although the agreements that the people had to sign if they wanted a job did not at this time include workers compensation, Troubleshooters in fact did have people covered. I just wanted to correct that statement, having spoken to Mr Bosa about the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess this is one of the areas that most concern me and most people. I take the point of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) last night that those of us who had said we were not experts were not experts, and that he was the person who knew most about these things. I will grant him that.

PARA.TAB: I would like the Minister, in his own humble fashion, to tell me something. In the Australian this morning there was an article about the contractors Bill. The penultimate paragraph said:

SPEECH.PARA: As part of the compromise deal with employers, Senator Cook dropped provisions that would have clearly given the IRC jurisdiction over disputes involving contractors.
The Government is taking out proposed section 127A. I remind the Minister of what he said in answer to a question from Senator Crane about sham contracts. He said:

It would have been the purpose of the legislation had I persisted with 127A. 127B is about harsh and unfair contracts, which I would think are probably sham contracts anyway, but they are better described as harsh and unfair. Section 127A was about contracts that were designed to get around or circumvent the provisions of an award. They are sham for the reason that they are not genuine contracts. They are contrivances, inventions and artificialities,—
his use of the language is excellent, is it not?—

designed to put some sort of legal gloss on law breaking and contracting out. As you know, from the evidence that has been given, they are contracts that deal with body hire rather genuine contracting. I, at least, am of the view that, if a particular case of that nature arose and was contested and taken to the High Court and went through the whole appeal system, the High Court would probably find, and this is my judgment, that the Commission has the authority to deal with those sorts of contracts, because its scope is wide enough. It is because I am of this view that I am more relaxed than I might otherwise have been about the 127A changes.

In other words, under proposed section 127B, the Commission may review a contract if the contract is unfair, the contract is harsh, the contract is against the public interest. I think Troubleshooters, in evidence to us, pointed out the number of times that the words `against the public interest' have been used by the trade union movement as a means of getting disputes into the Commission. Paragraph 127B (4)(e) reads:
any other matter the Commission thinks relevant.

Given all those particular outs in proposed section 127B, does the Minister really think that the changes that he has made to the amendments drop the provisions that would have clearly given the IRC jurisdiction over disputes involving contractors?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to make some comments on the removal of proposed section 127A and the impact of proposed section 127B (2). It is worth defining what the differences are. To do so, one has to look at a number of aspects of all the provisions in proposed section 127.

PARA.TAB: The first point that I want to make is that 127A, which has been deleted, was in fact a class action provision. If we look at 127B, we see that it relates to the review of a single contract. That is the fundamental difference. If we go over to 127B (5), we find that the Commission must record its opinion. Of course, the fundamental difference between these two provisions and what has been removed—and this is where the employers have been conned and this legislation has been very cleverly written—is that, while it will take a little longer, the impact will in the longer term be exactly the same.

Once the various cases are recorded, they will be used and waved in front of contractors on the ground. Coercion will be used. It is part and parcel of the whole thing. This is legitimising or legalising coercion. It will be used, it will be waved in front of the various contractors and they will end in up in front of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission whether they want to or not. Their only other option will be to be black-banned from sites. That is what will happen in practice. I think it is worth noting that aspect.

Let us go through what has happened in terms of the removal of that clause. Consideration of cost and efficiency was the first point of proposed new section 127A(1). Cost and efficiency is the only part left out of proposed new section 127B(2). It must be remembered—I particularly put this point to the Democrats—that contracting is about being paid for work. In a normal employee situation, one gets paid for the time worked. There is a very big difference in terms of what can be produced in terms of cost and efficiency. So many people in this country—in the order of one million—choose to work the the contract system because they put efficiencies in place. They do not get involved in some of the more outrageous work practices that exist in some industries—not all industries, but some—and because they are efficient they earn more money for doing a particular job and they go home with more net dollars in their pockets. That is what contracting is all about.

We find in proposed new section 127B (4)(e) the phrase `any other matter that the Commission thinks relevant'. Proposed new section 127A(1)(b) states that it `may have regard to any other matter that the Commission thinks relevant'. They are both there. Proposed new section 127B(4)(d) refers to total remuneration. We see total remuneration referred to again in 127A(1)(a)(iii). If we look a little further at 127B(4)(c) we find reference to the `development of the skills of employees performing work'. That is on the other side of the ledger. As one goes on through the Bill, one finds obligations of an employer on both sides of the ledger.

The point I make in terms of the removal of clause 127A is that it does not remove anything other than the time it will take to do it. The Minister knows well and the Democrats should know well—particularly Senator Spindler, who has been lobbied significantly in terms of this Bill and has had many viewpoints put to him—that the only difference is time. Once there are a number of these particular cases on the record, the impact and the effect will be exactly the same.

It is indeed unfortunate that the major employer organisations in terms of their paid advertising campaign were conned. I also think it is unfortunate that they should go into negotiations with a government—and I do not care which government it is—on the basis that `if you do certain things we will not do something'. That is not how organisations should operate and run. They should assess the merits of where they get to and then make their decision. From this point of view, I am going to defend the Housing Industry Authority, ASBA and the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Western Australia, which has been running paid advertisements in the West Australian, as the Minister would know well, as was its right. It realised that it had been conned in terms of this particular legislation. Because it realised it had been conned, it then took appropriate action to bring the matter to attention.

Last night the Minister said that no evidence had been presented with regard to housing costs and the impact of unionisation. I want to set the record absolutely straight on that. At the hearing of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on Monday the Housing Industry Association was asked, if I remember correctly, by Senator Sowada, to produce some evidence. The Authority did produce that evidence yesterday. It is there for all to see and I am sure the Minister has seen it by now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not.
—I am surprised. I have it here. I seek leave to table the evidence that the Housing Industry Association presented to the Committee yesterday as a result of a request by Senator Sowada.
—Is leave granted for the tabling of that document?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Minister agree, now that he has seen it, that it be incorporated?
—There may be a difficulty with the length of the document.
—It is not particularly long.
—I will put the question, but I do ask Senator Crane to have a look at the length of the document, because it would mean reproducing it in Hansard. Is leave granted?

—I am happy for the document to be tabled, but it is a longish document and I am not quite sure whether it is sought to incorporate all of the document. It contains a number of tables, followed by more chapter and verse and then another set of tables. Is what is being sought to be incorporated the written words or the tables as well, because it would then be quite a lengthy document?

INTERJECT.PARA: IMPACT OF UNIONISATION ON HOUSING COSTS

While building unions have been unsuccessful in penetrating the single-family detached housing sector, they have forced industrial/commercial conditions on some high-rise and higher density housing sites in the major capital cities.

Where building unions have penetrated medium density housing, building companies are required to engage subcontractors on union imposed terms and conditions. The main forms of union interference involve the setting of subcontractor prices well in excess of prices prevailing in single-family detached housing. So while subcontractor labour arrangements might be tolerated by the building unions they behave as a de facto contract regulation tribunal.
Home building firms which operate in both detached and multi-unit housing typically are forced to separately incorporate or to establish two divisional operations.

The Housing Industry Association has compiled a profile of housing projects where subcontracting arrangements are applied under industrial/commercial conditions. These studies were based on actual unionised townhouse and home unit projects undertaken in 1991 and early 1992 and identify the source and magnitude of additional costs over dwellings of a comparable standard produced under non-unionised housing conditions.

The projects were undertaken by different companies in Sydney and Brisbane ranging from budget-priced townhouse developments to high-rise apartments. The additional costs arising from unionisation reflected mainly higher prices for subcontract labour due to the imposition of a union "rate schedule" and additional finance costs from lost time due to union industrial stoppages and closed sites for rostered days off. In some projects site allowances were imposed, requiring builders to maintain log books of hours worked by subcontractors (site allowances typically were expressed in terms of a $1 to $1.50 per hour per on-site worker).

The case studies revealed that unionisation of medium density sites added around 15 per cent to construction costs in three projects and 11.2 per cent in the other project. In the examples of townhouse projects the construction methods were virtually the same as for those applying to detached housing construction, but industrial/commercial conditions were imposed on the townhouse projects because the number of units in the projects exceeded four dwellings. In some areas, unions try to force commercial conditions on builders constructing homes in excess of $1.7m.

For a project home builder of detached housing, on-site labour costs would represent around 25 per cent of total construction costs; building materials, fittings and fixtures would account for the largest component of housing costs at about 50 per cent of the total and the remaining 25 per cent would represent administrative overheads, marketing and selling costs, interest expenses and profit margin. The impact of unionisation is to lift dramatically on-site labour costs. On the basis that on-site labour costs in non-unionised housing construction represent 25 per cent of overall costs of construction, the imposition of union conditions would increase on-site labour costs by between 40 and 50 per cent over traditional arrangements applying in single-family detached housing.

If the building unions were to succeed in subverting housing sites from subcontract arrangements to day-labour as applies to office construction sites the impact on labour productivity and housing costs would be devastating. Many home building companies would be forced to close down their business.

One of the most significant cost penalties arising from the imposition of on-site employees instead of subcontractors is the loss of productivity. Independent subcontractors, unlike direct employees, are remunerated on the basis of results achieved as distinct from the number of hours worked. Subcontractors have the incentive to get on with the job.

Building firms which operate in the commercial building sector estimate that labour productivity of direct employees in that sector is about half of the productivity levels achieved by housing subcontractors. On this basis alone, the replacement of subcontract labour with day labour would push up housing costs by an intolerable 25 per cent. After allowing for both additional holding costs from industrial stoppages and site allowances, the extra cost burden on housing would be in the vicinity of 30-35 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. I wanted to correct that aspect of the situation and bring to the attention of the Minister that as a result of the Committee hearing on Monday this document has been produced.

PARA.TAB: A number of aspects in relation to the clauses before us certainly need addressing. I particularly want to refer to the contract and the public interest. I want to address a question to the Minister as to why, in terms of that particular clause, we find that it is being deleted for certified agreements, yet as far as contractors are concerned, it is not being deleted. As I understand it, the principle reason for its being deleted in terms of the certified agreements is so that there can be variations to what are known as custom and practice. That means that under a certified agreement, for example, work could be carried out on five of any days in a week rather than the traditional Monday to Friday.

In many cases it has been the work practice of contractors to either start work early in the morning or work across the weekend when that is suitable to do the job, taking into account weather conditions and a number of other aspects which impact on the work. Perhaps the Minister will address that aspect. We will find that, as a result of this legislation, practices which existed in the traditional 40- or 38-hour week, or whatever it was, will be forced onto contractors and there will be the sorts of price hikes referred to in the document which I have mentioned.

I emphasise that, according to what the MBA had to say in evidence, which is inconsistent with what the Minister said yesterday, unionisation of the housing industry would push up the costs by no less than 25 per cent. The document shows quite clearly what has occurred in housing developments where unionisation has taken place. As I said last night, there is no way that the housing industry or any other industry can be quarantined from it, including the industry I am involved in, which is agriculture. I am sure the Minister knows very well that, in terms of contracting and transport tasks, it is possible to have a totally different price rate during what is known as the off season from that which applies during the busy times such as seeding and harvesting. Contractors operate during those times because there is competition in the marketplace and there is not the work around. Mark my words; this legislation will destroy all of that.

In essence the provisions mean the same and in practice they will mean the same. The issue is one of public interest. It is inconsistent in terms of industrial policy to have the public interest applying in one area after having recognised in certified agreements that it is no longer appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask the Minister a couple of questions about the Government's intention concerning the measures sought to be legislated in clause 8. Before doing so, I inform the chamber that I will not be moving the amendment circulated in my name to clause 127B(3)(b), at line 18, following discussions last night with the National Employers Forum and after receiving further legal advice.

PARA.TAB: The questions I pose to the Minister centre on the distinction between independent contractors, who essentially are workers and have nothing to sell except their labour, as distinct from self-employed entrepreneurs operating as business people in an open, competitive market.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the difference?

—There is a big difference. I personally, and the Democrats, have absolutely no objection to legislation which gives protection to people who are substantively employees, and who are workers selling nothing but the work of their hands, to ensure that the total remuneration and conditions under which they operate are not inferior to those applying to employees who are working under award conditions. That is a matter of simple justice and equity. That is why it is important to draw that distinction.

PARA.TAB: I have two questions for the Minister. Firstly, would the Minister confirm that the remaining provisions of clause 8 are not intended by the Government to cover self-employed entrepreneurs operating as business people in an open, competitive market? It must be borne in mind that this will have some bearing under the Acts Interpretation Act on how a court would construe the reach and ambit of the provisions contained in clause 8.

The second question that I ask the Minister to address relates to the matter of public interest, which is identified as being one of three grounds which could be used to review a contract. The first ground is that the contract is unfair; the second is that the contract is harsh; and the third is that the contract is against the public interest. On the matter of public interest, I would like the Minister to confirm that the public interest in this provision is aimed at the substance of the contract and not aimed at the desirability of settling an industrial dispute which may then be in existence. A concern that has been brought to my attention on a number of occasions is that the public interest provision could be brought under the provisions of a contract that needs to be reviewed simply because it is the subject of an existing industrial dispute. I draw that distinction. I would appreciate the Minister's answers to these two questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me endeavour, in the time available to me, to answer the questions. I start out of order with Senator Spindler because, with the greatest of respect to the other contributors to this debate, Senator Spindler has taken the time to become familiar with what this Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill is about and, therefore, asks questions that are intelligent rather than questions which reflect no knowledge or understanding of the purposes of this Bill and which simply propose the rhetoric of the Opposition to this legislation without coming to grips with a comprehension of what this legislation does.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler asked two questions. The first related to the distinction that he has made between independent contractors and self-employed entrepreneurs. The type of person that we are talking about in this legislation is a worthwhile distinction to come to grips with.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation doesn't say that.

—Senator Crane is very dogged in his opinions. Certainly, no illumination of fact does anything at all to persuade him. I am breathtaken at his ability to withstand logic. However, let me persist with a question that Senator Spindler has asked. As I recall, this is a question similar to the one Senator Spindler asked me directly when I appeared before the hearing of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, in which he took part. At that time the answer was—and the answer remains—that it is not intended that self-employed entrepreneurs acting in a commercial way are caught by this legislation in the way in which Senator Spindler has drawn attention to it. That is also set out in the legislative statement of intent that I put down at the beginning of this debate in the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: In the hearing on Monday I handed up to the inquiry a list of decisions of the New South Wales Industrial Commission which illustrate the approach that we have taken. I also handed up a decision of the High Court. I stand by that as the position of the Government. I think that does clarify it. I indicate for the record that Senator Spindler is nodding that it does clarify the point.

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't know anything about the real world.

—He knows a damned sight more about the real world than Senator Parer, having been a contractor in the building industry before he was a senator. The next question concerned the public interest and related to whether the Australian Industrial Relations Commission would direct its attention to the public interest in terms of the substance of the contract rather than embracing the wider dispute settling procedures of the Commission. The way this Bill is drawn, supported now by the amendments, makes it explicit that it deals with the substance of the contract. It is, therefore, distinguishable and different from the other powers of the Commission where it is enjoined to prevent and settle industrial disputes.

PARA.TAB: This is the fundamental distinction we want to make. The legislation, stripped of section 127A, which is what the amendment before the Chair will do if carried, comes down to empowering the Commission, in the event of a contract being presented to it by a contractor which is found by the Commission to be harsh and unreasonable, to deal with harsh and unreasonable contracts. That is what the legislation does. It does not provide, as has been suggested in some of these questions, a class action basis for a union to take an action on behalf of all contractors. It explicitly does not provide that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are misleading again. I said that was what was removed.

—You have had your go; listen to the explanation. In this sense, I think any fair-minded, independent commentator would acknowledge that the way we have drafted these provisions reflects the existing provisions in the New South Wales Act enacted by the Greiner Government last year, although I might say that we have done it in a slightly narrower way.

PARA.TAB: Let me go in order of merit to the next set of questions, which were from Senator Calvert. I will come to Senator Crane eventually; he is at the bottom of the class. Senator Calvert asked me two questions. The first was whether I thought that, by removing section 127A, we removed the jurisdiction of the Commission over sham contracts. That is according to the notes I took of the honourable senator's first question. There has been a long debate about what are sham contracts. Sham contracts were best defined by me in evidence I gave to the Senate committee of inquiry on Monday, and which was read into Hansard by Senator Calvert when he asked the question. Sham contracts are contrivances to evade the lawful provision of an award in the pretence that it is an independent contract and not someone working as a wages employee. They are an artificial device to get around the law.

Let me put it in logical sequence. To answer the honourable senator's question, one first has to comprehend the scope of the law as it presently stands. This is a matter of debate between protagonists in the field until such time as the matter comes before the High Court and the High Court finally decides what the legislation means. So, when we talk about what we think the law means, we are dealing in the realm of subjective judgment until it is defined by the High Court, which has the final power to tell us what it means.

I think the powers of the Commission are wider than the powers that are commonly assumed to be its powers. The reason I am relaxed about deleting this provision is that, if an appropriate case went before the High Court—and this is a subjective judgment by me, based on advice coming to me—I think the High Court would find that it has the power to deal with sham contracts because it relates to employment law. I think the Commission would find that it has that power, but that is a matter to be contested in due course should such a case arise.

I am happier to remove this power to make it explicit because of my belief as to what the High Court would find. Whilst I acknowledge that not everyone believes as I do—the employers certainly do not; they think the High Court will find differently—maybe we will all be enlightened sooner or later one way or the other when the High Court makes a decision.

Removing section 127A does substantially change the quality of the legislation before the Committee. The legislation in dealing with independent contractors is about two separate things. The first, which we are now taking out, gives power to the Commission to determine what sort of worker—an independent contractor or a wages employee—should be employed on particular work, and the second deals with giving the Commission power to deal with contracts which are found to be harsh and unreasonable and to then be able to set aside those contracts which are harsh and unreasonable. So, if we take the first section out, we are left with the fair contract section. Let us all take our chances before the High Court when defining the powers of the Commission.

That brings me now to the second question which Senator Calvert asked relating to section 127B as to whether we are clothing the Commission here with a judicial power which would, on the face of it, bring it up against determinations of the High Court. I think the case that is commonly cited here is the boilermakers case in which the High Court, inter alia, found that the Commission has an arbitral power but not a judicial one. Are we in fact running against that precedent? That is what I ascertain the question to be. The answer is that it is not in the way in which we have written it. We do not believe there is a judicial role for the Commission in the way the clauses have been expressed. I am aware that some people have said we are wrong in that and that they may challenge that. That is their right, but we are confident in our opinion and, should there be a challenge, we will defend the legislation.

But please bear this in mind: we are simply asking that the Commission, as a no cost, simple, accessible venue, be able to determine whether a matter is harsh and unfair in a way which does not give it a judicial ring and then be able to replace it with something that brings it up to being fair. If people are opposed to this amendment, they support in an obverse way harsh and unfair contracts. If it is understood by the Opposition that by opposing our legislation it in fact supports things that are harsh and unfair, logically it cannot sustain its own position.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to wait until you get a High Court decision, won't you?

—Let me conclude by coming to Senator Crane because it is about time he got an answer. I notice that he constantly refers to the HIA as the Housing Industry Authority. This is a small, trite point, but let me correct him: it is the Housing Industry Association. It is not an authority of any kind. It has acted reprehensibly in this debate. Senator Crane may or may not know better than the body of mainstream employer organisations in this country, but I notice that he holds his opinion out to be superior to that of the HIA. My question about the HIA and ASBA relates to their integrity when they negotiate with the Government over changes. To take the outcome of those negotiations and the advantages of them but to not honour their obligations shows, I think, a lack of integrity. I have addressed myself to that.

PARA.TAB: I turn now to the particular questions which Senator Crane raised but which are pretty hard to find in the mishmash of rhetoric. It comes down to this: this Bill will not introduce wholesale unionism into the housing sector. It will not do that because no preference provisions will apply. It will not do that because we will accept an amendment from the Australian Democrats which will make it clear that a person does not have to be a member of a union to approach the Industrial Relations Commission to have a harsh and unfair contract set aside. It will not do that because there is no provision for class actions or logs of claims to be served on behalf of independent contractors.

Given that all those things are true, this document—which was never sent to me by the HIA, which is adduced here today and incorporated in Hansard as showing the reasons why housing prices will go up, which I have quickly scanned—is based on a fundamental falsehood that there will be mass unionisation, that as a consequence rates will rise and, therefore, that housing prices will go up as a consequence of this legislation. The falsehood is that the premise is not admissible—the premise is just not true and, as a consequence, nor is the allegation of the Housing Industry Association.
Let me make this clear: being a member of a union is not a criminal act in this country. People are free to join or not join as they choose.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are forcing them to join.

—In fact, there is no enforcement provision here. If Senator Kemp would care to read the legislation simply and clearly rather than the propaganda, he would know that. It is not a criminal act to join a union. Many independent contractors join unions because they work at one time under an award, at another time as independent contractors and, at times of slack demand in the housing industry, often call upon unions to negotiate contract rates for them. That is unexceptional. The rates for contractors in the housing area relate to supply and demand factors and economic factors rather than the award rate. This legislation acknowledges that and simply enables harsh and unfair contracts to be dealt with, leaving everyone free to set whatever contracts they wish as long as those contracts do not offend the test of harshness or unfairness.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: REMUNERATION AND ALLOWANCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Remuneration and Allowances Legislation Amendment Bill is an important piece of legislation, although it may not appear to be so simply on the face of it. The purpose of the Bill is to create a new salary structure for members of the Industrial Relations Commission. It removes the power of the Remuneration Tribunal to determine those salaries. It changes the structure of the Remuneration Tribunal and provides that the Chairman of that Tribunal shall no longer need to be a judge or a retired judge of a State court. It also disallows a decision of the Remuneration Tribunal relating to the salaries of the vice-chancellor and deputy vice-chancellors of the universities in Canberra.

PARA.TAB: In normal circumstances, although the Opposition may be critical of legislation of this type it would not oppose it. But, in fact, this legislation has a purpose which goes far beyond the actual provisions that I have mentioned. This Bill has its genesis—I think that is the word the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has used—in what has become a very long and bitter controversy between the Industrial Relations Commission and the Government. The Government is allied with the ACTU, particularly Mr Kelty, in this bitter struggle that has been going on for more than two years. It is because this legislation is designed to undermine the status of the Industrial Relations Commission, rather than because of anything in particular that the Bill does, that the Opposition wishes to register its strong disapproval and will be voting against the second reading of this Bill.

As I have said, this Bill goes back at least two years. The Minister himself acknowledged this in his second reading speech when he referred to a determination of the Remuneration Tribunal in May 1990 regarding judicial salaries which then included the salaries of the presidential members of the Industrial Relations Commission as well as commissioners. That decision in relation to judicial salaries displeased the Government and it made some changes in relation to judges' salaries. But it seems to have displeased the Government even more in relation to the salaries of the Industrial Relations Commission. Up until then, there had been a close nexus between the salaries paid to Federal Court judges and those paid to the presidential members of the Industrial Relations Commission. Following this decision, the Government broke that nexus—it changed the salaries that were allowed.

The important thing from the point of view of this Bill is that the Government then signalled its disapproval of the decision by breaking this nexus between the salaries of the Industrial Relations Commission and those of the Federal Court. That created a great deal of concern because, as I have said, historically, that status for the presidential commissioners had been observed for many years. Naturally, this was seen not only by the presidential members but also by all the members of the Industrial Relations Commission as a denigration of the status which they had previously enjoyed.

The Minister referred to events which followed this as `robust discussion'. We know from information that is already on the public record that that robust discussion has continued. Indeed, I will refer to some aspects of that in a moment. As a result of that, the Government set up a new advisory group, headed by Mr Gleeson, a former head of the New South Wales Premier's Department, to consider the structure of the Commission and how the new structure would be remunerated.

The Commission's report was ultimately made to the Government and given effect to in the Parliament as amendments to the Industrial Relations Act. Again, I do not need to go into that aspect of it. But in Mr Gleeson's report, the committee made the very firm recommendation that the Government should seek to disallow a determination of the Remuneration Tribunal only if extraordinary circumstances arise, to which the Government responded that the need to maintain the independence of the Remuneration Tribunal is recognised and the Government accepts that it should seek to disallow determinations only in exceptional circumstances.

The Remuneration Tribunal was asked to determine the new salary structure for the Industrial Relations Commission as a result of the legislation based on the Gleeson report. The Remuneration Tribunal did so to the extent that it felt it was able to, but it lacked certain information, for which the Government is responsible. The Government should have provided the further information that the Tribunal required. But instead of doing that, the Government simply brought in this legislation and has decided for itself, and is seeking approval of this Parliament for it, a new salary structure. By doing so, it is flying completely in the face of the recommendation of its own Gleeson committee that this should be done only in exceptional circumstances.

There are no exceptional circumstances that could be made out in this case. The fact that the Government has behaved in this way not only in relation to the Industrial Relations Commission, not only in relation to the Remuneration Tribunal, but also in relation to the recommendations of its own Gleeson committee, has now continued the great concern of the members of the Industrial Relations Commission and the Opposition as to what the Government is really about.

The record, as I said, over the last two years has been one of major stand-off and conflict between the Government and the ACTU on the one side and the membership of the Industrial Relations Commission on the other. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has got into the act. In relation to the April 1991 national wage decision, Mr Keating, who was then the Treasurer, made the most derogatory comments to the effect that that decision had been made by just five officials and that the accord is the primary national income determining institution, not the Commission. There could not have been a more offensive attitude by this Government to the Commission than that now infamous expression of the Prime Minister himself.
