The whole treatment of the Commission over this period of more than two years now is all indicative of the same attitude officially held by the Government towards the Commission. It is really hypocritical in the extreme that the Minister at the table, Senator Cook, who introduced this legislation, has come in and made these statements about his own views or those of the Government on the Industrial Relations Commission. In his second reading speech, he says that the Industrial Relations Commission should continue to have a central role in the industrial and economic life of the nation. I will not quote it all but he goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Its manifest fairness and competence are the reasons why the tribunal system has been so strongly supported so widely and for so long. The Government's support for standing, credibility and independence of the Commission remains as clear and as strong as it has ever been.

Those words can mean absolutely nothing in the light of what the Government has said and done over the last two years in relation to the Commission as a result of this two-year-old conflict in which the Commission has taken such a beating from the Government, and not just from the Minister. In fact, the Minister himself has probably been less guilty than the Prime Minister and, indeed, the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty, both of whom have continued to denigrate the Commission and its role. It is simply hypocritical and totally inconsistent with that attitude of the Government for the Minister to make these remarks which I have quoted from his second reading speech.

PARA.TAB: It is not an easy situation for a body such as the Industrial Relations Commission, which has an independence granted to it by legislation. It is an independence from government which has been historically acknowledged by its own standing and performance over the years; it has earned and observed it. It is clear that it is not easy in those circumstances for a body such as the Commission to defend itself. We know that there has been some correspondence between the Commission and the Minister which, if it could be placed on the public record, I am sure would indicate a lot of that concern.

There are some very clear indications of how the members of the Commission feel about the treatment they have received from this Government. The most notable is a letter which has been made public by Mr Ken Turbet, a former commissioner, who resigned last month in disgust with the way the Government has behaved. That letter has been quoted from fairly freely; it is certainly not unknown to the Minister. I seek leave to have Mr Turbet's letter to Senator Cook incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Australian Industrial Relations Commission

PARA.TAB: 14 April 1992

SPEECH.PARA: Senator the Honourable Peter Cook
Minister for Industrial Relations
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Minister

PARA.TAB: I respond to your letter to the President, Mr Justice Maddern, dated 8 April 1992, by advising of my intention to tender my resignation, as a Commissioner of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, to the Governor General with effect from 10 May 1992.

The reasons for my resignation after 14 years as a Commission member, which was preceded by 16 years service to the trade union movement and 20 years membership of the Australian Labor Party are three-fold.

Firstly, the Government cannot be relied upon to keep to its word. A classic and simple example is your about face on the Gleeson Committee's recommendation in regard to recognition of the Remuneration Tribunal.
Gleeson recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: "The Government should only seek to disallow a remuneration determination of the Tribunal if extraordinary circumstances arise.

PARA.TAB: To which cabinet responded:

SPEECH.PARA: "The need to maintain the independence of the Remuneration Tribunal is recognised and the Government accepts that it should only seek to disallow determinations in exceptional circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Yet the first determination you receive from the Remuneration Tribunal concerning the AIRC following this announcement of policy you reject. There are no "extraordinary or exceptional circumstances" surrounding the Remuneration Tribunal's decision. There are in fact, 15 pages of detailed reasoning supporting the decision. The word of the Government in the form of an official policy statement just wasn't worth the paper it was written on.

Secondly, actions by you and the Government have damaged the public's perception of the independence and integrity of the AIRC. I acknowledge that this is difficult to prove and is denied by Government. However, as a person who lives and works in the industrial community I know it to be a fact. It does not happen overnight and it is not caused by one event or one statement. As a Government and as the responsible Minister you could at least be seen as standing by the Commission, showing support for the principles of conciliation and arbitration. You have either been silent or you have joined the critics.

The public's perception of the independence and integrity of the Commission is dependent on the appointment process. The Commission should represent a fair cross-section of the Australian community. It is essential that the presidential level contains good lawyers together with persons qualified in economics, and those with acknowledged industrial relations skills and experience. Over recent times the top lawyers have retired, among them two QC's. They have not been replaced. Is it that the standing of the Commission has fallen so low that the "silks" who regularly appear before us would never accept an appointment?

It also damages the institution and makes life particularly difficult for the individual when the names of prospective appointees are being speculated upon in the press and in industry journals. If the appointment comes to pass they are perceived to be stooges for the side of industry from which they come. If not, they stand humiliated in the eyes of their peers. Currently, the press and self-styled informed newsletters are touting Jenny Action from the ACTU staff as a Deputy President. One newspaper article headcounted the Presidential members

SPEECH.PARA: noting that Ms Acton will make it four directly out of the ACTU office, plus another two who were members of the ACTU Executive. It cannot be denied that four Deputy Presidents from the ACTU office is hardly a fair cross-section of the Australian industrial community.

PARA.TAB: Finally, my third and most compelling reason for resigning is your Government's total lack of understanding of and respect for the Constitutional requirements of Section 51(xxxv) of the Constitution. There have been five referenda directed at altering this provision. All have failed. The Industrial Relations power is therefore in the same terms as when originally drafted in 1900. The AIRC has been established under S.51 (xxxv) and its jurisdiction and power is limited by the Section as interpreted by the High Court. For my part I have been directly involved in two cases which have contributed to a significant expansion of the Commonwealth's power in this area. I refer to Turbet's case (144 CLR 335) and the Social Welfare case (153 CLR 299) where I was a member of the Full Bench whose decision went to the High Court.

Statements by the then Treasurer, now the current Prime Minister, that the April 1991 National Wage decision was made by just "five officials" and that "the Accord is the primary national income determining institution, not the Commission" reveal a complete lack of understanding of the Nation's Constitution or are a deliberate endeavour to administer the Nation's affairs in a manner inconsistent with its provisions.

Although I could never be described as a devotee of Sir Robert Menzies I recently read a paper he delivered when on a lecture tour in the USA following his retirement as PM. Discussing the constitutional position in regard to industrial relations he said:

SPEECH.PARA: "The system of compulsory arbitration has, on the whole, worked well in Australia, largely because the judges and commissioners have been regarded by the general public as impartial. When my great predecessor, Prime Minister Bruce, attempted in 1929 substantially to repeal the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act he was defeated in the House and was devastatingly defeated in the subsequent General Election. And I need hardly add that nobody has made a similar attempt since.

It is my own, considered opinion that most thoughtful people in Australia would not want the great issues of pay and hours of work, with their tremendous economic implications, dealt with by a political auction at a Federal Election.

PARA.TAB: In my view these words are as apt as they were in 1967. The so called Accord process has been manipulated to such an extent that it is only the Prime Minister and the Secretary of the ACTU who are now involved in its decision making procedures.

A public institution such as the Australian Industrial Relations Commission whose decisions either directly or indirectly through our State counterparts, impact upon every working Australian and their families can only function effectively when it has the respect of the Government which established and maintains it, the organisations which use it and the employers and workers of our Nation who are required to abide by its decisions. Currently, respect from your Government is lacking.
Minister, it is for these reasons that I reluctantly leave the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Yours faithfully
Ken Turbet
COMMISSIONER

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply point out in particular two statements made in that letter. I do not have time to deal with them at any further length. Mr Turbet gives reasons why he has resigned after 14 years as a commissioner and after a total service in the trade union movement of 16 years. As he said, he has had a longstanding membership of the Australian Labor Party. The former commissioner says:

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the Government cannot be relied upon to keep to its word.
He refers to how the Government has treated the Gleeson report, from which I have already quoted. He also says:
Secondly, actions by you and the Government have damaged the public's perception of the independence and integrity of the AIRC.
He goes on to explain that matter. Fortunately, that will now be available in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Not only has Mr Turbet resigned from the Commission in recent weeks but also Justice Peterson, a presidential member of the Commission, resigned from the Commission to take up a position in the New South Wales Industrial Commission. From these two resignations and other rumoured resignations, it is clear that there is the gravest disquiet in the Commission. We also know from press reports that a number of members of the Commission have recently declined an invitation by Senator Cook to meet and discuss these problems. So the feeling is very strong indeed.

It is clear from some of the things I have already said why there would be that concern within the Commission. As I said, it is a combination of the breaking by the Government of the longstanding nexus which had existed between salaries of the presidential members of the Commission and judges of the Federal Court. I presume that the Government will say, `But our legislation restores a nexus'. However, it is not restoring the nexus of the past. The Government has rejected the Remuneration Tribunal's decision which had retained that nexus in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —The umpire's decision.
—Senator Kemp used the word `umpire'; it is one which Senator Cook has been very keen to use.
—One of his favourite words.

—Yes, it is one of his favourite words in relation to this Commission. In debates in this chamber in recent times he has referred to it in just those favourable terms, yet we now know how hypocritical that view is as far as the Government's real feelings are concerned. We know, as I have said, that the Government has been egged on and encouraged at all times in this new attitude to the Commission by none other than the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty. This has been so particularly in relation to the April 1991 national wage case decision which so upset the ACTU.

PARA.TAB: As I said, this has been a longstanding problem. The Government's new salary structure, although it now establishes a new nexus between Federal Court salaries, does so only at the level of new senior deputy presidents. The ordinary deputy presidents—or presidential members as they are generally known—will have a reduced salary which will be 95 per cent of the Federal Court salary. That may not seem to be a very large sum of money, but it is indicative of the attitude of the Government to express its displeasure with decisions that have been made by the Commission, such as the 1991 national wage case decision and others.

I have briefly mentioned other matters arising from this legislation. It changes a decision of the Remuneration Tribunal in relation to salaries of vice-chancellors and deputy vice-chancellors of Canberra universities. The Opposition would not normally be concerned about that, but we have adopted the policy that these matters should be determined in future not by the Remuneration Tribunal, not by this Parliament and certainly not by this Government, but by contractual arrangements entered into by the universities and their staff. They should not be part of decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal. They should not be treated in that way. Certainly the Opposition does not believe that decisions that have been made should now be changed by the Parliament in the way the Government is proposing in this legislation.

Another matter I have mentioned is the change in the status of the Remuneration Tribunal. It takes away from the Tribunal the traditional status of the Chairman, who has always been either a judge of a State court or a retired judge. That has been a very important part of the status of the Tribunal and it has given it that independence and acceptance which it may well not have had if the Chairman had not been a judge of a State court.

The role of the Chairman, Mr Justice Mahoney, has been a very fair and a very distinguished one over many years. Incidentally, both he and the other remaining members of the Tribunal have decided not to seek reappointment to that Tribunal since the Government foreshadowed this legislation. Whether that is due to this legislation is perhaps uncertain, but it is certainly the case that the Chairman of the Tribunal is no longer prepared to continue in that role. If this legislation goes through, his successor will not have to have judicial status.

There again in this legislation is a downgrading of the status of another independent tribunal. Not only the Industrial Relations Commission, but also the Remuneration Tribunal, are in the Government's sights in this legislation. The Government is taking retrograde steps. It is really more for those fundamental reasons, rather than the salaries that are being replaced by this legislation, that the Opposition is strongly opposed to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the Remuneration and Allowances Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and to point out that the Democrats are supporting this Bill. The legislation provides levels of remuneration for all the positions on the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The Remuneration Tribunal had not, in its list of recommendations, set appropriate wages for all of the positions. I take issue there with the previous speaker, Senator Durack.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats believe that a strong and independent Commission is central to the optimum functioning of Australia's industrial relations system. It is the Commission's performance which defines its standing in the community, not the levels of salary paid to its officers. It is the security of tenure which guarantees that commissioners should not have their independence compromised by threats to their employment. Unfortunately, this Bill has been tainted by the power mongering of some members of the industrial relations community and the petulance of one former member of the Commission.

I remind the Senate that section 72(iii) of the Constitution provides that it is the responsibility of the Parliament to fix the salaries of judges. In this Bill the Government is seeking to establish a salary link between judges and members of the Commission appropriate to their responsibilities. Just picking up what Senator Durack was saying, I interpolate that that is absolutely essential at a time of recession, when it is very important that the lid be kept on unrestrained claims for salary increases.

These recommendations that it is appropriate for the Government to establish this link were made by the Gleeson committee review. The Democrats have endorsed the recommendations of the Gleeson committee which echo our own policy goal of preserving and strengthening the status and independence of the Commission, and that is a very important point.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot be serious.

—I am pleased to have that interjection because the Liberal and National parties have been very open about their intention to dismantle the IRC. The hypocrisy of Senator Durack a moment ago talking about the IRC is remarkable in view of the coalition's declared intention to remove it altogether. Its distortions concerning the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill, even referring to it as the subcontractors' legislation, made it absolutely clear that its opposition to this legislation is based on its desire to prevent a workable system of salary determination being instituted. The Opposition wants to politicise the salary levels of the Commission in order to belittle the IRC. It desires an annual wages brawl so as to degrade the Commission's standing and authority with regard to other wage determinations made on behalf of Australian workers.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge that these salary levels are reductions of the Tribunal's recommendations. But we should also acknowledge that the Opposition is hypocritical in its support for big wages for commissioners, in light of the wage restraint being asked of other Australians, and also given its attitude to the IRC and its commitment to removing the IRC altogether. I understand that the commissioners' wages are about $134,000 a year and by no stretch of the imagination could be regarded as low incomes.

This Bill also proposes to alter the salaries of vice-chancellors at the Australian National University and the University of Canberra. Other universities will pay much more in salaries and allowances than these institutions. The Australian National University and the University of Canberra may well be disadvantaged when seeking high quality applicants for these positions. While the Government has indicated that it will adjust funding to other institutions to compensate for these salary reductions at the ANU and the University of Canberra, it is a clumsy and unfortunate way to establish wage ceilings for vice-chancellors. It also leaves it at the discretion of the universities to decide to spend their budget allocations on higher salaries instead of on more student housing or course funding.

We wish to place on record our grave concern about the potential for distortions in funding allocations to compensate for these decisions on the wages of vice-chancellors at the Australian National University and University of Canberra. The implications of this decision are far-reaching and serve to make it a more complex issue than the mere pursuit of parity with other public sector employees. I note that the Bill leaves open the opportunity for the Remuneration Tribunal to recommend adjustment of these wages in the future. The Democrats trust that the Remuneration Tribunal will do so in light of the broader issues of university funding which I have just mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Remuneration and Allowances Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. As my colleague Senator Durack has pointed out, we will be voting against the second reading of this Bill. As John Howard pointed out in the other place, we are opposed to this Bill because it represents, as he said, yet another milestone in the surrender of industrial relations to the ACTU.

PARA.TAB: The basis of this Bill stems from the desire by Mr Bill Kelty to inflict a pay-back on the members of the IRC for their failure to agree to accord mark VI. Senator Cook would be aware of an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald which said:

In April last year, the ACTU president, Martin Ferguson, said the ACTU would "work through" a national wage decision by the Industrial Relations Commission which rejected the ACTU's Accord VI deal but allowed a 2.5 per cent pay rise in the middle of a recession. When Mr Kelty returned from a trip to London, he flatly rejected the wage decision and spearheaded a vicious campaign against it.

Since then, Mr Kelty has waged a personal battle with the commission as he has pushed Mr Keating to sever a link between the salaries of bench members and Federal Court judges. His crusade is certainly personal, because few other union officials give a hoot about the commission's own salaries.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the basis of this Bill. Senator Coulter has come in here and argued—and previous statements by the Australian Democrats have shown that they have long argued, if anything, for an increased role for the IRC—that this Bill reinforces the status and independence of the IRC. He does not have to believe me; he has only to listen to the words of people who are on the bench. Later in my remarks I shall seek to table a confidential letter which was sent to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) on 21 April which I think makes pretty clear the views of at least eight of the deputy presidents of the IRC.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook ceaselessly comes into this chamber and urges us, as Senator Durack says, to accept the umpire's decision. It is interesting that Senator Cook's own view is that he will accept the umpire's decision only when it accords with his own views. It is now a matter of public record that Senator Cook attacked the IRC over the April 1991 national wage case decision. He was, of course, echoing, as I have said, Mr Bill Kelty who suggested that Justice Maddern—and I quote Mr Kelty at the time—`may see himself as some form of Fidel Castro'. This is an astonishing attack by the ACTU on the leader of the IRC.

At various times following the April decision, in a desperate bid to bully the accord through the system, the Government in concert with the ACTU attacked the Commission on every available occasion. I have to cite only the building and waterfront examples. On each occasion, the IRC stood firm against the Cook-Kelty efforts to institute the $12 pay rise. Senator Cook in another example failed to support the IRC decision on the APPM dispute.

We have seen in press reports just today that Senator Cook has failed to follow the IRC's views on the best way to progress superannuation. Yet, in what must be the irony of ironies, Senator Cook urges the coalition to accept the umpire's decision and has the cheek to criticise the coalition for its advocacy of a more limited role for the IRC. I think that gives the lie to Senator Coulter's view that we wish to abolish the IRC. The coalition does not wish to abolish the IRC. The IRC will certainly have a role under the industrial relations policy outlined by John Howard.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has an independent role.

—It has an independent role, as my colleague Senator Durack says. In fact no person in this Parliament, in this chamber, has done more to undermine the independence of the IRC than Senator Cook. Make no mistake—the reason for this comes straight out of the office of Bill Kelty. As Senator Cook has demonstrated on so many other occasions—it has been noted by many press commentators—Senator Cook does exactly what he is told by Bill Kelty.

PARA.TAB: Just to demonstrate the point, recall that Senator Cook wrote to the Remuneration Tribunal to support the maintenance of the current salary structure while the Gleeson inquiry took place. Does Senator Cook recall that letter? Just days later, Senator Cook reneged on this decision as a result of ACTU pressure. The Remuneration Tribunal, another umpire, exposed a lack of merit in the Government's case and decided in favour of an increase. Again Kelty intervened and now the Government has moved to legislate.

As a result of the actions of Senator Cook, I believe, the entire Remuneration Tribunal resigned. Now two IRC members, Justice Peterson and Commissioner Turbet, have resigned in disgust at the Government's decision. Ken Turbet was the third longest serving member of the Commission and prior to his appointment to the Commission he spent 16 years of service to the trade union movement and was a member of the ALP for 20 years. In resigning, Ken Turbet said the Government could not be relied on to keep its word in relation to the IRC. Secondly, he argued that Senator Cook and the Government had damaged the public perception of the independence and integrity of the IRC. Finally, Ken Turbet pointed out that the Government had failed to uphold the requirements of the Constitution in relation to the industrial relations power. They are pretty strong words from a longstanding member of Senator Cook's Party and a very active trade union official.

The great concern of members of the IRC has continued unabated. Let me quote from a letter signed by six of the deputy presidents and two justices which was sent to Senator Cook just over three weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: if this is the letter on the letterhead of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, marked private and confidential and signed by the presidential members, I think it is inappropriate and improper that private and confidential correspondence from presidential members of the Commission to me as the responsible Minister should now be quoted from. That was not the intention, by the marking of this letter, of the presidential members. I think it should be something that should be disallowed in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Perhaps Senator Kemp can elucidate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just planned to quote it. It is an absolute nonsense. Senator Cook is trying to repress a very damaging letter—
—Point of order—
—I have not finished speaking on the point of order. Could Senator Cook sit down while I finish?
—Order! Senator Kemp—

—I am speaking to the point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Cook is trying to suppress a very damaging letter sent to him by members of the IRC. It is a matter of major public interest. Senator Cook may find it embarrassing—and so he should find it embarrassing. But the reality is that this is a matter of public interest and it should be put on the public record.
—I would just like to rule on the point of order if you will bear with me for a moment. There is no ground for the Chair to refuse you permission to read the letter if it is in your possession.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Cook would have known that that was the ruling which had to be given. We appreciate that. Senator Cook received this letter on 21 April. As I pointed out, he is acutely sensitive about it. It was signed by six deputy presidents and two justices. It is a letter which is incredibly damaging to Senator Cook and his whole role in this very grubby exercise. It is no wonder that Senator Cook does not want this letter incorporated. The commissioners wrote to Senator Cook as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . our concerns are well known to you. They were set out in a letter of 6 June 1990 that the President sent to you on behalf of Commission members. They were repeated in subsequent correspondence and referred to in our submissions to the Gleeson Committee and the Remuneration Tribunal. Nothing that has occurred since the letter of 6 June 1990, referred to above, has changed the fundamental concerns then expressed. To the contrary, events. . . have then reinforced our concerns.

Those events have seriously affected, and are seriously affecting, the status and role and future of the Commission, and the status and rights of members of the Commission, both individually and collectively, and the rights of ex-members.

That was not John Howard talking; it was not Senator Peter Durack talking; it was not me talking; it was members of the IRC. These were senior members saying what they thought of Senator Cook's policies. The concluding paragraph of this letter is particularly damning. This is what the six deputy presidents and two justices of the IRC said:

If what underlies the recent actions of the Government is a desire to change the character of the Commission, to alter its culture and the manner in which it operates and to change the nature of appointees who might accept a position on it, then that should be made plain and the Government should make proper and equitable arrangements for the termination of commissions or re-appointment.

In effect, the senior members of the IRC have raised for the first time, albeit in carefully worded terms, the possibility of resigning from the Commission, I believe. This may be a preferable course to the Commission accepting the suborning by the Government and its actions as demonstrated in this Bill.

PARA.TAB: The letter of 21 April to Senator Cook is from a distinguished group of Australians who, I believe, are witnessing the destruction of an institution to which they have committed their prestige, their careers and their future. They are telling Senator Cook and the Government that enough is enough. Like former Commissioner Turbet, they are simply not going to put up with this Government's actions. They are not going to be rolled over by the Bill Keltys of this world and, to take Mr Keating's unlovely phrase, `the collateral damage', which was promised by the Prime Minister.
I believe that their lack of faith in Senator Cook is demonstrated by their unwillingness to meet with the Minister when he invited them for a meeting. This is what they said:

SPEECH.PARA: If individual members of the Commission were to meet privately with you at a time when you are giving consideration to those whom you may wish to recommend to Cabinet as appointees, it could lead to wrong perceptions of both processes and could cause adverse consequences for the Commission as an institution.
This is particularly so, given that the proposed legislation provides no criteria by which appointments could be judged objectively.
That point is worth repeating:
This is particularly so, given that the proposed legislation provides no criteria by which appointments could be judged objectively.

This brings me to my next point. The senior members of the bench are clearly concerned about the appointments the Government proposes to make to the Commission. The Commission already has four members who are straight out of the office of Bill Kelty. I make no comments on their ability or independence, but I express the hope that they have the same fierce independence as the members of the Commission who signed the letter on 21 April. It was a pity that none of the four Deputy Presidents who have an ACTU background—Deputy President Marsh, Mr Justice Boulton, Deputy President MacBean and Deputy President Watson—signed the letter. One hopes that they have made their own views known to the Government in the same strong terms as did those who signed the letter of 21 April. Mr Howard has made his concerns known about there being a further appointment to the IRC from the ACTU. I believe that such an appointment will create enormous controversy and increase fears in the community about the independence of the IRC.

PARA.TAB: I have indicated that this Bill comes before the Parliament today because it stems from a failure of the IRC to implement the accord mark VI of April 1991. This decision led to an attack on the Commission and a desire to undermine its authority. This is part of the pay-back policy beloved of the ACTU. The plain fact of the matter is that the IRC has not been totally compliant with the wishes of the Government and the ACTU. It is, of course, our view that in a number of areas the IRC should have made a number of different decisions. Nevertheless, the IRC, expressing its statutory independence, has refused to rubber stamp the accord processes. Mr Keating, our Prime Minister, warned the IRC to rethink its approach or face being `run over, bypassed or materially damaged'. That comes from a man who said, `We have the Reserve Bank in our pocket. We have the Treasury in our pocket'. Essentially, this Bill is yet another attempt to put the IRC in the Government's pocket.

This Government has damaged the great institutions of this country enormously. This is part of this wide-ranging attack. This country has two nations. One nation is the mates and friends of the Labor Party and the other is the rest of us. If one is not a mate of the Labor Party or is not in the club, one is on the outer in this country. This Government has no respect for institutions or independence. At the end of the day it will reap the bitter harvest, because the public will not put up with it. Over the years there has been—and opinion polls show this—a strong degree of support for the IRC, but this support will rapidly erode if the public feel that this institution is not acting in an independent way.

When the IRC showed it was not prepared to rubber stamp accord mark VI, Mr Keating said that it would suffer some collateral damage. Basically, that is what this Bill is about—an attempt by Senator Cook, Mr Keating and their colleagues to inflict collateral damage in an attempt to bring the IRC into line. I wish to conclude my remarks by quoting from Ken Turbet, who, as Senator Durack pointed out, has left the Commission. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A public institution such as the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, whose decisions either directly, or indirectly through our state counterparts, impact upon every working Australian and their families, can only function effectively when it has the respect of the government which established and maintains it, the organisations which use it, and the employers and workers of our nation who are required to abide by its decisions. Currently
—and this is from an old Labor man—
respect from our government is lacking.

We agree with Ken Turbet; we agree with those who signed the letter dated 21 April in which they stated their fears about the damage which has been done to the IRC. That is why we will be voting against the second reading of this Bill. I seek leave of the Senate to table the letter dated 21 April.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Is leave granted?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the letter marked `private and confidential'. I will not object to the tabling because I know that the Opposition can introduce this into the public record in some form or another, but I want it recorded that this is a confidential letter marked `confidential' by the presidential members. The exposure of their private views that they wanted kept private is a travesty and an invasion of their privacy.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the greatest load of hypocrisy that can be imagined in this place, where hypocrisy has already been raised to an art form by the Opposition. Let me make it clear that the Government's attitude to the Industrial Relations Commission in Australia is that we may disagree from time to time with some of the decisions that it makes, but we will fight to the death for its right to be free and independent and to make those decisions.

PARA.TAB: Our history has been always, and without variation, to have respect for the decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission in the end, whether or not we disagree with them. The very institution of the Industrial Relations Commission is a creation of earlier labour struggles in the broader labour movement last century, out of the disputes in 1891, that gave rise to the call for a better way of settling industrial conflict, and it is a major labour constitutional reform.

Our position is quite clear; through history it has been clear; it is clear now; and it remains clear for the future. But the hypocrisy of the Opposition is that it wants to remove this institution. The wolf in sheep's clothing debate that we have just heard would, to the passing observer, appear to be saying that the greatest defenders of this institution are members of the Opposition, when we know that under their Fightback proposals their intent is to abolish the Commission, remove the umpire and introduce the law of contract between individuals and employers with a resort to the common law. That is the position. Their squeals of frustration when they are exposed only heightens their hypocrisy.

There are a number of matters in this debate that need a reply. My time is brief, so I will be very quick. Senator Durack sought leave—and I gave it—to incorporate a public letter written to me by former Commissioner Ken Turbet on his resignation from the Industrial Relations Commission. I now seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my reply to former Commissioner Turbet which balances the record in terms of this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that a private and confidential reply?
—It is a public reply, issued publicly. It is not a private or confidential document.
—I just wanted to make sure that you are not being a hypocrite again; that's all.
—I have not been a hypocrite before, like Senator Kemp, and I am not a hypocrite now. I seek leave to incorporate this letter in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: MINISTER FOR INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS
PARLIAMENT HOUSE,
CANBERRA, A.C T. 2600
24 April 1992
Commissioner K Turbet
Australian Industrial Relations Commission
Nauru House
80 Collins Street
MELBOURNE VIC 3000
Dear Commissioner Turbet

I have received your letter of 14 April advising of your intention to resign as a member of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. That is your decision and one which I understand has been anticipated for some time. I wish you well in your retirement but I have to say there a number of wrong assertions in your letter that must be corrected.

If you held these views, I am surprised that you never approached me or the Government to put them or to seek an explanation of the Government's position before taking the action you have. The role of the Commission and the perception of this role by its members are too important to let these wrong notions stand.

First, you assert that "the Government cannot be relied upon to keep its word". You cite the reason as the alleged about-face on the Gleeson Committee's recommendation that the Government should only seek to disallow Remuneration Tribunal Determinations "in exceptional circumstances". Your assertion just cannot be substantiated.

The Gleeson Review was a full and open inquiry into the structure of the Commission. It was undertaken by Mr Gerry Gleeson, former head of the NSW Premier's Department, Mr Justice Olsson, a Supreme Court Justice of South Australia and former head of the South Australian Industrial Relations Commission, and Professor Alan Fels, then Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority. It was broadly representative and its findings were unanimous.

The restructuring of the Commission the Review proposed was endorsed by the Government and agreed by the Parliament in 1991. The positions of Vice-President and Senior Deputy Presidents were established in that process and agreed by the Parliament. The Remuneration Tribunal failed to fulfil its responsibility to determine rates of pay for all Commission positions as requested by the Government. This was exceptional and has been a substantial influence on the Government's decision to present legislation to the Parliament to change the Tribunal's determinations and to establish a more certain basis for future determination of remuneration of members of the Commission.

The legislation which has now been introduced will provide levels of remuneration for the full range of positions on the Commission. In addition, it will provide salary increases commensurate with those received by the Australian community at large as a result of National Wage Case Decisions. There are very few in the Australian community who would not see this as appropriate.

Second, I absolutely refute your assertion that I or the Government have taken any action which has damaged either the credibility of the Commission or the public's perception of its independence and integrity. As I have previously stated without qualification to Justice Maddern, both the Government's policy and its public comments have always made clear that a strong and independent Commission is central to its vision of Australian's industrial relations system into the future.

The Gleeson Committee Review and the Government's endorsement of its recommendations were predicated explicitly on the importance of preserving the status and independence of the Commission. Indeed, doubts had already been raised about that standing. The establishment of the Gleeson Review reflected the Government's determination to ensure that those doubts would be quickly set aside through a complete and open examination of the Commission's structure.

It is simply not the case that the public's perception of the Commission is affected by the amount of money paid to its members. It is the Commission's capacity to do its job, and the way in which it does it, that determines the respect with which it is held in the community.

Frankly, I find it bizarre that Parliament's exercise of its legislative power to pronounce on Remuneration Tribunal decisions should be seen as threatening the independence of anybody. I note, for instance, that the Constitution itself (Section 72(iii)) provides that the Parliament fix the remuneration of judges. This constitutional duty of the Parliament in no way threatens, in fact or in appearance, the independence of the judiciary. That the exercise of such Parliamentary power in relation to non-judges—such as members of the Commission—should be thought to be such a threat defies all logic and commonsense.

The Constitution provides judicial remuneration ultimately to be the responsibility of the Parliament. The Government is legislating to re-establish a salary link between judges and members of the Commission. This in practice enshrines ultimate responsibility on the Parliament for the remuneration of members of the Commission. The Remuneration Tribunal was established in 1973 and from its inception its operations have contained provisions which allow the Parliament to have the final word. It has been the common view within the Parliament that this is the way in which the Tribunal should operate. Comments by the Opposition during the Parliamentary debate over the Remuneration and Allowances Bill in 1991 made clear their continued commitment to principles which have been adhered to since 1973.

Decisions of the Tribunal have not been accepted by the Parliament on seven occasions since its establishment. It is clear that the power of ultimate decision of the Parliament has been seen by both sides of politics not as a theoretical power but as one that can and should be utilised on appropriate occasions. And it is not as though the Parliament's power has been used only or predominantly in relation to members of the Commission. It has, in fact, been mainly used in relation to overturning salaries for members of Parliament. It has also been used in relation to senior public servants and vice-chancellors of universities. Has it ever been seriously suggested that the independence of these people has thereby been compromised?

It is, of course, grotesque that anyone should suggest that members of the Commission—or other senior officials or statutory office-holders—would allow their independence or judgement to be affected by matters of remuneration of this kind. I cannot believe that members of the Commission would be so affected and it is beyond my understanding that people should have tried to suggest that there is a perception that they would have been.

Third, I am bemused by your suggestion that I "could at least be seen to be standing by the Commission, showing support for the principles of conciliation and arbitration". I just cannot understand what you are referring to—unless you are confusing the Government's support for workplace bargaining with a lack of support for the principles of conciliation and arbitration.

If this is the case, it is just not right to suggest that support for workplace bargaining and the encouragement of employers and unions to reach agreement about terms and conditions of employment amount to a lack of support for the Commission and the abandonment of the principles of conciliation and arbitration. The Commission itself, through its most recent National Wage Decision, has recognised that the economy must move towards greater workplace bargaining.

It is the Government's recognition of the Commission's central role in ensuring equity and fairness in workplace agreements that is central here. The Commission's role is integral to the legislative changes the Government has in mind. Moreover, the legislation will strengthen the Commission's role and expand its jurisdiction to deal with disputes involving independent contractors. This is a tangible statement of the importance the Government gives to a strong and independent role for the Commission.

By way of contrast, I refer you to the most recent statements by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, who said in Auckland this week that, under the Opposition's industrial relations policies, the Commission "will become increasingly less relevant". That is the real threat to the role and independence of the Commission.

Fourth, the delay in filling a number of vacancies on the Commission is directly due to the establishment of the new structure for it and to the further legislation now in the Parliament affecting it. A number of appointments will be made in the near future. Any speculation about the identity of proposed appointees is regrettable, but such speculation does not emanate from the Government. I note, by way of interest, that much of the recent media speculation over the remuneration issue has likewise been generated elsewhere—and not in government, or apparently even union, circles.

I take your references to Section 51(xxxv) of the Constitution to be intended to demonstrate the constitutional recognition of the place of an independent arbitral tribunal in the federal system of industrial relations. As I have said, the Government accepts and recognises this role. Indeed, the Constitution provides the basis for its protection by the High Court. You imply that this role for the Commission is compromised by the Government's proposals on remuneration, by media speculation about appointments and by disagreement by the Government over some Commission decisions. I do not see how such an implication could reasonably be accepted on any impartial judgement.

Finally, I agree absolutely that an institution of such national importance as the Industrial Relations Commission—whose decisions affect every Australian worker—must have the respect of Government, those workers affected by it and the community generally. No action taken by the Government has been intended to—or would be intended to—diminish the integrity or the independence of the Commission.

I am sorry that you have felt the need to respond in the way you have and to retire early from the Commission. But it is important that it be appreciated that the Government cannot accept the reasoning you have given for your decision.
Yours sincerely
Peter Cook

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate has revolved around the question of whether or not there are any extraordinary circumstances following the Remuneration Commission's decision in relation to the determination of salaries for members of the Industrial Relations Commission, and in relation to the determination of the wage increase of 25 per cent for vice-chancellors. The Government's undertaking was that we would abide by determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal, which is not, as has been styled here, the umpire; in this sense, Parliament is the umpire with respect to the proceedings of the Remuneration Tribunal.
—Bill Kelty is the umpire for you; let's face it.

—Senator Kemp interjects. I draw his attention to the actions of the Fraser Government of which he was not a member but which was, nonetheless, of his Party. As was its prerogative—and I do not object to it—it overturned decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal, as we now propose to overturn one. But we gave our undertaking that we would only do so if there were exceptional circumstances. What are the circumstances? The circumstance which we regard as exceptional in this case is that this Parliament had decided on a range of positions on the Industrial Relations Commission.

PARA.TAB: Two of those positions—Vice-President and Senior Deputy President of the Commission—were sent to the Remuneration Tribunal for a salary to be determined. The Remuneration Tribunal, for reasons that I still cannot fathom, decided not to determine a salary for those positions. This means that I, as the Minister, on behalf of this Government, am not in a position to invite any person to fill the vacancies created by this Parliament for those positions. One cannot invite someone to accept an appointment for which there is no salary. That, therefore, effectively negates the will of this Parliament.

This Parliament's will was expressed, whether the Opposition approved of it or not, in the creation of those two positions. The failure of the Remuneration Tribunal to set a salary means that we cannot invite anyone to fill those positions. I think that by any fair and objective test that is a circumstance which is exceptional. It is for that reason and that reason alone that we have proposed to overturn the decision of the Remuneration Tribunal and to set salaries at the level recommended to us by the Gleeson report—as has been remarked in this debate, an independent report, free of any influence of government, and a report that we have adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! Don't expect us to believe that rubbish.
—I hear the interjection, `Don't expect me to believe that the Gleeson report was free and independent'.
—That is not what I said; you are lying again.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, that remark is unparliamentary and should be withdrawn. The honourable senator is out of his place. He should sit in his right place.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Senator Archer, will you withdraw that remark?.

TALK.START.PARA: —With pleasure, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—Thank you. I call the Minister.
—Thank you.
—You are running out of time.

—I am running out of time to make a full explanation, but I am convinced that a full explanation will not change Senator Patterson's prejudices. Let me go to the Gleeson Committee. The Gleeson Committee comprised three distinguished Australians: Gerry Gleeson, who is a former head of the Premier's Department in New South Wales, Professor Alan Fels, who is the Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority and a distinguished economics professor, and Judge Olsson, who is a judge of the South Australian Supreme Court and a former President of the South Australian Industrial Relations Commission. They were unanimous, as an independent body, in recommending a structure and scale of rates to this Government. As I say, we sent that whole report to the Remuneration Tribunal, which then did not set those salaries for the Vice-President and for the Senior Deputy President. It is on that basis that Parliament must fill the vacuum.

PARA.TAB: To style the Remuneration Tribunal as the umpire in this area is erroneous—that is, of course, well known in the case of the Opposition—because the Remuneration Tribunal is an advisory body. All of its determinations come here for allowance or disallowance. The structure of this body is to advise. If not disallowed, its determinations become law. But, if disallowed, Parliament will decide by virtue of overruling those decisions. That is all we are doing in this case.

As to the independence of the Tribunal, the fundamental and most sacrosanct thing of all is that the Industrial Relations Tribunal be free to exercise its jurisdiction in a way in which it is respected by all parties in the community and not interfered with by government or by anyone else. This legislation does not do that. We are basing ourselves on the findings of what the right level of remuneration is by an independent body that considered all of the evidence and made that recommendation.

The Opposition wants to make access to the Industrial Relations Commission a voluntary act in which both parties have to agree—the employer and the employee. So, if an employer withholds consent, there is no resort to the umpire and no ability for the arbitrator to make a fair determination. That amounts to undermining the total institution. It is fundamental hypocrisy to pretend otherwise. It is fundamentally fraudulent for Opposition members to argue that they are somehow the protectors of this institution while they hold a commitment to those views. I commend the Bill to the Senate and trust that it will pass on the numbers.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I advise the Senate that, following the decision of Senator Peter Durack to resign as Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, the Liberal Party in the Senate has met and elected Senator Jim Short as the new Deputy Leader.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given the decision by the Government to press ahead with its anti-jobs legislation in the form of the superannuation guarantee levy, aided and abetted by the Democrats, is the Government aware that the decision has been roundly condemned by almost every welfare, women's and retirement incomes group in the country—from ACOSS to the Over 50's Friendly Society, the Australian Council on the Ageing, the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation and the Womens Electoral Lobby? Can the Minister advise the Senate what the Government understands to be the concerns of these groups regarding the shambles that is superannuation under Labor, and what does the Government intend to do to address these concerns?

—I am aware that a number of organisations have expressed criticisms of the decision. I have to say that the criticisms represent diffuse and different points of view, and no doubt the Treasurer will be having consultations with various groups about those criticisms as time goes by.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I say, by way of preface, that I regard that as an outrageous affront to the Senate and to all those people in the community who have an interest in this subject.
—What is the point of order?

—I did not say it was a point of order. This is yet the latest occasion on which the Minister has come in here without the slightest knowledge or interest in the major issue of the day. My question is this: has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that these diffuse groups with diffuse views, as he put it, actually released a joint statement last night strongly criticising what has happened in recent days and pointing out the job consequences of this deal? Does he have any conception of what will flow, when Senator Cook and Mr Dawkins both concede there will be job losses—as indeed does Senator Kernot—but use such vague expressions as `negligible'? Has his Government the slightest interest at all in addressing these concerns and in explaining why a backroom deal with the ACTU should substitute for some sort of sensible public discussion on a very serious issue and probably the most important concern that Australians have at the moment—that is, the impact on jobs? Would the Minister kindly start taking issues seriously?

—The question was not asked in an environment in which there had been no public discussion about this issue for a long time. The Government's policy intentions have been clear for a long time. The fact that there has been some adverse comment from organisations about the decision today is not a reason for saying that the Government's policy is wrong in terms of its long term objectives.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston talks about employment. There is a difference of opinion about the impact on employment between the Government and its advisers, and some other groups which have made comments about it. That is true: there is a difference of opinion. That does not mean for a moment that Senator Alston is right, or has ever been right, in his contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they all wrong?

—I am talking about Senator Alston for the time being; he ought to be flattered. I do not often talk about the honourable senator; he mainly talks about himself. I am saying that that does not mean that Senator Alston is right or ever has been right on this particular issue. It is true that Mr Dawkins and perhaps Senator Cook—I am not aware of any statement made by Senator Cook—have made comments—
—He made a meal of it yesterday.
—I did not say what you said I said. Read Hansard.
—You don't know what you think you have said.
—Read Hansard, fool!
—Order! Senator Alston, you have asked your supplementary question.

—It is true that they have made comments about the employment impacts of the superannuation decision. Let me say that the superannuation decision has been reached in a context of our capacity to influence the wages outcomes and our capacity to talk to the ACTU about the influence of the superannuation decision on wage claims. That is a capacity that the Opposition never had when it was in government and would never have if it were in government again. That is something which the Opposition would be totally unable to influence.
—You are run by the ACTU.

—If Senator Kemp wants to be reminded of the question of wages policy, I am surprised at him. After all, when Senator Kemp's brother was an adviser here and he was rusting away in a think-tank, we had the worst wages outcomes in the history of this country. That is the Opposition's record and that would be the experience of this country under an alternative government if the Opposition were ever elected.
—You know why it is that this has happened. It is because of Halfpenny.
—Because of Halfpenny?
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—It was because of the former Liberal Prime Minister and his Minister for Industrial Relations. That is the reason for the wage outcomes which occurred in the period of the Fraser Government.

PARA.TAB: Let me make the point again that an important part of the decision on superannuation is that it will influence wage outcomes. The Government's record on sensible wage outcomes is an important one. Of course, the Opposition has never obtained sensible wage outcomes in government. It has been a hallmark of this period of government that we have and we will continue to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the welcome announcement earlier today of additional nuclear arms cuts by the United States and Russia. I ask the Minister to explain the significance of this announcement. Given that even after these cuts each side will still have at least 3,000 nuclear warheads, does the Minister see any prospect of further reductions in nuclear weapons, including cuts by the other countries which have stockpiles of nuclear weapons?

—The Australian Government is delighted by the news that Presidents Bush and Yeltsin have announced agreement to major further cuts in their strategic arsenals beyond the reductions that were anticipated and agreed in the START talks. While some details have yet to be clarified, it is clear that the two leaders have given very positive effect to their unilateral statements in January offering to negotiate deep cuts beyond the START agreement limits.

PARA.TAB: Today's announcement focuses in particular, and very encouragingly in that respect, on heavy and multiple warhead intercontinental ballistic missiles. According to President Bush, at the latest by 2003 the US and Russia are to cut their strategic nuclear systems to between 3,000 and 3,500 warheads each. That is significantly below the level agreed to in START, which was approximately 6,000 warheads each.

The current arsenals of the two are estimated at, in total, approximately 21,000 strategic warheads. In addition, of course, there are some 8,000 tactical nuclear warheads in existence between the two of them, or there will be after the presently agreed, or presently identified, unilateral cuts are carried through. The announcement does represent a dramatic and extremely welcome reduction in nuclear armories. But beyond that it also gives clear expression to the significantly improved security relationship between the two nuclear superpowers.

It is too early, I think, to comment on the prospects for further reductions. We have heard the remarks attributed to President Yeltsin that the scope for further cuts will be limited by practical difficulties associated with destruction schedules. While such practical issues do need to be acknowledged, we are encouraged that the timeframe for reduction to the agreed levels does appear to be based on the tightest possible destruction schedule.

In the case of the other nuclear weapon states—the UK, France and China—I think this is an appropriate occasion for the Australian Government to call on them, as I now do, to follow the example of Russia and the United States and to start the process of implementing cuts in their nuclear arsenals. We do not accept that the smaller size of their arsenals in any way frees them from their continuing obligation to negotiate measures of nuclear disarmament. In this context, we consider also that a cessation of nuclear testing is an essential component of nuclear disarmament, and we call on the UK, the United States and China, as a first step, to follow France and Russia in their current moratorium on testing.

Such a universal moratorium leading to a comprehensive test ban treaty would achieve a longstanding Australian policy objective, quite apart from anything else, and contribute in a practical way to the process of nuclear disarmament which has been given, again I say, such a welcome further impetus by today's agreement between the United States and Russia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to his claim yesterday that the Foreign Investment Review Board application `in respect of the companies concerned' in the Keating multi-million dollar, multinational joint pig venture was approved without any public announcement on Christmas Eve of 1991, five days after Paul Keating became Prime Minister—happy Christmas, Mr Keating! How was it possible for this project to receive such unpublicised approval when it was not until a meeting in Denmark on 3 March 1992, more than two months later, that the Danpork board agreed to confirm Australia as an investment location, to finalise joint venture arrangements with a local producer, the Brown and Hatton group, and to nominate a site for a processing plant? As there was not even an agreed site for a processing plant in this $80m joint venture in December, let alone an agreement with a joint venturer, can the Minister give an unequivocal assurance that the FIRB approval that the then Treasurer, Mr Willis, gave to Mr Keating as a Christmas present on 24 December was for the same joint venture proposal that was not even agreed in outline until April 1992, more than three months later, and which is still the subject of three weeks of negotiation so far in Denmark by Mr Keating's nominee on the board of Euphron, Mr Stephen Coudounaris?

—This is pretty desperate stuff but, after yesterday's effort, one is not surprised. If those opposite want to understand the history of the Foreign Investment Review Board treatment of the proposed joint venture between Danpork and Brown and Hatton, let me say that the Board received an application on 26 August 1991. Approval was granted by the then Treasurer on 28 September 1991 and the parties were advised on 2 October 1991. An application for variation, which was a matter I referred to yesterday, was lodged on 5 December and dealt with on 23 December. The parties were advised on 24 December.

PARA.TAB: First of all, Senator Baume asked the question, `Why was it unpublicised?'. The Foreign Investment Review Board deals with many applications and many approvals. They are not, unless they are hugely significant in terms of the size of the foreign investment and so on, matters which receive publicity; that is something which any one of those opposite ought to know and understand.

Senator Baume clearly also does not understand that applications for Foreign Investment Review Board approval are frequently made by companies, and they are made on the basis of various other things happening subsequent to approval being given. It is an application for foreign investment in a particular project. All sorts of things usually have to be resolved before a project in any one of those cases goes ahead. There is nothing abnormal about that. Only Senator Baume could try to see some abnormality in this matter. The Leader of the Opposition has cast Senator Baume in the role of asking these questions in return for a position on the Opposition front bench. Those opposite ask these questions in here because they are apparently not game to ask them in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you noticed that it is not sitting?

—I know it is not sitting. In the House of Representatives a very clear procedure has been laid down by this Government about how these matters might be dealt with in the Parliament. As an opposition, those opposite have chosen never to avail themselves of those procedures in the House of Representatives which we gave to the Parliament and to the people of Australia. That is their problem, not ours. In terms of this desperate effort by Senator Baume, the fact of the matter is that there is nothing in either the question or the answer which ought to excite him particularly.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his refusal to give an unequivocal assurance that it is the same proposal. As the board of Danpork only agreed, in principle, to an Australian venture last November—two months after the claimed revised approval date that the Minister has now given us—will the Government now come clean on this issue and explain clearly whether the Prime Minister's conflict of interest relates to the One Nation decision or to the FIRB decisions?
—Yesterday Senator Baume made allegations about the conflict of interest question, allegations which he would never be game to make outside.
—I made them outside.

—Will Dr Hewson subsidise Senator Baume there, too? Will Dr Hewson subsidise Senator Baume in respect of legal actions as well? In respect of the conflict of interest issue, Senator Baume made these allegations yesterday, and they were dealt with.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the FIRB, I have already answered the substantial question. I do not know anything about decisions made by the board of Danpork in Denmark. I do not know anything about it, I am not particularly interested and members of the public are not particularly interested. The fact of the matter is that the Foreign Investment Review Board applications were made by two companies, Danpork and Brown and Hatton. With his creepy mind, Senator Baume has sought to establish a connection between those applications and the Prime Minister. I understand Senator Baume's role in this place. He is not discharging it very effectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The word `spiv' was used three times on both sides during that answer. It is unparliamentary. Do not use it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to reports that the recent aviation policy will have an adverse effect on airline services available in Queensland and that plane fares will soar. Is there any genuine ground for such fears and has the Minister undertaken any initiatives to allay such fears? Is the Minister aware of plans by the United States airline, Northwest Airlines, for direct flights from Japan to Brisbane?

—I am aware of media reports of statements made by the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Fischer, that `Queensland is to be axed as a front-runner for the headquarters of a second international airline'. That really was quite a ridiculous statement for Mr Fischer to make. The base of an airline for its operations in Australia is absolutely a matter for the commercial judgment, obviously, of the airline involved.

PARA.TAB: The next fallacy outlined by Mr Fischer was an allegation that some political deal had been done to ensure that Melbourne would be the base for the new carrier. The Leader of the National Party seems to be completely oblivious of the fact that the reason why Melbourne is a likely base—I have no difficulty in saying so—for the second international carrier is that Melbourne is currently the operational base and headquarters of Ansett Airlines. Clearly, in terms of the criteria that are being laid down by the Government for providing viable and sustainable competition for additional Australasian carriers—

TALK.START.PARA: —If it wants to go to Sydney, will you let it?

—That is a matter entirely for Ansett. I might also add that that is assuming Ansett will be successful in any applications it makes. Clearly, Ansett is well placed—I am simply stating the obvious—to provide a viable alternative in respect of another Australian carrier having access to international routes, as I have stated many times publicly. Ansett is well placed to become an international carrier in the future, following the policy changes announced by this Government and welcomed by the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: There was no deal. Tourism will be one of the major beneficiaries of this Government's aviation policy and the changes that have been made to it. With future opportunities for a second Australian international carrier to operate services from Queensland to important markets, such as South East Asia and New Zealand, the vitally important tourist industry of the sunshine State will undoubtedly benefit from this Government's policy announcements.

In reference to the services that Senator Jones mentioned, it is a fact that the Government has recently announced approvals for additional charters from Japan to Queensland that will bring enormous additional benefit to the tourist industry of that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does Australia still have an Austrade office operating in Burma? If so, when will it be closed? Which Australian companies currently have business interests in Burma? Given that the Burmese regime remains as brutal and as illegal as ever, as evidenced by the continuing plight of refugees fleeing its atrocities, will the Government consider requesting the United Nations Security Council to meet on the question of Burma, as requested three weeks ago by the main Burmese opposition leaders?

—A small Austrade office is currently in operation in Rangoon, consisting of two locally engaged staff responding to trade inquiries but not otherwise engaged in substantial business. The question of the continued operation of that office is under close review by the Government, as I indicated not so long ago in answer to a question from Senator Schacht.

PARA.TAB: The number of Australian companies with business interests in Burma is approximately 15 at this stage. Some major companies have recently pulled out of the country, in particular BHP, which ended its operations just last week. At the moment there are no Australian companies with significant commercial interests in Burma, but I will advise the Senate if there is any change in that state of affairs over time. Overall, Australian trade with Burma is presently very slight; last year two-way trade totalled just $7.4m.

The Government is considering a range of options it can employ to give further effect to our policy of promoting urgent democratic change and respect for human rights in Burma. While there have been some recent moves by SLORC, the State Law and Order Restoration Council, in the direction of political liberalisation, including the release now of some 183 political prisoners and the convening of the first stage of constitutional talks on 23 June next, these constitute manifestly only a very small step in the long overdue process of reform in that country. There are obvious weaknesses in the talks process that is proposed to the extent that it may only be attended by a limited number of participants, certainly not the 34 MPs who are presently in gaol, along with some 2,000 other political prisoners, and certainly not Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of the NLD.

There is still not enough evidence of genuine reform by the SLORC, notwithstanding the steps that have been taken. We are keeping the state of affairs very closely under review, consulting with other countries at every available opportunity and considering what further action it may be appropriate to take and when to take it. I say also that we are deeply concerned about the plight of the Rohingya refugees and the continued refusal of the Burmese authorities to permit a UNHCR presence in Burma, which could help in the repatriation process.

Recent consultations with like-minded countries have, however, made it unlikely that there will be significant support for action in the UN Security Council in the immediately foreseeable future. Under those circumstances, I can only say that we are keeping under close review other options which we might be able to take up in respect of the situation there.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's assessment of the appointment of Anand Panyarachun as Prime Minister of Thailand and of other recent events in that country?

—Australia very warmly welcomes the appointment by the King on 10 June of Anand Panyarachun as the new Prime Minister and the announcement by Anand on 14 June of a new Cabinet. Prime Minister Keating wrote to him on 12 June, congratulating him and expressing the hope that under the new Prime Minister Thailand would be able to restore confidence in the process of democratic government and political dialogue.

PARA.TAB: Anand is a widely respected civilian figure. He was interim Prime Minister after the February 1991 coup. In that period he established a reputation as a principled leader, committed to transparent government independent from outside influences, particularly the military. He has made it very clear that he will serve only in the capacity of Prime Minister of an interim government for an interim period in order to preside over the formal dissolution of the Parliament and the holding of fresh elections, which should take place in about four months time. His new Cabinet is more or less identical to the 1991 interim Cabinet. I particularly welcome the return of Arsa Sarasin as interim Foreign Minister. He played a valuable role in the interim Government.

I should further say that another positive development in recent days is the third and final reading in the Thai Parliament of four amendments to the Constitution, which include, among other things, a requirement that the Prime Minister be an elected member of parliament.

On the question of the aftermath of the unhappy, tragic events of a few weeks ago, we continue to be very concerned by the latest Thai figures on the number of people unaccounted for after that violence. The Australian Embassy in Bangkok has reported to me that the latest Thai Government Interior Ministry figures put the number of dead at 40 and missing at 517. Independent organisations are reporting between 49 and 52 dead. One of those organisations, the Mahidol University, reports 49 dead, 606 injured and 697 missing. Other figures, even larger, have been reported from other sources.

It is widely acknowledged in Bangkok that caution should be used in interpreting the numbers of those reported missing. Some are being reported missing by family and friends only because they have not been seen since the suppression, not because there is any real belief that they are in fact dead. Nonetheless, putting all of the available information together, the consensus we are getting from most observers in Bangkok is that the final death toll is likely to be of the order of 100 at least.

Australia certainly hopes that under Prime Minister Anand Thailand's internal processes will hold to account those responsible for the violence of 17 and 21 May. We will continue to monitor closely the progress of parliamentary and governmental committees established to look into recent events. We are encouraged by reports that the new Thai Defence Minister has pledged full support for continuing investigations of the violence. Taking all these various considerations into account, our response has been to treat the relationship as largely, for the moment, back to normality. But we will continue to keep on hold senior level military contacts with Thailand.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the fact that Mr Keating, in his capacity as a part owner of a business, is benefiting from an $800,000 assistance package from the New South Wales Government for the Danpork Australia piggery project, including payroll tax concessions totalling in excess of $600,000. Will Mr Keating take the steps which are within his power as Prime Minister to enable all other businesses to enjoy the same payroll tax concessions as proposed by the coalition in its Fightback proposals to enable these businesses to grow and create jobs as well?

—One could draw the inference from the question that there is a particular payroll tax concession for a particular company because of its particular situation. I think that is a question that Senator Short should get his colleagues to address to the Premier of New South Wales in Question Time in the New South Wales Parliament. That is what he should do with that question because that is the appropriate forum for the question to be asked.
