PARA.TAB: In so far as Senator Short seeks to make a general political point in pursuit of the argument about payroll tax and Australian competitiveness generally, that is something which is in the debate of this chamber, and I do not wish to add to anything that has been said over the years or over the last few months since this issue came into public contention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Button obviously chose deliberately to misrepresent my question, which was not in any way an attack on the New South Wales Government but an attack on his Government for failing to extend that concession to all businesses by the abolition of payroll tax. That is what the question was about. However, in view of the Prime Minister's obvious belief that payroll tax relief will assist his business, is Senator Button again at odds with his Prime Minister following his answer to me yesterday that he—that is, Senator Button—does not think payroll tax abolition would provide a solution to the horrendous level of unemployment that his Government's policies have provided?

—I think it is a tragedy for this country to have an Opposition purporting yesterday to be so concerned about this issue and to have Senator Hill in here today telling fibs about youth unemployment in South Australia. In the recession of those opposite in 1983, youth unemployment in South Australia was higher than it is now—
—What are you talking about? Forty-six per cent of kids in South Australia are looking for work who cannot get it, the highest in recorded statistics.
—Higher than it is now—
—It was not higher than it is now.
—It was. If we look at the number of unemployed youth in South Australia in 1983 compared with now, there are more than 2,000 more unemployed.
—That's a lot a rubbish.

—The Opposition ought to look at these figures before coming in here weeping crocodile tears about figures which it is quite pleased with. We have followed in this Senate the tortuous snail trail that has been set down by Senator Baume in relation to this issue; he leaves across the political landscape in this country a trail like a snail's which Senator Short is now trying to get himself on to. If Senator Short in all his grubbiness wants to have it out about members of the Opposition front bench and what benefits they would get from the Opposition's policies, I will have it out with him. Look at my Opposition spokesman: I could go for him in this place about his interests. I have never done it. The benefits that many Opposition spokesmen will enjoy—as they did in the period of the Fraser Government—from the Opposition's policies is huge. Senator Short tries to make a particular grubby little point about a decision of the New South Wales Government, with which he ought to take up this issue.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of a workplace agreement developed at the National Australia Bank which is improving productivity by providing the bank and its employees with much greater flexibility in the way work is organised? If so, does this agreement indicate that the cooperative system of workplace bargaining supported by the Government is the most effective and efficient method of improving productivity in all sectors of the economy? Further, in view of the recent industrial disputation in Burnie, could APPM learn some lessons from companies such as the National Australia Bank?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —To the last question: absolutely right; APPM could learn a lot from the approach that the National Australia Bank has taken. This is a question which enables me to give the Senate some good news about the continuing improvement in the Australian workplace through the change in workplace culture in this country and workplace reform.

PARA.TAB: The changes that the Senate enacted just before lunch to section 155 of the Federal Act will ensure that there will now be a flood of workplace agreements. I can only trust that they will be based on the sort of agreement that has been reached between the Finance Sector Union and the National Australia Bank, which covers some 23,000 workers in that institution. That is a fine example of the type of workplace change—without conflict, with consensus and with cooperation—that this Government identifies as the positive way forward in this country for workplace change.

I have previously spoken about workplace agreements at Rheem, Email Simpson, Anderson Rae, ICI, ASTA, Australian Newsprint Mills, SPC, Kimberly-Clarke and Don Smallgoods. All those companies have engaged in extensive workplace reform. But all those companies have been in the manufacturing sector.

The National Australia Bank is a significant banking institution in the finance sector in Australia. It, too, has transposed the cooperative mentality and approach in the workplace. In our system of workplace bargaining, in cooperation with and through the union structure, it has negotiated an agreement which has now been registered in the Industrial Relations Commission. That agreement, which introduces innovation in how working hours are to be organised, will ensure a productivity increase for the company which will be shared by the workers in that company.

The facet of this agreement that is particularly engaging is that full time workers of this company can now choose how they work their hours, as long as they work a total of 38 in their working week and as long as they meet their job demands. The bank has introduced a process called Flexinet, which ensures that the work is carried out but in a way which suits the family responsibilities and obligations of its employees. This company, National Australia Bank, won the Affirmative Action Agency award in the work and family category because of its in-house policies which ensure that workers who have family and child caring responsibilities are able to adapt their working days to meet those responsibilities as well as their work responsibilities.

I have been asked how this relates to APPM. In the course of the APPM dispute, we saw great conflict as authoritarian management tried to impose change on its workers without appropriate consultation. Because of the Government's action, with the Tasmanian Government, we got the matter into the Industrial Relations Commission where, for the moment at least, it has been settled. What we have here is a conflict of style: on behalf of the National Australia Bank, cooperation; on behalf of APPM, conflict. APPM's style is that of the Opposition.

I conclude by drawing attention to an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald by the economics writer Ross Gittins, who talks about the spread of workplace reform in Australia. I want to read one excerpt from this article which—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just leave it. We will go and read it.
—I am sure that Senator Newman does not want to hear about it. I will quote Gittins:

ANSWER.PARA: They're the how-to-do-it story and they give the lie to the popular impression that we're still waiting for workplace reform.

He goes on to talk about how widespread workplace reform is and that we should not be distracted from believing that it is occurring by the APPM example. It is widespread and it is growing. I commend the example of the NAB agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to acknowledge the young man from the Church of England Grammar School with the Australian flag who is in the gallery. He is obviously a very proud Australian. My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Minister representing the Prime Minister. This is a very serious question. Whilst I have no objection to the Prime Minister investing in new industry provided there is no conflict of interest, I am concerned about any possible quarantine risk to our existing primary industries—a concern I expressed to the Minister yesterday. Therefore, is the Sydney Morning Herald correct in reporting that Danpork intends to introduce genetically engineered strains of pig from Denmark? Will this be done through the importation of semen or embryos or, alternatively, through the importation of live pigs which will be kept in quarantine and bred here? What proposals or applications has Danpork or Brown and Hatton made regarding the importation of breeding material and/or live pigs?

—Senator Boswell asked me a question with several parts the other day and this was one part of his question. I did not have an answer to it at the time and I undertook to try to get an answer. I am advised by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy that there have been discussions between the Danish company, Danpork, and the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. This has led to the quarantine service telling the company that appropriate protocols would have to be developed if such imports were to take place. I understand that the Danpork company has now advised the quarantine service that it intends utilising the breeding qualities of Australian pigs, realising that it may not be appropriate to use its own stock. It certainly could not use its own stock for a considerable time unless appropriate quarantine arrangements were made.

PARA.TAB: As I could have said the other day, any proposal for the importation of breeding stock, horticultural products and so on into Australia is dealt with by the Quarantine and Inspection Service. I think it is a very efficient service and it has done well by Australia. It applies the same rules to everybody, whether it be the horticultural industry, the meat industry or anything else. I think it has been a considerable success.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister advise when the discussions between Danpork and AQIS commenced? Is there now no plan to import breeding material or live pigs from Denmark?

—I understand that the answer to the last part of the question is no. There is no current proposal because of the discussions which have taken place. I cannot give the honourable senator the date of those discussions. I will obtain that information for him from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

—While we are being parochial, I would like to acknowledge the presence of the boys and the teachers from Churchie in the public gallery. My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Earlier in Question Time, Senator Alston referred to debate in the press today about the impact of the superannuation levy package on low income earners—the sudden natural constituency of the coalition. Firstly, does the Government support the view that a flat rate as opposed to a percentage rate increase in a national wage decision achieves the objective of benefiting low income earners? Secondly, is the Government considering supporting such a proposal, as I believe the alleged disadvantages of the SGL for low income earners can be overcome in other ways such as this?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I do not want to be parochial but I would like to acknowledge the presence in the gallery of all our visitors this afternoon. Unfortunately, I am sure they have not found the performance of the Opposition very engaging today. However, as to the question from Senator Kernot, of course it is a matter of fact that a flat rate wage increase benefits lower paid workers by virtue of the fact that they get the full amount of the increase. A percentage wage increase means that because their wages are lower they get a lower outcome.

PARA.TAB: I will give an example of what I mean. In accord mark VI we negotiated with the ACTU a $12 flat rate increase payable from the middle of last year. That went to the Industrial Relations Commission and in April of last year the Commission overruled the accord submission and instituted a 2.5 per cent wage increase. I have constantly said in this place that the Government's attitude to the Industrial Relations Commission is that we sometimes disagree with its decisions but we fight to the death for its right to make them. This was one of those decisions with which we disagreed.

We believed that, as a matter of public equity and social equity, it would have been far better to have awarded a flat rate increase to meet the needs of lower paid workers than to have gone to a percentage increase. I will give the figures. To someone earning $18,000 a year, a $12 increase represents a 3.5 per cent increase per week; but for someone earning $60,000 a year, a $12 increase represents an increase of only 1 per cent per week. So in terms of the Labor Government trying to get some equity for lower paid workers, the flat rate increase was a significant measure which we supported.

In her second question Senator Kernot asked whether we would consider supporting a flat rate increase in the next wage round. It is too early to say what the nature of a wage claim will be and whether or not we will actually have a flat rate component to it. It is certainly a matter for consideration because we are concerned about meeting the requirements of lower paid workers, but we will need to talk shortly with the ACTU about the nature of its wage claims. In those discussions we will consider what the right way is of meeting the needs of wage earners in this country.

I might add that this does highlight one important difference between the Government and the Opposition, that is, we do support national wage cases. We support them because they do make adjustments to wages across the board in this country and they are a vehicle for dealing with the equity dimension of wage fixation. That is in contradistinction to the Opposition, which wants to abandon national wage case increases and leave ordinary workers in the grips of the market, negotiating wage increases directly with their employers within the structure of common law and, outside that, of the Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. No doubt the Minister is aware that the number of people on public hospital waiting lists is still between 70,000 and 100,000 while occupancy rates in private hospitals are between 55 and 60 per cent. The hospitals are being closed and there is a gross shortage of GPs in rural areas. Hospital costs are increasing by 12 per cent per annum. The percentage of the population holding private health insurance has dropped dramatically and the cost of private insurance has risen by 130 per cent in the past 5 years. When will the Government take action to fix our deteriorating health system and what action will it take?

—I can give an assurance to the Senate that the Prime Minister, unlike the Leader of the Opposition, will not be going to the council meeting of the AMA and seeking the concurrence and direction of the doctors union in formulating the health policy for all Australians. In fact, we certainly will not be using taxpayers' funds to subsidise private health insurance, which is what the Opposition proposes to do, by offering various subsidies. We will not be cutting grants to the States which will, of course, have the effect that those States will be unable to provide funds to the public hospitals in their jurisdictions in order to assist those public hospitals to remain viable.

PARA.TAB: We will not be doing any of those things. We will be trying to strengthen the public hospital system in a way which provides for the necessary services to be available for those Australians who require them and we will be taking steps which will certainly not lead to a transfer of funds from those who apply for private insurance to the doctors and to the private hospitals. As far as I am concerned, we certainly will not be adopting the sorts of—

TALK.START.PARA: —No plan.

—Senator Herron's plan is to adopt the United States health system, which would be anathema to most Australians. Back in February, Senator Collins asked Senator Herron, `Have you seen the health system in the United States lately?' Senator Herron replied, `It is one of the best in the world for those who can afford it'. We on this side of the chamber do not believe in providing the best system in the world for those who can afford it. We believe in providing public support through the taxpayer and through the Medicare system so that all Australians can obtain the best possible health care.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Does strengthening of the public hospital system and providing assistance through the tax system involve the nationalisation of the health system, with a rise in the Medicare levy to 2.25 per cent and the abolition of private health insurance, as is speculated in the press today?
—The Federal Government has no intention to nationalise the health system.

—Did the Minister for Justice have the opportunity to see the recent Four Corners program dealing with the use of deadly force by police? Could the Minister advise the Senate what steps, if any, are being taken to regulate the use of lethal force by police forces within Australia?

—I did see that particular program. I think it was two Mondays ago. It was very sobering viewing indeed. I think we all know that police are placed in positions of particular peril, great hazard to their lives in various instances, where they have to confront those who are carrying out a crime or are threatening the lives of others. But at the same time I think it has to be acknowledged that there is widespread community concern about the use of deadly force by police forces. In that situation the Police Ministers Council has responded by putting down minimum guidelines to be implemented by all commissioners to regulate the use of such force.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I have been most concerned since the findings of the inquiry into the shooting of David Gundy in New South Wales, when the police made forcible entry and shot him. The National Committee on Violence also expressed its concern that there should at least be minimum guidelines nationwide regulating the use of lethal force by police; that is, in situations where they intend to kill, or certainly to inflict very serious bodily injury on a person who, as I say, is perhaps in the course of carrying out a crime or threatening the lives of others.

The commissioners and the police Ministers have agreed that there ought to be very strict guidelines making it clear that the use of such force is indeed a last resort, only to be used where there is immediate threat to life. What has to accompany such guidelines, of course, is much better training processes so that police in these various squads or in general are psychologically, as well as physically, prepared to undertake the sorts of split-second judgments that have to be made in many of these situations of quite considerable peril.

I believe that with these guidelines in place nationwide, and with enhanced training, the Australian community can have much more confidence that its police forces in these situations of peril will undertake their obligations to the community in a way which emphasises safety, and will try to ensure that, in all situations, those in an incident come out of that incident alive rather than being killed in the course of the confrontation between the police and some person in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.
—Make it sensible.

—Anything would be more sensible than Senator Cook, the Minister for unemployment, to whom one would call, `Come in spinner!' I refer to the Foreign Minister's advice to Senator Richardson on 3 April that it would be perfectly proper for Senator Richardson to telephone the President of the Marshall Islands to make representations on behalf of a mate.
—Give us a break.

—I realise Senator Bolkus might not like it, but that is tough. I refer to the Minister's failure to seek advice from his Department about the circumstances surrounding this highly unusual request as evidenced by the handwritten note on a departmental file copy of Senator Richardson's press release of 28 April which records that, `We had not previously been aware of the Richardson-Kabua phone call'. In light of the fact that we now know that the Department already had a large amount of information about Mr Symons and his scheme, including the involvement of Senator Sibraa and Senator Richardson, I ask the Minister: what is his explanation for this failure to seek advice?

—I have told you, Mr President, about 14 times before—and I will say it again—that it was an essentially private representation that Senator Richardson wanted to make on behalf of the husband of a relative of his in circumstances where there was obvious family distress about the particular situation in which the person found himself. The representation he sought to make was simply on the question of whether or not that person should be able to get access to his passport in order to come back to Australia and prepare his defence.

PARA.TAB: No substantive issues were addressed in the particular phone call. Senator Richardson made it perfectly clear to me that he did not want to address any substantive issue. He was asking me a straightforward question as to whether there was any particular foreign affairs reason why it would be inappropriate for him to make the call, which was requested by the lawyer of the man thus arrested. The only reason he wanted—

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is clear he wanted to seek the advice.

—I did not know there had been anything in departmental records to suggest that there had been any connections of any kind between Symons and anybody else. I am describing the situation with which I was confronted when a colleague of mine rang up to make what was, on the face of it, and what remains, a perfectly reasonable request in circumstances that were amply and fully described to me and in response to which I acted as I have explained on innumerable occasions.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of concerns that Australia may cease to play an active part in the negotiations to tighten the international nuclear liability regime as funding may be withdrawn? Are these concerns justified?

—I have seen concerns expressed to that effect by Greenpeace in a widely circulated letter, among other places. They are quite unfounded. Australia will continue to participate in meetings of the International Atomic Energy Agency Standing Committee on Nuclear Liability in Vienna as we have in the five meetings that have been held since the establishment of that Committee in 1990.

PARA.TAB: In the past, we have generally been represented by officers with specific legal expertise drawn variously from Canberra and/or Australian missions at Geneva and Vienna. Such specialised participation will be maintained for future meetings as often as possible but decisions on our delegations to particular meetings will, as always with multilateral meetings of this type, depend on the availability of appropriate staff, competing priorities and other circumstances at the time. There is absolutely nothing new in that respect.

Australia does place importance on the work of this Committee. In conjunction with a number of other countries, we have taken a firm position supporting the introduction of an improved regime covering international nuclear liability arrangements. We hope that that Committee's work will lead to a comprehensive nuclear liability regime embodying those arrangements. We will continue to pursue our objectives in the Committee including, importantly, to commit states hosting nuclear facilities to ensuring that adequate compensation is available to victims of damage arising from those facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. I ask the Minister: will he comment on recent media speculation that the $50m Indonesian-financed casino development on Christmas Island had shut down because the investors were offended by further inquiries into the backer's suitability to hold a casino licence? What are the implications of the stopped work on the building site for the Government's proposed expenditure of over $130m on a community infrastructure rebuilding program and the legislation currently before the Senate to drastically alter the Christmas and Cocos Islands legal regime from 1 July, particularly in light of the answers to questions by DASET tabled in the Senate yesterday?

—The Minister has provided me with the following information about the Christmas Island casino. Senator Tambling is quite incorrect in assuming that the current dispute over the Christmas Island resort and casino in any way jeopardises the Government's plans for Christmas Island. It is true that the developer of the Christmas Island resort is in dispute with the resort's former construction managers, Geraldton Building Co. Pty Ltd. It is also true that the developer has recently terminated the services of the subsequent construction managers, the principals of whom had been associated with the Geraldton Building Co.

PARA.TAB: These disputes are of a commercial nature and do not involve the Commonwealth Government. There will obviously be some delays, but the developer is adamant that the completion of the casino is not in jeopardy. As Senator Tambling is well aware, the casino building is substantially completed, with about $30m already having been spent on it. The developer of the casino has advised the Department that, despite the dispute, trading accounts are up to date and no money is owed to local businesses. It is not anticipated at this stage that the current situation will impact in any way on the agreement the Commonwealth has with the developer.

The Government will obviously take into account the developer's performance and the performance of other parties associated with the casino before a licence to operate the casino is issued. However, it is noted that the current disputes are essentially commercial disputes and, therefore, should not impact on the agreement with the Commonwealth.

The current situation with the casino has no implications for the Bill currently before the Senate on the introduction of new laws for Christmas Island, nor to other Government initiatives, such as the Christmas Island rebuilding program. As for the much needed public works on Christmas Island in the electorate of the Northern Territory, which Senator Tambling has consistently tried to white-ant and torpedo—which I cannot see assisting the interests of his constituents—those works will proceed in the manner that the Government has already outlined and are not affected by the casino or otherwise. I also reiterate that the developers have advised the Government that, as the work on the casino is already substantially complete, the current dispute may delay but will not prevent its opening.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. By way of preamble, I draw the Minister's attention to the evidence that I gave to the Joint Committee on Public Works, calling for an economic development plan for Christmas Island before this massive public expenditure and the need for a Grants Commission assessment. I take the Minister back to my original question where I referred to the review that is currently under way by the Australian Federal Police and the answer yesterday. I ask the Minister to comment on how the review that is now going on, as commissioned by the Government, will impact. The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has stated:

QUESTION.PARA: This review involves interviews with all of the companies involved, state police forces, state gaming commissions and authorities, the Australian Securities Commission, delegates from the Western Australian Royal Commission and other relevant state and government agencies who hold pertinent information. Officers from the Australian Federal Police will visit both Singapore and Djakarta to carry out personal inquiries. The Australian Federal Police have advised that during the course of their investigation, inquiries will be made to both the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Tambling, ask the supplementary question.
—In light of that review, will the Minister comment on how the review will impact and on the fact that the casino has now shut down for construction reasons?
—As was made clear yesterday, and made clear again today, the question of the review—
—He is not very bright.

—I am not very bright today either. The review that is being conducted by the police is the normal investigation that is carried out by police, as Senator Tambling knows, coming from the Northern Territory, in respect of issuing casino licences. It is in no way related to this dispute, which is essentially of a commercial nature.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that, as difficult as the current circumstances may be for the casino developers on Christmas Island, they would pale into utter insignificance when stood alongside the complete fiasco of the compulsory acquisition of the Northern Territory casinos by Senator Tambling's conservative colleagues who presume to run that place. The construction of developments at Yulara and Sheraton hotels in Alice Springs and Darwin on the latest count will saddle Northern Territory taxpayers with a contingent liability bill of in excess of $400m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday after Question Time Senator Watson whacked me over the head with the Standing Orders. In my capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer I was asked to provide answers to two questions in particular. I have those answers to questions Nos 1893 and 1922. The Treasury apologises for the delay, which is said to relate to administrative delays. I also indicate that this morning I signed off the answer to a third question from Senator Watson which will be incorporated in Hansard. I seek leave to have these two answers incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answers read as follows—
Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 April 1992:

With reference to the answer to Question on Notice No 1434 (Senate Hansard, 25 March 1992, p 1112) concerning the taxation of pensions paid to Australian residents originally from Italy, which are being taxed by both governments in contravention of Article 18(1) of the agreement, and the representations made by the Australian Government to the Italian Government to obtain refunds of the Italian tax withheld at source for these pensioners, what representations were made to obtain these pension refunds.
Senator Button—The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Article 25 of Australia's taxation treaty with Italy provides that taxpayers who believe they have not been taxed in accordance with the treaty may approach the Competent Authority of their country of residence with their grievance. If a claim of this nature appears to be justified, and the taxpayer is unable to arrive at an appropriate solution, the Competent Authority shall endeavour, with the Competent Authority of the other country, to resolve the problem.

Two such representations have been made to the Italian Government on behalf of Italian pension recipients, resident in Australia, seeking refunds for tax withheld on their pensions by the Italian authorities. The first was by way of a letter of 20 August 1991. A reminder letter was sent on 11 March 1992. This matter will be addressed in discussions between officials very shortly.
The Australian Government will seek to have an early resolution of this matter, in accord the taxation treaty, for the benefit of the Italian community in Australia.
Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice on 7 May 1992:

ANSWER.PARA: With reference to the Australian Taxation Office new audit focus on transfer pricing:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the United States aggressive in perusing its transfer pricing audits in other jurisdictions, including Australia.

(2) As Australia also has its own transfer pricing rules, is there a possibility of doubling up of both sets of rules and are measures contemplated to avoid double taxation being imposed on one set of income.
Senator Button—The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has over the last three years increased its focus on international transfer pricing issues. A significant number of the adjustments made by the ATO during this period involved transactions with the United States.

The ATO's relationship with the United States Internal Revenue Service in the area of transfer pricing audits is one based on cooperation to bring to tax the correct amount of profit in each country. They have also moved towards an advance agreement procedure for transfer pricing issues which provides benefits to both taxpayers and tax authorities with greater certainty, avoidance of double taxation risks and minimisation of compliance costs in event of an audit.

The income tax treaty between Australia and the United States incorporates an arm's length test to be applied by both tax administrations to transfer pricing activities, ie as if the parties were independent entities dealing wholly independently with one another. With this in mind, the ATO is currently analysing the recently proposed changes to the United States transfer pricing rules.

International tax arrangements generally recognise the possibility that double taxation may arise from the application of different transfer pricing methodologies. Consistent with practices adopted around the world, the foreign tax credit systems in Australia and the United States enable relief to be granted from double taxation. Furthermore, the Australia/United States income tax treaty provides an additional mechanism for mutual resolution where difficulties may be experienced in obtaining relief from double taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked a question by Senator Boswell concerning funding to Catholic schools. While I provided him with an answer, I would now like to add to the answer. Since the addition has been supplied to me by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, and is quite long, I wonder whether it would suit the needs of the Senate and Senator Boswell if I incorporate it.
—I have no objection to incorporation, but I ask the Minister to table it also.
—I will get another copy for tabling. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday I was asked a question by Senator Boswell about the funding of award restructuring for teachers in Catholic schools. I now wish to add further to the information provided at Question Time yesterday. The following answer has been provided by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Minister Beazley.

The Government is aware of the concerns of the Queensland Catholic Education Office. However, contrary to what Senator Boswell has alleged, the Federal Government has met its share of award restructuring for teachers.

The Award Restructuring Assistance Program (ARAP) commenced operation in 1991 to pay the Commonwealth share of costs arising from teacher award restructuring. Key elements of this in 1991 were the move to a national benchmark salary of $38 000 and the introduction of Advanced Skills Teachers (ASTs) to provide a career path for classroom teachers.

Since 1990 Catholic systems have benefited directly in line with real increases in teachers' salaries i.e. Catholic systems were paid $2 million in 1990, $19.7 million in 1991, with an estimated allocation of $27.3 million for 1992.

ARAP operated differently between States and school sectors in recognition of their different stages of moving towards the benchmark. Schools and systems are reimbursed according to actual wage movements rather than lagged average national movements.

this has been of particular benefit to systems such as the NSW Catholics which moved to the benchmark and introduced ASTs quickly and the Queensland Catholics where the benchmark adjustment was large.

The Catholic sector has argued that the Commonwealth's share under ARAP should be 50 per cent of actual costs as Commonwealth general recurrent grants account for 50 per cent of Catholic systems actual operating expenditure. The Commonwealth contribution for most Catholic systems is 41 per cent which equates to the category 10 percentage share of the community standard—the benchmark for Commonwealth funding for non-government schools. The Government has not given any commitment to meet the higher percentage.

By providing differential funding the Commonwealth has allowed non-government systems to progress their award restructuring agendas (in advance of government systems) and receive appropriate Commonwealth compensation.

The other items—workers compensation, holiday leave loading, superannuation and long service leave—mentioned by the Honourable Senator yesterday are on-costs. They are not included in the Schools Price Index which supplements general recurrent grants. The Catholic education authorities have already been informed that, consistent with government policy in respect of the supplementation of recurrent grants through the Schools Price Index, these on-costs have also not been included in ARAP funding.

Federal funding for non-government schools falls largely into two programs: capital grants and recurrent (per capita) grants. Capital funding is currently under review and allocations for future years will be determined in the Budget. Recurrent grants have been announced through to the Year 2000 to enable non-government schools to plan their future with confidence.
I would like to make a few comments about non-government schools funding in Fightback! which should be of concern to all parents of children in Catholic schools.

Fightback! promises funding increases worth $300 million per year to non-government schools phased in from 1 July 1994 and fully implemented in 1997. The present 12 categories of need will be collapsed to six with the largest funding increases (up to 65%) awarded to schools in the present Categories 1 and 2.
A key question is the capacity of a Hewson Government to deliver these promises.
As there is a $6 billion shortfall in Fightback!'s budget costings, the funding increases promised for non-government schools will never materialise.

If elected the Hewson Government will be struggling to pay for the package of measures associated with the introduction of the Goods and Services Tax (GST). As personal income tax cuts and family allowance increases are essential measures to alleviate the negative impact of the GST on family incomes, schools funding will take a low priority.
A Hewson Government would, at best, be able to deliver the promised increases for non-government schools on a greatly modified scale.

As the Liberals' proposed restructuring of funding categories will favour schools in Categories 1 and 2, Catholic systems (which are funded at Category 10, and Category 11 in WA) are likely to receive significantly less than they have been promised in a scaled-down version of the Liberals' funding arrangements.

The Opposition's package also threatens to re-open the State Aid debate by reducing funds to States and Territories while promising significant funding increases to non-government schools. Fightback!'s promised 5% cut in grants to States and Territories will inevitably be passed on to State School systems. The Hewson Government would simultaneously increase funding to non-government schools—a move which would be interpreted publicly as a major resource shift from the government to the non-government schools sector.

This blatant departure from needs-based funding may well invite questions about the legitimacy of Federal funding for private schools and re-open the State Aid debate. The question of State Aid was successfully laid to rest by the Labor Government in 1985 when it introduced the present funding scheme based on twelve categories of need. Revisiting this issue would be divisive and destructive to the instability of all non-government schools in years to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, through you I wish to raise a matter with Senator Button pursuant to an order of the Senate of 28 September 1988 in relation to unanswered questions. I asked a question in the chamber which Senator Button took on notice to obtain information from the Treasury. That was on 4 May 1992. It concerns the important matter of the rate at which interest is charged for calculating provisional tax at the present time, given that the Treasury is still charging it at 10 per cent when interest rates have dramatically dropped. This matter is of extreme importance to a lot of taxpayers, especially as their interest and income have dropped significantly with the drop in interest rates. I have written to Senator Button and I wonder whether he is able to tell us what Treasury is doing.
—I will advise Senator Reid as soon as I can, and certainly by tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lewis—I seek leave to move a motion in relation to an answer given by Senator Button.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

PARA.TAB: Senator Button—Mr President, I should indicate that leave will not be granted in these matters unless it is clearly indicated what the subject matter is. There has been a chronic abuse of this process.
Senator Lewis—I will continue to seek leave and will expand on the seeking of leave. Senator Button would have to acknowledge that in no way have I been involved in any chronic abuse.
Senator Button—I agree with that.
Senator Lewis—I thank the Minister. I have a few words to say about Senator Button's answer to Senator Baume in relation to the Prime Minister's conflict of interest. Do I have leave?

PARA.TAB: Senator Button—No, Mr President. If Senator Lewis has a substantive motion that he wants to move, he can do that at some stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the contingent notice of motion in Senator Hill's name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion to take note of an answer to a question without notice.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been in this Parliament for nearly 16 years now. Having been in this Parliament for many years and having observed what goes on, it is my view that no Prime Minister should involve himself in any large scale commercial transactions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about farming?

—I will come to farming, Senator McMullan. I remind the Senate that the President of the United States, on taking office, transfers his assets to what is called a blind trust. I do not know whether he does that as a matter of requirement or just as a matter of principle, but in my view it is an action that all Prime Ministers should take. In my view, it is quite wrong that a Prime Minister of Australia, at the time he is Prime Minister, should involve himself in large scale investments. I do not care whether they are international investments or national investments. I am not talking about selling a block of land that he might own; I am not talking about selling the house that he might have owned before he became Prime Minister; I am not even talking about restoring or improving a house that he owns.
—Or clocks.

—I do not even mind if he has investments in antique clocks and he keeps those investments. But to involve himself in large scale commercial transactions is not something that a Prime Minister of this country can and should do. He cannot take off his hat and have a go at investment. I am sorry that that should be the situation for Prime Ministers, but they simply cannot just take off their hats and appear to be ordinary citizens. When I made some interjection in relation to Senator Button's answer, Senator Ray said to me, `What about Fraser?'.
—And McMahon, and Anthony.

—I acknowledge that Mr Fraser apparently had a very substantial interest in a farm in my area in the western district of Victoria. I say to Senator Ray that I wish that Mr Fraser had transferred that farm to blind trustees during his term of office as Prime Minister. If I had been in this Parliament for 15 years and I had had the experience in 1975 that I have now, that is the advice that I would have given to Mr Fraser.

PARA.TAB: Let me say to those opposite that I openly say to Dr Hewson, `On election to the office of Prime Minister of Australia, whatever assets you have left in your name ought to be transferred to blind trustees so there is no question that you are in any way investing in commercial transactions during your term of office as Prime Minister'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't want to declare your interests to the Senate.

—Senator Ray has a lot to say about this matter. If Senator Ray kept the millions of dollars that he earned as a thuggish taxi driver in Melbourne, I am sure that he would not be investing those millions of dollars in some sort of small arms deal, because he is the Minister for Defence and it would be seen to be wrong for him to be so investing. So I hope that he does not have any investments in arms deals around the world or around Australia, and I bet he has not. The Prime Minister of this country should not have any investment in any substantial commercial transactions. I say to those opposite that it is quite wrong. Clearly, as Prime Minister of this country, any such investment would involve him in a conflict of interest.

PARA.TAB: My colleague Senator Baume has been talking about the Foreign Investment Review Board, and it may very well be that the Government has some answer in relation to the Foreign Investment Review Board. But the Government and the Prime Minister, while he is in office, have no answer in relation to the Prime Minister's conflict of interest in any large scale investment in anything. I believe that this is a matter which the Senate ought to discuss as a matter of urgency today, here and now.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —No case has been made by Senator Lewis to deal with this matter by way of suspension of Standing Orders.
—It is urgency.

—Senator Lewis started off on something else but finished on the question of urgency. There have been ample opportunities for the Liberal Party to display its bona fides on this. Senator Lewis may have higher standards than the rest of his colleagues, I do not know, but when conflict of interest provisions and the registration of potential conflict of interest provisions were introduced by a Labor Government in 1986 they were opposed by his parliamentary colleagues.
—This is not a question of the disclosure of anything. It is a question of conflict of interest and investment.

—I quite understand what Senator Lewis said. Senator Lewis may have higher standards than his colleagues. That is what I am saying and that is why I let him go with his little speech for five minutes—
—You couldn't stop me.

—Without interruption, I am saying—which is more than the courtesy I am extended when I speak in this chamber. It is terribly upsetting to me to be constantly interrupted by the brilliant, incisive interjections which I get from the Opposition.Senator Lewis seeks to suspend Standing Orders, firstly, on the basis of an answer to a question which I gave—the question dealt specifically with alleged failure by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to register a conflict of interest, an allegation which fell a little flat—and, secondly, on the basis of a number of questions relating to a company called Danpork and another company and their fee of application. On the basis of that issue, Senator Lewis seeks to suspend Standing Orders to raise a whole new set of issues which have not been comprehended even by his colleagues in the Liberal Party. Certainly, in relation to the question of registration of interests, they have been opposed by his Party.

PARA.TAB: I understand that he is taking it a step further in relation to Prime Ministers. I take it that he is taking it a step further in relation to Prime Ministers because he wants to hitch on the wagon of Senator Baume in seeking to make his point. I think it would be a very good idea for him to come back on the adjournment debate some night and tell all of us his new views about the matter. Starting as he did with President Bush, I think he should examine the actual situation in the United States before he puts that forward as a model for Australian Prime Ministers.

If Prime Ministers, why not Ministers? Looking at the history of this country, the honourable senator suggested that, if he had screwed his courage to the sticking place with this issue in the time of the Fraser Government, he would have told Mr Fraser that he should put his farm in the hands of trustees—the very thing which the honourable senator's colleagues objected to in the pecuniary interests committee inquiry a few years ago. They regarded that as rather a deceitful sort of course to follow in terms of the public.

If Senator Lewis has a suggestion, it could well be put in the adjournment debate to give people the opportunity to think about it. I want to assure him that it is a very new suggestion, and I wish him success in telling Dr Hewson what he ought to do. If this sort of issue has to be debated continually we will be telling him what he ought to do now under the guidelines which currently exist. But let me say that it is totally unrelated to the sorts of questions which the hatchet man here, Senator Baume, has been pursuing in the Senate on behalf of his Leader in the lower House. Senator Lewis's proposition is just not relevant in terms of the suspension of Standing Orders and I hope that the Senate will deal with the matter quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Button needs to be reminded of what is at issue. In support of the points that have been made by my colleague to suspend Standing Orders, I think it is important to point out the following: firstly, the investment concerned had been camouflaged. The points that Senator Button makes with regard to the registration question being opposed or not opposed by honourable senators on this side of the chamber is irrelevant. We have often said and have said again that it is meaningless, just as it has been shown to be on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that it is half a million dollars that is involved. Despite Mr Keating's assertion that half a million dollars is only a small amount of money, to most Australians it is a very large amount of money. The third thing is that it is a particular industry which is subject to decision making by the Government of the day. The Government is in the position to make a decision which will either advantage or disadvantage Mr Keating in a personal financial manner. That relates to the question of the so-called dumping of pig meat onto the market. One could say that, if indeed other piggeries were put out of business before the regulations were changed, Mr Keating would be very definitely advantaged and that there would be a virtual monopoly on the market for that meat.

Another point that was brought out today that needs to be made again is the fact that the advantage given to Mr Keating by way of getting a special waiver of payroll tax, which is being denied to other Australians because the Government simply wishes to discredit or oppose the Liberal Party Fightback package, is something that will be available to all people when the Fightback package is in fact introduced.

It is important to realise that here is the Prime Minister of the country being advantaged by a decision that gives him a tax advantage not only with regard to his personal income tax, as the Commissioner of Taxation chose to do on a previous occasion, but also this time in a commercial transaction. Further than that, we have the FIRB, which has been quite crucial in this matter. Of course, all the people in the FIRB worked for the Prime Minister when he was the Treasurer. Indeed, to say that this matter is full of improprieties is to put it mildly. Senator Baume has put the case perfectly well. He has put it in an important way. Senator Button has chosen to answer it—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order, Senator Bishop is not even pretending to bring her contribution within the scope of the Standing Orders which at this stage require her to argue why this matter should be dealt with as a matter of urgency and why Standing Orders should be suspended. Moreover, she is raising a series of quite specific imputations against the Prime Minister and others which ought to be the subject of substantive motion if they are to be raised in this place. I ask you to bring her to order.

—Mr President, on the point of order; it is very clear to me that the issues Senator Bishop is raising are very important. They are underlining the reason why this whole matter is a matter of urgency. I argue strongly that Senator Bishop has mounted a very strong case for precisely why the urgency motion should be moved.

—Mr President, on the point of order; we changed the Standing Orders as a result of this relevance problem, because we always had a debate. Instead of having a half hour debate, we decided to reduce it to five minutes and ignore relevance. I think you should not uphold Senator Evans's point of order; I think Senator Kemp for once got it right.
—Whilst I agree with the remarks made by Senator Ray, I think the honourable senator should refer every now and then to the reason why there should be a suspension of Standing Orders.

—In a five minute speech I began by saying that I thought it was important and urgent for the following reasons. I then simply outlined the reasons. There happen to be a lot of them. Collectively, they make out a very strong case as to why this matter is urgent, why Standing Orders ought to be suspended and why this matter ought to in fact be debated. The important issue, as I said, is that it is a lot of money and the Government is deliberating on policy which could advantage the Prime Minister financially.

—Senator Lewis, I think, asserted that he had tried to take the high road on this and tried to discuss it in principle, but he started to talk about thuggish millionaire taxi drivers. Any money I earned that way I earned honestly. I am not sure that every solicitor in this place could say the same thing.
—But you did acknowledge that you beat up one of your customers.

—I did not throw the first punch. I certainly finished the job when he started it. I finished the job on him and, as Senator Lewis would know, when you drive a cab in those circumstances quite often your life is on the line. Nevertheless, we will let that pass.

PARA.TAB: The real problem with Senator Lewis is that he is now retiring and he has gone on some road to Damascus conversion about where he should stand on this issue. I would have been much more impressed if a virulent young Senator Lewis, with ambitions unfulfilled—that is not his fault; it is no reflection on him—had made this strong speech in 1976 or 1977. There are two issues involved here: potential conflict of interest and conflict of interest. It is always a problem in these matters.

To highlight a potential conflict of interest one produces the declaration form so it is quite clear to everyone what interests a Minister or a Prime Minister may have. In my lifetime, looking at the past Government, Mr Doug Anthony held a variety of portfolios—primary industry, trade and all these others—whilst he owned a very large pig farm. Was there a conflict of interest or only a potential conflict of interest? In this case it was not even secret; it was well known that he owned a pig farm.

Probably the richest Prime Minister in the history of this country was Mr McMahon who had investments in shopping centres and a whole range of activities. Then we had Mr Malcolm Fraser. I do not know how—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you telling us it is all right because they did it?

—No, it is just the degree. Suddenly Senator Lewis wants to intervene and establish a rule when there is a Labor Prime Minister, but he would not do it when there was a conservative Prime Minister. That is what we call hypocrisy or double standards.

PARA.TAB: I am not so sure that anyone on this side is arguing that we would not look at rules for conflict of interest now and into the future. We do not have a closed mind on it. Today the Opposition suggested that we look at President Bush and the other administration people who have had a similar experience; they have had to put their private interests aside, including even superannuation. I am not suggesting that even Senator Lewis would delve into that particular area today. That can all be looked at.

But the fact is that Senator Lewis has suddenly raised an issue which he has not raised before in relation to all these other people. If the Opposition were to win government, even from the declarations of pecuniary interests in the House of Representatives, would it suggest that Mr Beale, Mr McGauran, Mr McLachlan and Dr Hewson, who all have quite extensive interests, will all put these aside or that they will act improperly?

In all of this, Senator Lewis, in a fairly high minded way, and Senator Baume, in a totally grubby way, have pointed to what they say is a potential conflict of interest. They have no evidence whatsoever that there is a conflict of interest. They will not walk outside this chamber and say the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has done the wrong thing by intervening to put the fix in or anything else. They will not do that outside this chamber because they know they will be sued because the Prime Minister has not done that. But they would much prefer to make a few rhetorical allegations, knock down a few straw men and hope that a few smears stick.

I could spend a heap of time today doing over the poor Victorian member whose company, it was announced yesterday, went bust. I could drag the details backwards and forwards about how much he owed the Tax Commissioner and how he set up an exactly identical company and had not paid off the debts of the previous one. One can do that in politics.

Today, Senator Lewis has sought to suspend Standing Orders. Senator Button was quite right, this is the new technique—not the suspension of Standing Orders but the noting of answers to questions—that people eventually get sick of. If that procedure was rationed and done on important issues, no-one would object, but it is done on the most trivial of issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fix up your Question Time performance.

—That is Senator Kemp's interpretation of it and his only. If the shadow Minister for industry and commerce wants to hold shares in Elders, in Adelaide Steamship, in South Australian Brewing, provided that is on the public record and unless there is a direct linkage of a conflict of interest, we will accept his integrity, and I expect the Opposition to do exactly the same. But, for political opportunism, we have the arch smearer of the Senate coming in and making all sorts of allegations; previously he has had to withdraw a lot of them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the right of Senator Lewis to note the answers given by Senator Button in Question Time about the conflict of interest of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that emerged more clearly not only today but yesterday as well. It is right for Senator Lewis to note the answers given, particularly when there was a strong interjection from Senator Ray that this conflict of interest did not matter; that it was something which ought not to be for the attention of senators.

PARA.TAB: Obviously this has spurred Senator Lewis to immediately take the advantage that exists in this Senate to seek leave to speak for some few minutes to make crystal clear his own view that the interjection made by Senator Ray suggesting that the Prime Minister's conflict of interest is trivial or not important ought to be rejected by the Senate and by this Government.

There are at least six areas where the conflict of interest of the Prime Minister has emerged with regard to this $500,000 investment in the pig industry that he has developed during the time he was Treasurer last year and during the time that he has been Prime Minister. The first area is in regard to the investment possibly being a loan of $500,000. If he has a loan of $500,000, it is clear that it is to his personal advantage that interest rates be low. To the extent that he may, in his public capacity, seek to see interest rates lowered, it is a matter not only of personal interest to him, but it is clear to the public that there is a potential conflict of interest in the Prime Minister's decisions about interest rates or foreign investment.

The second area is that an investment, such as this joint venture in the pig industry in New South Wales, would have been banned by the foreign investment rules up until February this year. We do not know what the variation is that Senator Button referred to in Question Time today. The variation could have taken it over the line with regard to the

SPEECH.PARA: existing investment review guidelines of this Government. The Prime Minister may have gained a personal advantage by using a public power he has to make such a decision or to influence such a decision.

PARA.TAB: A third area is that visitors from foreign countries come to visit the Prime Minister, such as a Minister from the Government of Denmark. We are told that, in that discussion, the Prime Minister can take his hat off as Prime Minister and speak as Paul Keating. Senator Button, who represents this Government as Leader of the Government in the Senate, says that the Prime Minister was not speaking to him as the Prime Minister, but as a private citizen of this country. He cannot maintain that distinction. The Prime Minister was speaking in his public capacity as Prime Minister to gain a personal advantage of the $500,000 investment that he has in the pig industry.

A fourth area is the pig industry. The Prime Minister is a competitor with others in the pig industry. Many of those competitors are going broke at the moment; they are suffering a depressed price for pig meat. The reason is that there is an alleged dumping of Canadian pig meat in this country, underselling the Australian price. Into that vacuum, into that area where a lot of pig producers in Australia are going broke, moves the Prime Minister of this country for a personal advantage through the use of his public position.

A fifth area is payroll tax. Senator Short asked a question today about the particular advantage the Prime Minister enjoys in being involved in an investment which is exempt from payroll tax. How do we know what influence the Prime Minister may have had to gain that exemption from the New South Wales Government? The sixth area is the registration of company details. There is a requirement for the Prime Minister to register. I put it to those opposite that the required details were not on the register of pecuniary interests of the Prime Minister as is required of Ministers of this Government. Who would have guessed, by reading the register of pecuniary interests of Ministers, that this Prime Minister had such an investment or had such a pecuniary interest? It was only because of a search of company records that this became clear. There is a conflict of interest and the Prime Minister must declare what his personal interest is.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have here is episode three in the dirty tricks saga. Dr Hewson likes to sit in the House of Representatives and pretend that he is above all this grubby stuff. He sends the second-raters in here to play dirty tricks and smear, including Senator Baume. The Opposition did not try to use him today to speak in the debate; it sent some of those who are able to be a little more sanctimonious and high-minded about it, but the attempt is exactly the same.

PARA.TAB: What we have had exposed by Senator Ray is the absolute hypocrisy of this approach where Ministers in Liberal governments, during the time that those opposite have been here, have kept all their proceedings to themselves. Nobody has disclosed anything; nobody has made any allegation that the investments these people had in animals—pigs, cows or sheep—were a conflict of interest. Because Mr Lloyd is a farmer, his potential as Minister for primary industries under those opposite is a potential conflict of interest.

Were it were not for the fact that this Government has introduced disclosure provisions, none of this would have been on the public record, as none of the Opposition's information is. Those opposite will not disclose it. There we have it. When Mr Keating made this investment he was a backbencher. When he became Prime Minister it was disclosed. Were it not for our policy, which the Prime Minister supports and which those opposite do not, this information would all be secret, as it was all the time that those opposite were in government and as they wish it could be again.

We have had the world's most ridiculous suggestion from Senator Teague—Guinness Book of Records ridiculous—that somebody who has a loan has a conflict of interest if interest rates go down. Every Australian who has a mortgage benefits when interest rates go down. Every Treasurer since Federation has been in one of these positions: he has had either a debt or a bank account. Every time interest rates change, a Treasurer's financial interests change. What a stupid idea!

Now we have a proposal which says, `Anybody who proposes a policy from which that person may in any way be the beneficiary has a profound conflict of interest'. No-one's interest will be more substantially benefited by the introduction of a goods and services tax than the person who undertakes conspicuous consumption of things such as luxury motor cars. There is no price which will fall more than that of Ferraris, Lamborghinis and Rolls Royces. All those people whose special interest is the purchase of luxury cars will be massive beneficiaries.

No-one will be a bigger beneficiary than Dr Hewson. I do not allege that Dr Hewson does that for that reason. It is exactly the same argument that those opposite seek to propose. Those opposite have sat mute for decades on the basis that it does not matter that anybody else owns pigs, cows or sheep; there is no conflict of interest. Even if that person is the Minister for primary industries, it does not matter. But as soon as a Labor Prime Minister has an investment which he made as a backbencher, it becomes a scandal.

After a century of people in conservative governments doing it, one of ours has now done it, and those opposite think it is terrible. All they are concerned about is that they are in opposition and they wish they were over here. We all know that. If those opposite were, there would be no disclosure. They would still be hiding information under a rock, like all previous conservative governments have done. It is just another exercise in dirty tricks, another attempt to smear and to get away from debating the policy.

If those opposite want to come in here and say something about policy, we will accommodate them. But as long as they come in here and conduct an exercise in smear, an exercise in vilification, we will not be accommodating them by proposing that there should be any suspension of Standing Orders to allow this sort of debate on any occasion. We will not be supporting the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders to facilitate those opposite coming in with their dirty tricks. If those opposite want to think up a new tactic, they are welcome to do so. None of us should take any joy from any Premier being in any kind of trouble. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Packard and Smiles.
—Let's stick to the politicians.
—They are politicians, you boofhead.
—Order! I have ignored a lot of unparliamentary remarks during this debate. I will ask for that remark to be withdrawn, but there are many people at fault.
—I withdraw.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion to take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Patterson.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to Senator Hill's contingent notice of motion (No.2), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion to take note of an answer to a question without notice.

I stand more in sorrow than in anger in relation to Senator Tate's response. I seek urgency because there is obviously abysmal ignorance about the stand taken by the Australian Hospitals Association, which represents the public hospitals of Australia, not the private hospitals. Six hundred and six public hospitals and 330 private hospitals joined together recently in an effort which they entitled `Operation hospital survival'. We get this abysmal answer from Senator Tate about what the Government is not going to do. That is all we heard from him.

The hospitals in this country are in crisis. For the first time in their history, the public hospitals have joined with the private hospital system to get home to the Government that there is a crisis situation. It is a matter of urgency. It is not something that can be fobbed off by saying, `This isn't occurring'. It is occurring; it is occurring today. We get the absurd response that the Government is going to do nothing. It is more of the same. We got a litany of what the Government is not going to do.

PARA.TAB: The hospital system is in crisis. I will take but a few minutes to explain why. Gross domestic product spent on health care in this country has been static for 13 years. No other country in the world has kept its percentage of money spent on health care as a proportion of GDP static for the last 13 years. Every country has increased the amount expended because there has been an ageing of the population in Western countries and there has been a boom in technology, yet this country, under Medicare, has kept the lid on it. It is called rationing. If honourable senators do not believe me, they can ask the people in the streets who are trying to access the system. They cannot get in. Because of that expenditure blow-out, only 41 per cent can afford private insurance.

The reality is that the public system has to exist with the private system. The extraordinary thing that has occurred is that the Medicare levy brought in $2.5 billion in the last 12 months and the private system put $3.4 billion into the health system, more than the Medicare levy. There is more money going into the health system from the private system than there is in the Medicare levy. We get the response from Senator Tate, `We are not going to do anything; we are going to make it harder for people to insure themselves'. An article in today's Bulletin, which stimulated Senator Patterson's response, is headed, `Here comes Medicare II'. Mr George Gear said:
We made the major change in 1984 but have done nothing since.

SPEECH.PARA: This is just what Senator Tate said today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is he?

—Mr George Gear, a Labor member from another place, the architect of the current revival, as he says. He is going to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) with a system to nationalise medicine. If we look at the new information in our parliamentary database today we will see that Sweden, the last of the socialist systems in health care, is dismantling its system because it cannot afford it. Here we have one of the prime promoters of nationalisation. Does it not know what happened in eastern Europe in relation to socialism? Now we have a system promoted by a Labor member in another place that will increase the Medicare levy by another one per cent so that it will bring in a bit more money.

PARA.TAB: The system is bankrupt. It is gone. It is time to replace it. That is what the Opposition will be doing with the Fightback package. We believe that there should be freedom of choice. That is the basis of the Fightback system—allow people to insure themselves if they want to, subsidise them so that they can. We will not have this extraordinary situation where the hospitals are calling their operation `hospital survival' and asking for more money to be put in and the Government is saying, `No, it will be more of the same. We are not going to do this; we are not going to do that'. This is a matter of urgency. I cannot speak more strongly on this. It is a matter of urgency; it is a matter of operation hospital survival.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had Senator Herron been given leave I would not have risen to speak to this motion to suspend Standing Orders. He has not been given leave to express concern about the urgency of this matter and has moved a motion to suspend Standing Orders. I rise to support him on that issue.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Tate answered my question he did not give the Senate or the Australian public—older people and mothers with small children waiting for surgery—any hope at all about what was going to happen about the waiting lists. He gave us no hope. He told us what the Government was not going to do.

Mr Gear has other plans about what the Government is going to do in the health insurance system. Senator Tate said, `We are not going to nationalise health', but that is not Mr Gear's plan. He has put his plan to Mr Howe and Mr Keating. Mr Gear wants to nationalise the health system. He wants to increase the Medicare levy to 2.25 per cent—which still will not cover the cost of health in Australia. That is what Mr Gear wants to do, but Senator Tate does not answer the question.

Why is it urgent? It is urgent because in April this year four health Ministers met with the Federal Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) and said that they would refuse to reaffirm their commitment to Medicare because of the Federal Government's failure to fund it adequately. That is what the Ministers who are getting the message from the grassroots, the public hospitals—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Minister—Lawrence?
—The Minister from Western Australia—a Labor health Minister.
—The Premier.

—The Premier was not going to support it. The Government needs more money to implement any changes, but Senator Tate did not tell us that. He did not tell us how it will find the money, but Mr Gear has some ideas. He will increase the Medicare levy.

PARA.TAB: What else has happened? The two groups which are not natural allies—the peak body representing the public hospitals and the peak body representing the private hospitals—have together put out a very well researched paper outlining the state of health care in Australia today. It is disastrous. When we in this chamber were growing up we had what was recognised as one of the best health systems in the world. It is not one of the best in the world after eight years of the Labor Government and Medicare. What do the General Manager of the HIC and the Chief Executive of Medibank say? They say that the decline in private health insurance is disastrous. They want it turned around.

Before Medicare was introduced, 76 per cent of people were privately insured and now only 42 per cent are privately insured. We have hospital queues of between 70,000 and 100,000 across Australia and an occupancy rate in our private hospitals of between 50 and 60 per cent. That is a ridiculous situation.

I refer to an article entitled, `Health cover agony for mum'. A Western Australia mum who was out of work and finally got a job but still had a pharmaceutical benefits card had a child with glue ear. She went through the public health system in 1990 and waited six months for the child's ear to be treated. After the child had been treated, one of the grommets that were placed in the child's ear fell out and the other was not very successful. She went back to the public health system and was booked into a clinic. She was told that her child's ears could not be examined because they were too infected. So she had to wait. She got another appointment, for which she had to wait a long time. Finally, she was told that she would have to wait six months to a year for surgery.

This was a child who at age four could not hear—at the very critical time when a child is developing language, and hearing is vitally important for language development. Just consider how that would have set that child back in his or her development. It is not just the discomfort of that child's glue ear but his or her development. But the mother was told to wait, so what did she do? As she did not have private health insurance, she went to the private system and paid to have that service because she wanted her child treated. What was the outcome? She got an appointment immediately; she booked for private surgery; and, on the same day as would have been her next public clinic appointment, she was able to get the child into surgery.(Time expired)
Question resolved in the negative.
