DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Corporations and Securities

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Beahan, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a statement relating to the work of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Statement by the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, Senator Michael Beahan.

I wish to advise the Senate that the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities pursuant to its duty to inquire into `. . . any national scheme law. . . ' has resolved to examine the regulation of small business in Australia.
The terms of reference adopted by the committee are:

This committee will inquire into the creation of a new corporate form tailored to meet the needs of small business. The committee will examine the unproclaimed Close Corporations Act 1989. That act had as its object the simplification of the corporate rules for small business by reducing financial and other reporting requirements and by abandoning the company law distinction between directors and share holders in favour of simple principles based on partnership laws. The committee will also examine suggested amendments to that act and other corporate structures having the same broad objectives.

The Close Corporations Act was included in the Corporations legislation which was passed by Parliament in 1989. The Act was never proclaimed because of constitutional difficulties. However the demand for some new corporate form tailored to the needs of small business remains.

Australia has approximately 800,000 companies registered with the Australian Securities Commission. Some 1,200 of those are publicly listed on the Stock Exchange. Perhaps another 30,000 could be classified as significant in terms of their assets or the complexity of their corporate structures. The remainder are overwhelmingly small businesses—the family farm, the local shop or garage or the family company with few assets outside the family home and having only a handful of members. It is important that the regulatory requirements for these companies are appropriate to their size and value.

In addition to the advantages that will flow to small business from a simpler regulatory system, it is to be hoped that the Australian Securities Commission will also benefit in that it will not have to apply a single, and often inappropriate, regulatory regime to all companies in Australia irrespective of their size.

The committee will also take the opportunity to examine the drafting of the Close Corporations Act. It is particularly important that a piece of legislation designed for the use of small business and with the object of reducing cost and complexity of regulation should, as far as is possible, be expressed in simple and accessible language to enable the user to understand it without the requirement for costly legal advice.

The committee's inquiry is fully supported by the Attorney-General. For the information of Senators I table a recent press statement from the Attorney on this subject. It is the committee's intention to report on this matter to the Parliament by the end of the budget session, 1992.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1992POOLED DEVELOPMENT FUNDS BILL 1992DEVELOPMENT ALLOWANCE AUTHORITY BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 1 June, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating cognately the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the Development Allowance Authority Bill 1992, the Pooled Development Funds Bill 1992 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992. It is indeed very difficult to discuss four lengthy and complicated Bills in only five to 10 minutes each because of the imposition of a Government-inspired guillotine. I believe tax Bills are so important that they should not be subject to the guillotine process.

PARA.TAB: The four Bills which are before us—particularly the first of them—give legislative effect to announcements contained in the One Nation statement delivered earlier this year by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Tax Bill No. 2 corrects a number of tax anomalies and technical deficiencies. At the outset, I have to say that, unfortunately, many of these new measures announced in the Prime Minister's economic statement have failed quite dismally to address Australia's fundamental economic problems.

Some of the measures before us today were designed to lead Australia out of recession, but time and time again the proposals are too narrow and too restrictive. It is as though the Government is putting extra lead in the saddlebags of the racehorse and not enabling it to perform to its maximum. I think that is tragic. Who are the real losers? They are the unemployed. At least there was a glimmer of hope that some of these proposals would get off the ground in terms of infrastructure development. But they have been muzzled and constrained in such a way that very few projects will be possible. Then again, there is the time constraint—they have to be ready by December 1992.

In my remarks today I am will refer particularly to the Development Allowance Authority Bill, the infrastructure proposals and the lack of use of limited partnerships in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). The Opposition, through a series of amendments, gave the Government the opportunity to pick these up at the committee stage and make something worthwhile out of this legislation. But the Government has turned its back. The losers are not members of the Opposition, but the people of Australia. These Bills could have provided employment opportunities. That was the hype; that was the basis on which they were sold in the One Nation statement. But when these Bills came before this place they were not as stated in One Nation. They were restrained; they were changed. And the losers are the people of Australia, especially the unemployed.

Various sectors of the business community have called for the need for increased competitiveness and greater incentives for business expansion by way of tax reform. The business sector has expressed disappointment that in the One Nation statement there has been no attack on government controlled labour costs, such as payroll taxes and the superannuation and training levies, no clear means of stimulating investment in the labour intensive industries, and no extension of the meaning of effective life to the original announcements in the depreciation regime. The One Nation tax reforms we have before us today have been aimed at encouraging private investment in long term projects but they have fallen far short of what was needed.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 is once again an omnibus Bill implementing a wide range of proposals, most of which have previously been announced. But some of those previous announcements do not correspond with the legislation before us today. One of the most significant changes is in the area of the depreciation regime to provide higher rates of depreciation for depreciable property with effective lives of five years or more, and I indeed welcome those initiatives. These higher rates will reduce the impact of the Government's inability to resolve satisfactorily its earlier problem of what is known as the effective life issue. Depreciation has been described by one tax writer, Don Napier, in the June issue of Charter magazine as a moveable feast and he is quite right. He further says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government's One Nation statement. . . constitutes the seventh major change in 10 years to the tax depreciation regime.

Just ponder for a while, Mr Acting Deputy President, the impact that will have on business decisions and business investment. This Bill introduces the new six ranges of depreciation rates which are to replace the only recently legislated seven broad-based depreciation rates. While these accelerated depreciation arrangements will be of benefit to business, there is little evidence to suggest that the Government's tinkering around with depreciation rates has done much to bolster business investment confidence. In fact, this Bill not only incorporates changes to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) of this year but also contains the Government's reversed recent decision to make depreciation allowances to businesses available only on a declining balance method for depreciation purposes.

PARA.TAB: In the One Nation statement it was announced that straight-line depreciation would be abolished as part of the depreciation reforms. How little the Government knew of depreciation rules and how they work and how they adversely impact, particularly on the leasing industry in banking. In the initial years of owning equipment, this gives a worse result than `diminishing value', which the Government was proposing should be the only method. However, the straight-line method gives a better result in later years and, further, many companies would have had difficulties with the computerised accounting systems in leasing transactions which were generally calculated on a straight-line method.

At first the Government and the ATO response was emphatic that there was no chance of a back-down on the abolition of the straight-line depreciation regime. However, fortunately, after a lot of pressure, this Bill now incorporates a most necessary back-down and we do have the opportunity of straight-line calculations of depreciation under this new regime.

Further, I suggest that this Government take a good look at our Asian neighbours as well as our other major trading partners who show that they are only too well aware of the way in which tax allowances and other forms of assistance can encourage the spending of capital and the development of new enterprises. We cannot be a community isolated from the rest of the world. The World Economic Forum's 1991 report on world competitiveness shows that only New Zealand and Hungary have less advantageous taxation regimes than Australia. In fact, we ranked twenty-first, whilst Singapore ranked first and Hong Kong second, with Japan and India sharing third place.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) also increases the exemption for gains on the disposal of goodwill of a business from 20 to 50 per cent where the net business interests to the taxpayer are worth less than $2m. Again I would have to say that this goodwill concession is an attempt by the Government to counter the coalition's incentives and initiatives in Fightback. We welcome this because it is the Fightback incentives that show that the Liberal and National parties are leading the tax debate in this country, and it is the Government that is blindly following on well back in the field.

However, one problem needs to be addressed on the proposed capital gains tax. The proposed amendment to section 160ZD was designed to ensure that where the disposal of an asset occurs due to the expiry of the asset itself—where it is obviously worthless—no capital gains tax is to be payable. Because the anomaly actually arose from earlier legislation which came into operation on 15 August, it was considered that the benefit should apply from that date rather than 2 April 1992. I thank the Government for an amendment that has just been placed on our desks that will effectively mean that the operative date for those expired options and expired leases will now, fairly, be 15 August 1989, the original date when the Government should have got it right.

I note that the revenue effect is expected to be minimal. I must indicate that in recent times Government responses to these sorts of problems have been readily forthcoming. I particularly thank the Parliamentary Secretary for his part in attending to these on a timely basis. The effect of that amendment is that it will overcome a serious injustice committed against those taxpayers who had a lease or option which had expired during the period from 15 August 1989.

The Bill also contains 15 miscellaneous amendments to the capital gains tax. One worthy of comment ensures that capital gains tax is payable where non-taxable Australian assets owned by a deceased Australian resident are inherited by a non-resident beneficiary. A number of people might say, `Fair enough'. But I remind those listening, both on the radio and in the Senate, that this provision has certain dangerous death duties overtones which I do not think people really should ignore.

An amendment to the research and development 150 per cent taxation concession is the result of an anomaly in the clawback provisions which could not easily be accommodated or removed by a single Tax Office ruling. In fact, I believe that many of the taxation rulings should really be incorporated into legislative changes rather than left on the books as Taxation Office rulings. I applaud this move, and I request the Minister to ensure that more of the rulings are in legislative form to give them the correct force of law that is necessary to support them. This measure was announced on 17 January 1992. It will prevent the application of research and development clawback provisions to certain eligible companies where a grant or recoupment is made by the Commonwealth under the cooperative research centres program. Naturally, the coalition has no problems with this particular proposal.

Again I am pleased that the Government has heeded the call to enable substantially self-employed people with minimum outside superannuation support not to be deprived of deductions to their personal self-employed funds. This is a matter that we have been giving a lot of attention to in recent years because it is an injustice which affected the self-employed community. People such as doctors who got minimum support as a result of one or two visits to a hospital a month, and as a result of being paid a fee there, could be deprived of tax deductibility on their own personal superannuation funds. This amendment overcomes that degree of injustice.

Other amendments to the Bill include changes to the Medicare levy to limit concessions to those holding health cards, the blind, pensioners and recipients of sickness allowances; seven previously announced changes to anomalies to the foreign source income; contributions on behalf of employers extended to three eligible types of superannuation funds; and the deferral of the initial payment of company tax instalments for those which have a tax liability of $1,000 or more but less than $400,000, balance after 31 December 1991 and pay their tax in two instalments. This last proposal with regard to company tax is indeed welcome, but I must point out that a great deal of uncertainty and confusion within the business community could have been avoided if the proposals had been legislated before 31 December 1991 and not six months later.

One other taxation change which is causing the coalition some concern is a measure to exempt from income tax the pay and allowances of Australian Defence Force members serving with the United Nations Advance Mission in Cambodia and the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia. While the exemption is to be backdated to 9 June, provision exists, and apparently it is the Government's intention, to terminate this concession once the UN declares a cease-fire in Cambodia. Such action, if taken, is inconsistent with the exemption granted to Australian personnel involved in the Namibian peacekeeping force who were also operating in dangerous, unmapped minefields and were constantly subject to the threat of injury and disease long after the cease-fire declaration.

Further, it is my understanding that phase two of the UN peace plan was to start last Wednesday if all groups were in agreement. However, this is not so. One group, the Khmer Rouge, is still not willing to demobilise its troops. As well, one has to consider the literally millions of mines that have been placed or buried throughout Cambodia. Our Defence Force personnel are therefore in constant danger, but they are equipped to handle this. The full-year cost of extending the exemption is estimated at approximately $2.5m; yet this is only additional to the Government's costing in the event that the Australian personnel remain in Cambodia after the declaration of a UN cease-fire.

For a government to put the lives of our willing young men and women at risk and then refuse a tax exemption of pay and allowances for these courageous service people, given the precedent set in Namibia, leaves us speechless. I am pleased that, on the initiative of my colleague Senator Jocelyn Newman, an amendment will be moved during the committee stage proposing to overcome this unsatisfactory situation. The amendment, on behalf the coalition, will seek to extend the tax exemption for ADF personnel participating in the UN peacekeeping force in Cambodia until that country is made safe, not just until the UN announces its cease-fire. I think it is appropriate that Senator Jocelyn Newman do that because she has a long record of concern about the welfare of ADF personnel and she has special responsibilities in this chamber for defence issues.

A final comment for the Government on this Bill is that, when introducing legislation to correct anomalies, it is imperative that the amendments themselves do not contain anomalies and consequently perpetuate the problems which they seek to resolve.

I now turn my attention to the Pooled Development Funds Bill 1992 and the Development Allowance Authority Bill 1992. The Government's proposals for pooled development funds differ substantially from what was outlined in the One Nation statement. While Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) deals with some significant features, a separate Bill, the Pooled Development Funds Bill 1992, outlines the conditions for qualification of a pooled development fund. Some of the differences actually favour the shareholders. For example, the maximum investment by a pooled development fund in a single entity will now be increased to 20 per cent whereas in One Nation it was to be 10 per cent. That is one of the few areas where it favours the taxpayers.

The PDFs will ostensibly provide a mechanism for channelling equity capital to eligible small and medium sized Australian companies, defined as companies with total assets of not more than $30m. The Opposition is amazed that this Government is now reintroducing a concept which is very similar to the failed management investment company scheme which expired last year and which was subject to so much criticism, although I must admit it is less prescriptive than the former scheme. It was reviewed by the BIE in 1987, which concluded that the MICs should finish in 1988, given that the program was seen as a catalyst and not a permanent force of assistance. So neither the Government nor the MIC licensing board saw the program as continuing indefinitely.

Apparently, the Government now sees room for a new version of a tried and not very successful scheme. The coalition does not believe the pooled development fund scheme is likely to work either and, therefore, will not be supporting the legislation.

Presumably, funds which may have been or would be channelled directly to some firms or through other investment arrangements will now be channelled via the PDF in order to benefit from the lower tax treatment. The coalition's assessment of a 30 per cent tax rate applying to PDF and imputation credits attaching to receipts of franked dividends is that net investment is unlikely to change, even with the above tax concessions. The tax concession exists through one intermediary, the pooled development fund, only at the expense of investment through other financial arrangements. I think that is a tragedy. In short, it will just encourage investors to channel their investments through a PDF rather than encouraging increased investment in small and medium sized businesses.

The coalition feels that the pooled development fund scheme may tend to institutionalise investment decisions even further. In fact, Labor's pooled development fund would provide only a paltry $5m in 1994-95 and 1995-96 when major tax reforms are required for the business sector. It is another example of tinkering very much at the edges.

Moreover, concern should be expressed at the compliance costs associated with pooled development funds. They are exorbitantly high. Hand in hand with the announcement of the measures for the pooled development funds in the One Nation statement come measures which have resulted in the Development Allowance Authority Bill before us today. Again, this Bill is nothing more than a bandaid solution which will provide $40m in 1994-95 and $70m in 1995-96 when major tax reforms are needed for the business sector.

This Bill establishes the eligibility of large projects—that is, projects with a capital cost of $50m or more—for the development allowances. The type of eligibility project specifically identified in the legislation includes factories, mines, quarries, wharves and other port facilities, hotels, pipelines and transport. The development allowance is a deduction against income equal to 10 per cent of eligible plant expenditure in its first year of use. To qualify, an application must have been lodged with the DAA by the end of 1992. Why such a tight timeframe? This is not adequate, especially when one realises that the requirement to meet world best practice, which is known as the competitiveness test in the legislation, is actually waived for the first round of applicants who apply before the end of 1992.

Nonetheless, the question remains: what is the sense behind setting up a scheme of special assistance when the recipients are firms that are already identified as having little or no existing assistance but have in place world best management and industrial relations arrangements? Obviously, if firms have world best practice arrangements in place, they would not require any additional assistance from taxpayers to compete in the international marketplace. The unwieldy administrative arrangements and the denial of legitimate interest deductions in the form of inhibitions in prohibiting roll-over of interest financing is adding considerably to the capital cost structure of these businesses. This is another example of putting lead in the saddlebags.

At the time the development allowance was announced, no details were given as to what administrative arrangements would be put in place to deliver the allowance. It should be noted that at the time no mention was made of setting up an independent statutory authority at a cost of $1.2m. Further, the One Nation document records that certain broad criteria would need to be observed in identifying projects. There are three criteria. Unfortunately, because of time constraints I will not be able to address that issue.

Further, it should be noted that the Government's proposed Development Allowance Authority would discriminate against small projects, that is, projects with a capital cost of less than $50m. This $50m threshold is arbitrary and distorting and will encourage vertical integration which may or may not be the most efficient production structure. The fact that applicants must be registered by the end of this year will provide the Government, presumably before the next election, with some projects—at least on paper—which will enable it to claim that it is getting some investment back on track. But it is not going far enough; it is very much a bandaid treatment.

This raises the question of the genuineness of the Government in wanting to put in place significant development proposals. I suggest that the Government is assuming that two or three projects will get off the ground prior to the 31 December deadline. Why should projects such as stage 2 of the Loy Yang B project—a project that would yield lower electricity prices to Victorian consumers—not be eligible? The reason is that they must be substantially new, rather than the second phase of an already existing project. The whole concept of the Authority is flawed and there is no logic in setting up the Authority to hand out taxpayers' money over such a short timeframe. We supposedly have in place the world's best arrangements.

I now turn to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992. Undoubtedly, the time restrictions put on this debate will completely eliminate a proper evaluation by me as the leader for the coalition in this debate of most of the issues raised in this Bill. This is absolutely appalling. A number of amendments contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) were announced in the One Nation statement. These will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act by confirming that taxpayers are entitled to deductions in respect of losses incurred in writing off a bad portion of a debt; allowing interest or other borrowing expenses on funds borrowed to invest in infrastructure borrowings to be described as deductible, even though the interest received is exempt; and increasing the rate of deductions for buildings used for traveller accommodation and industrial accommodation from 2.5 per cent to 4 per cent from 26 March 1992. This is a welcome move. The amendments allow the capital cost of income producing structural improvements to be evenly deductible over 40 years at the rate of 2.5 per cent and allow depreciation to the holders of crown leases who were denied depreciation deductions for property they installed on leased land—another welcome move.

Two other measures not previously announced include expanding the definition of `primary production' so as to include horticulture, including the propagation or cultivation of plants and their products; and confirming that prospecting, exploration or drilling for minerals, petroleum and natural gas is not categorised as research and development for the purpose of the special R&D deduction of up to 150 per cent.

Because of the shortness of time, I commend readers and listeners to the deliberations of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration when these issues were extensively canvassed. I thank Mr Hood from the Taxation Office for his lucid explanation of these issues. I do have certain problems in regard to retrospectivity which I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to address when summing up the amendment during the committee stage. After some lengthy discussion on the point, the amendment will clearly change the law and not merely confirm or clarify it. It was agreed that this matter will be further investigated and I hope that the Parliamentary Secretary or the Minister, with assistance from the Taxation Office, can clarify this point on retrospectivity. I also wish to express my disappointment that the horticultural extension definition includes hydroponics only from 25 May 1992. We welcome this addition, but this industry has been operating now for quite some time.

However, of all the matters before us in this debate, the coalition is most concerned about the tax exempt infrastructure borrowings, or the facility for non-assessable/non-deductible bonds. The issue has been widely canvassed again in the Senate Standing Committee report, and I commend readers to that. However, we are very surprised, given the strong support from the witnesses, that the Government has not seen fit to acknowledge the worth and the value of those seven or eight amendments put by the Opposition. Because of time constraints, we obviously cannot put them again, but the proposals and the concept of limited partnerships must raise their heads in the future.

Unfortunately, the proposals in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) are far too restrictive in their application than the initiative announced in the One Nation statement. The Bill will restrict the utilisation of bonds to funding by corporate entities, and this restriction is in conflict with initiatives taken by State governments to establish the option of equity investment in projects to be structured as limited partnerships. We have already seen movements by the New South Wales and Victorian governments to this effect. The question is: why is this Federal Government lagging behind, stopping such developments from getting off the ground and easing our unemployment problem?

Honourable senators will realise that there are serious shortcomings in this Bill because of the narrow class of permitted borrowers. The Government, for some reason, has lost a golden opportunity to foster projects to raise Australia out of the hopeless unemployment situation that thousands of Australians have had inflicted upon them.

The proper utilisation of limited partnerships would support private participation in infrastructure projects, especially when it is considered that infrastructure projects require investors to take a very long term view in appraising the return on their investment and to address a range of risks and issues. Why should they have to have roundabout mechanisms of raising $2 companies? Why should they have to address their losses through that sort of artificial mechanism rather than through the efficient partnership arrangement which is acknowledged worldwide? It is hard to believe the Government's blinkered vision in this particular area.

I refer to provisions where moneys raised by infrastructure borrowings can be spent only on construction of a related facility on or after the date on which the first draw down of the borrowings was made. In other words, this will prohibit the effective roll-over relief. How does this work? In the initial stages of construction, one borrows short term; it is high risk. Once the operation facility gets going, one then borrows long term and low cost because there is lower risk. Under this legislation we are unable to make the first case roll over into the second. So we are denying these companies the opportunity of minimising in a legitimate and commercial way—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing a multitude of tax Bills, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), the Pooled Development Funds Bill and the Development Allowance Authority Bill. To my knowledge they were guillotined through the House of Representatives, and now they are being guillotined through here. We were blamed for holding up legislation last evening. We are not holding it up at all because the House of Representatives got the same treatment. The most important Bills of the session always come up at the last moment when we do not have the time that we should have to go through them in fine detail, as Senator Watson so ably pointed out.

PARA.TAB: I was third on the speakers list this afternoon, and Senator Kernot from the Australian Democrats was supposed be ahead of me. This shows the scant regard that the Democrats have for taxation Bills: they just let the Government do what it likes with them. I presume Senator Kernot is out doing another dirty deal with the Government. She did a dirty deal with it yesterday to lose 80,000 jobs, and she is probably out doing a deal to lose another 20,000 jobs to make it an even 100,000 for the week. It is disgraceful that they have not taken their place in the debate even though Senator Kernot put her name on the list.

I will address Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) more than any other Bill. It involves amendments to taxation laws to provide for higher depreciation rates for plant purchased after 26 February 1992. This is for plant which has an effective life of more than five years. The items of plant which have an effective life of less than five years have been dealt with in legislation following the March 1991 statement by the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. It was dealt with as late as February of this year. So it is very hard to keep up with the continual amendments to the depreciation schedule. I think Senator Watson did say that there have been seven changes in three years or something like that.

This is the present situation with the depreciation schedule: for plant which has an effective life of three to five years and a prime cost of 40 per cent, the diminishing value is 60 per cent; for plant with an effective life of five to 6 2/3years and a prime cost of 24 per cent, a diminishing value of 36 per cent; for plant with an effective life of 10 to less than 13.3 years the figures are 12 per cent and 18 per cent respectively; for plant which has an effective life of 13 1/2 to 20 years, the figures are 9 per cent and 13.5 per cent respectively; for plant which has an effective life of 20 to less than 40 years, the figures are 6 per cent and 9 per cent respectively; and for plant with an effective life of 40 years or more, the figures are 3 per cent and 4.5 per cent respectively.

I will do the comparisons a bit later to show how much this is tinkering at the edges. There is no real gain in it. These rates are far too low. There is certainly no incentive in these new schedules to invest in new plant. Plant purchases go on all the time; they are programmed to go on all the time. If the incentives had been greater, some operators whose plants may not have needed changing over for a few years might have made the decision to do so earlier. But the changes are not great enough for that.

Why have these incentives been put back into the legislation? Under the Fraser Government there were many incentives to turn over plant fairly regularly. This did two things: a lot more machines were supplied to the business sector and productivity increased. We had those incentives under Malcolm Fraser's Government. But when this Government came along—led mainly by Senator Walsh, the former Minister for Finance—it continually eroded those incentives. The investment allowance certainly went and the depreciation schedule was changed to write off machinery over a longer period.

This Government has realised the folly of its ways, but it has taken 10 years to do it. It has started clawing back the depreciation schedule little by little. But, unfortunately, the bit that it is clawing back is having very little effect. The depreciation schedule is in a state of flux. We have had a number of changes even since I have been a senator. This is just piecemeal.

Under the new proposals in this legislation, as I have said, anything with an effective life of under three years will not be affected. It will be wholly written off. Anything under $300 will be a one-off write off. Under the new proposals, items of plant of three years to less than five years stay at 40 per cent prime cost, with a diminishing value of 60 per cent. This is where the changes come in. Items of plant of five years to less than 6 2/3 years go to 27 per cent prime cost whereas it was 24 per cent before. The diminishing value is 40 per cent whereas before it was 36 per cent—hardly any change. Items of plant of 6 2/3 years to less than 10 years go to 20 per cent prime cost under the new schedule whereas it was 18 per cent before, with a diminishing value of 30 per cent whereas it was 27 per cent before. I will not repeat all of those figures because they are in the explanatory memoranda. This Government is just tinkering at the edges and not making any real changes.

This is only further tinkering, because of what happened in the March 1991 statement. That legislation did not come before the Parliament until February of this year and made changes that were supposed to be effective from July 1991, not when the statement came down. There was pressure on the Government—I think Senator Watson alluded to this—just before last Christmas to put all those new schedules back to March 1991. The problem was that when the March 1991 statement came down anyone thinking of purchasing a fairly big plant could see a better depreciation schedule around the corner, in four months, and backed off or delayed purchasing new equipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pending its being made retrospective, the second one.

—Right. They put it off until July. The pressure having been put on the Government later to put the schedules back to March, those who waited until 1 July were punished for waiting because those who went ahead and did their deal, who took the chance or who needed the plant, got their productivity and their depreciation started from March rather than from 1 July.

PARA.TAB: The ones that hung off lost that productivity, lost employment opportunities and lost the opportunity to increase profits. The Government has been tinkering and tinkering. We have had three changes in the schedule, virtually, in 12 months: one in March 1991 that was supposed to have lasted until July 1991; then the one that existed up to the One Nation package, if anyone can remember the One Nation package; and then the One Nation package which changed it again. So there is utter and total confusion. How can anyone—earthmoving firms, farmers—who buys plant, which depreciates for business purposes, do any forward planning? As I have said, farmers, plant operators and everyone like that get caught.

The coalition is supporting the main thrust of this piecemeal Bill, but I presume that one day this Government—in the life it has left, which is not very much—will do something more positive. Having regard to the way this package of Bills is being pressured through the Senate, as it was pressured through the House of Representatives, I think we will be here in the next sitting with three or four amendments, which will keep us busy, as a result of our not having had the time to fully review it.

The coalition, of course, is much more definite about what it will do in government with the Hewson Fightback package. There will be a full review of depreciation schedules and, hopefully, we will get back to something proper and clear and investment—

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole of business taxation.

—The whole taxation regime will be clear to everyone. People in business will be able to make business decisions, will know where they are going and will have the confidence to make decisions without the Government changing the rules halfway around. We will do that in government with the Fightback package to promote growth and international competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) also defers the initial payment of company tax for 1991-92, that is, for companies which have a tax liability of under $400,000. Companies which pay in two instalments will be able to defer for nine weeks. Once again, this is tinkering at the edges. Company tax payments had to be made at the normal time, although there was a time when payments were able to be made in four equal instalments, but this Government came along and saw that the only way it could keep up with its ever expanding deficits was to get money in more quickly. The Government was not getting any more money in, but it continually had to get money in and spend it before it earned it. Under a Bill we put forward a couple of years ago tax payments had to be made within 28 days after the end of the financial year or from the end of the reporting year. Companies with a financial year ending 30 June had to pay by 28 July. That is extended now to 28 September—nine weeks. That is simply tinkering at the edges. The bulk of the tax was paid by most companies six months later. It is a totally ridiculous situation. There is no great concession. It is simply a stay of execution—a term I used last night. If one is to be executed and there is no way out, I suppose the sooner the better—get it over and done with.

Also under this Bill, the capital gains exemption on goodwill for small business will go from 20 per cent to 50 per cent. The threshold for the net worth of a business under this category will apply to companies worth under $2m. At present, the 20 per cent is available, to my knowledge, for companies worth $1m. I suppose this measure is in this Bill to try to pick up a few votes to appease small businesses that have either been put into bankruptcy or will have to put personnel off in the next few months when the new legislation and the superannuation levy come in. When will these measures come in? In 1993-94. I ask Senator Tate: if these measures are so important and are needed for small business, why are they not introduced now? Taxes are increased on the day they are announced. If these measures are to loosen up businesses that are in a corner, why do they not apply now?

I would like to make a couple of small points. I believe that the measures contained in these Bills are small changes. I do not pretend that I have been able to read the whole lot in this short time. I do not think that even an expert like Senator Watson has been able to go through the whole lot and get the indications. That is why I think the legislation will be back here in a couple of months for more amendments. Whatever these measures are, they are far short of what we have in the Fightback package. Indeed, when we are in government, the Fightback package will be the answer.

I urge anyone who may be listening to this debate—I do not know how many people listen to parliament these days—especially small business, accountants and accounting firms, to examine what is coming out of this package. We on this side of the chamber have not had the opportunity to go through these measures as much as we would like to. Unlike the Government, we do not have the facilities and the resources to examine these measures. I believe that anomalies will come out of the woodwork left, right and centre because of the short time we have had to examine them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The four Bills that we are debating cognately, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992, the Pooled Development Funds Bill 1992 and the Development Allowance Authority Bill 1992, are part of the 62 Bills that the Government has chosen to guillotine through this Senate in the closing days of the autumn sitting.

PARA.TAB: On other occasions we have spoken about the absolute bad management that involves for the Government. We have yet another example with these Bills of bad planning on the part of the Government in its legislative program. It must surely reflect on the Government's programming of work through the parliamentary draftsmen and through the whole departmental, parliamentary and governmental processes of the Executive decision making. Quite frankly, it is unacceptable at this stage with five or six sitting days left of the autumn sitting to contemplate giving serious consideration to no fewer than 62 Bills, of which this package of four is an intimate and integral part.

The Bills that we are dealing with, not just this package but the others that are subject to the guillotine, are of enormous significance to the well-being of most Australians. Taxation legislation affects all Australians in some shape or form. These four Bills certainly do that, both directly and indirectly. On top of that, we have the package of very important so-called sales tax simplification Bills that we have to deal with next week.

TALK.START.PARA: —All under the guillotine.

—All under the guillotine again, as my friend Senator Watson says. The simplification involves, when one takes the explanatory memorandum and the Bills into account, simplifying it down to 1,200 pages of documentation to tell us how we are going to simplify the already horrendously complex sales tax legislation. Simplification is just a word that is absolutely the antithesis of what that package does. We will debate that again, no doubt, and the stupidity of trying to deal sensibly with such complex legislation in such a short period when we get to that package of Bills.

PARA.TAB: I just mention the tax aspects of those 62 Bills. There are other very significant pieces of legislation involving the whole gamut of Government business and the whole gamut of community involvement and community concern in many of the other Bills as well.

These Bills were also pushed through the House of Representatives—I think most of them were guillotined—so the Parliament has had no adequate opportunity to consider their content seriously and in depth. It is a futile call to the Government, I know, because we have been calling for years without any success at all for the Government to get its act in place in terms of the proper administration and decision making processes of government. Fortunately, I suppose we can say that we are in the last stages of having to put up with this nonsense because we are witnessing the death throes of a government which has only a very short period to run; most Australian electors will say the shorter the better.

I will deal briefly with each of the Bills in front of us. I will preface that by adding slightly to the remarks that I have made by saying that this recession that we have in Australia today is a very deep recession. It is the most serious, most protracted recession that we have had since the years of the Great Depression in the 1930s. There are various causes of the recession which have caused two million Australians to be either unemployed or underemployed, but one of the fundamental reasons for the recession is the impact of grossly incompetent economic and financial policies on the part of this Government impacting on the confidence of investors and on the ability of both individual and corporate Australians to save.

The surest way of undermining confidence amongst investors and savers is to continually change the relevant laws, in this case particularly the taxation laws, and also to ram laws and changes through at such a rate of knots that no-one has any confidence at all that what is passed today by this Parliament will not be before it again in a few short weeks or months for necessary amendments. I think Senator Panizza and Senator Watson referred to that matter.

It is a tremendously important factor in the whole confidence of this nation. If one were to go to my State of Victoria or to most other States of Australia, one would find an air of great uncertainty, great concern, great despair and a great lack of confidence. The way in which the Government is planning—`planning' is a total misnomer—is handling its affairs, is adding in very large measure indeed to that overall lack of confidence, and that is reflected in the whole approach to these Bills.

Together the Bills are important. Some are more important than others. As Senator Watson has advised the Senate, the coalition is opposing two of the Bills and is not opposing the other two. We are opposing the Development Allowance Authority Bill and the Pooled Development Funds Bill. We are not opposing Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) or Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), although we will be proposing one or two amendments.

I will very quickly outline again why we are opposed to the Development Allowance Authority Bill and the Pooled Development Funds Bill. The Development Allowance Authority Bill establishes a one-member statutory authority—the Development Allowance Authority, the DAA—which will have the task of assessing the eligibility of large projects with a capital cost of $50m or more. The basic objection that we have to this is that no earthly reason has been presented as to why we have to set up yet another quango to handle a matter such as this. The cost of establishing this Authority is not small by any means. It is a one-man Authority, so it says. As I understand it, the cost to set up the Authority is $1.2m. The administration costs in relation to what the Authority is supposed to be doing are very high indeed.

Let me make it clear: we are not opposing the concept of the development allowance as such; we are opposing the establishment of another authority to administer, if you like, the development allowance that is being proposed. That development allowance was announced in the One Nation statement on 26 February. At that time no details at all were given as to the administrative arrangements to be put in place to deliver the allowance. At no time was any mention made of setting up an independent statutory authority at a cost well in excess of $1.2m.

It is worth noting that the One Nation statement records that certain broad criteria would need to be observed in identifying projects eligible for the development allowance. Various criteria were spelt out but, strangely, those criteria are not given any attention in the outline of the Bill's explanatory memorandum, although they are contained in the clauses of the Bill. I am not sure what that suggests. It could suggest sloppy or inconsistent drafting. It could also suggest that the Government will not be putting much weight on these broad criteria when it comes to interpreting the legislation. If that is the case, it just increases the whole element of uncertainty to which I referred earlier.

I find it very odd indeed that the requirement in the Bill to meet `world best practice', known as the competitiveness test, is actually to be waived for the first round of applicants who apply before the end of this year. There are various other points one could make about this Bill. The $50m threshold is arbitrary. It distorts investment decisions because there is a big difference in terms of the development allowance situation and, therefore, the tax treatment according to whether a project is a whisker under $50m or a whisker over. Smaller investors, of course, miss out altogether.

There are many reasons—I have only touched on some—why we believe this legislation is a very shoddy piece of work and why we will therefore oppose it. It is a bureaucratic solution being imposed on investment decisions. Quite frankly, it smacks of little more than a political stunt for the Government to have some so-called big projects to tout as successes at the next election.

The main point to be noted in relation to the legislation is that it is very small beer when we look at it against the proposals contained in the coalition's Fightback package. This Government is tinkering at the edges of the fundamental problems confronting business in this country. It does not have the wit or the courage, for whatever reason, to really tackle the major problems that are facing this country in the way that the coalition has set out so concisely and in such detail in its Fightback proposals.

So far as business is concerned, far from mucking around with allowances such as this, we are proposing the abolition of no less than $20 billion of taxes on the cost of doing business in this country—on the actual cost of producing goods and services. That includes, in particular, the abolition of the totally anomaly-ridden, ramshackle wholesale sales tax system that we have in this country, much of which is built into the whole cost structure of business. We are also proposing the abolition of payroll tax, which is a tax on jobs—a massive tax on employment.

When the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) puts on his businessman's hat, as he seems to have been doing in recent times, he is happy to accept the package which exempts the business of which he is a part owner from payroll tax payments, yet he is not prepared to see his Government extend those exemptions and the abolition of payroll tax to other businesses to allow them to grow and create jobs in this country. If the Government were really serious about doing something to assist investment and business to get going again, it would adopt those measures.

It would also have another look at its whole approach to superannuation, about which we have read so much in recent days. There have obviously been deals done between the Democrats and the Government on this. There has been some watering down of the Government's initial proposals. The fact remains that the Government is imposing a system of compulsory employer contribution superannuation which will cost this nation thousands more jobs to add to the unemployment scrap heap that the policies of this Government has produced over the last several years.

If the Government were really serious, it would recognise the fact that the cost of transport in Australia is an enormous burden because of the size of our nation and the reliance we have on road transport. That, in turn, is importantly dependent on the fact that there are such industrial relations problems across the other areas of transport. If the Government were really serious about doing something to lower the costs, it would do what the coalition is proposing and abolish fuel excise. That impacts to the tune of something like $4 billion a year on business in Australia. The Government will not do any of those things. Instead, it mucks around essentially—when compared with the broad sweep of what it ought to be doing—with mickey mouse projects of the nature that are contained in the Development Allowance Authority proposals.

The other Bill that we will be opposing—and for similar reasons—is the Pooled Development Funds Bill. The aim of this Bill is to provide a mechanism for channelling equity capital to eligible small and medium-sized Australian companies, provided those companies have total assets of $30m or less. The incentives to invest in pooled development funds will be tax concessions. They are covered in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). As I said, we are not opposing that Bill, which contains a whole variety of proposals consequential upon some of these other Bills.

The fact is that the PDF scheme is similar, in many respects, to the management investment companies scheme which was in operation in previous years. The management investment companies scheme was unsuccessful and was terminated, with agreement on all sides, in June 1991. The pooled development funds proposal is essentially a new version of that earlier tried but not very successful scheme. One question that the Government ought to be answering is: with the management investment companies scheme having failed in the past and being wound up, why is the new proposal not likely to suffer the same fate?The pooled development funds scheme will encourage the further bureaucratisation of investment at the expense of individual portfolio investment. Very serious objections to the scheme have been raised by both the manufacturing industry, which might be seen as the recipient or beneficiary of the proposal, and many areas of the finance sector.

The Industry Commission, which reported recently on the availability of capital in Australia, does not support the PDF concept. The Industry Commission noted in its report that there had been a rapid growth in intermediaries specialising in investments in smaller companies in the past decade due largely to the deregulation of the finance market. The Industry Commission concluded that the availability of capital for small and medium enterprises depended largely on the rate of return. That is not a very startling finding but it appears to have been overlooked by the Government with respect to bringing forward the pooled development funds proposal. The Industry Commission observed:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission does not consider that direct Government intervention to expand institutional funds available to smaller companies would improve the efficiency of the capital market or the economy generally.

That is a very striking criticism of the proposal contained in this Bill. I would have to say that the Bill is typical of the half-baked schemes which have been cooked up by the Labor Government over the last 10 years almost to try to give the appearance of doing something instead of tackling the fundamental reforms required to stimulate investment.

PARA.TAB: The only effective and enduring policies for boosting the level of savings and, therefore, the level of investment in this country are, as I outlined earlier, the types of policies that are contained in the coalition's Fightback package. The pooled development funds proposal is going into the type of thing that we have seen bankrupt Victoria in recent years—my own State. The Cain Government and now the Kirner Government have got government involved more and more in channelling funds into investment, into trying to pick winners as to where investment will go—getting government's sticky fingers into the whole area of the private sector.

Look at what that has brought about in Victoria. It has brought about a State which is in great despair, which is essentially in depression, not recession, and which has had its public finances totally bankrupted. The cost to Victorians, of which I am one, over future years to try to get back on an even keel, to repair the damage that has been done by that Government, will be extraordinarily high. It will be a major burden on the whole process of economic development in Victoria through the 1990s. Although the pooled development funds proposal is of perhaps a lesser magnitude than that, it is conceptually very similar. It is very dangerous. Given the experience of the Government in previous years, and having seen the experience of other States, I am surprised that it would wish to go down that path.

The other Bills, Taxation Laws Amendment Bills (No. 2) and (No. 3), I will not comment on in detail. My colleague Senator Watson has covered most of the points that I would wish to have made. I will conclude again on the note that I think it is regrettable in the extreme that the Senate and the Parliament as a whole—because of the treatment of these Bills in the House of Representatives as well as in this place—are being forced to debate and give the appearance of considering seriously Bills of such magnitude as these in such a guillotined fashion. This is the hallmark of the Government's incompetence, ineptitude, bad planning and absolutely sloppy mismanagement of its program, which is causing, as I say, such a lack of confidence among investors and throughout the community as a whole.

As I said at the outset, the sooner this Government sees the whites of the electors' eyes, gets out of government and gives the coalition an opportunity to try to restore confidence, hope and jobs to Australia, the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the Opposition should go on too often about guillotining when we look at the amount of time that has been spent on other matters in this place instead of the Government agenda in recent weeks. This evening the Senate is considering a package of legislation which arises from the One Nation statement. Contrary to Senator Panizza's wager that every Australian Democrat will speak for 30 minutes, I will be extremely brief in my comments on this legislation as Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) are not controversial, although of course there are some matters of disagreement on the fine detail and some amendments have been proposed.

PARA.TAB: The No. 2 Bill relating to the capital gains tax will be amended to increase the exemption for goodwill which accrues to the seller of a small business. As honourable senators would know, the capital gains tax exemption for goodwill for small business was inserted into the capital gains tax legislation at the insistence of the Australian Democrats. We support the move by the Government to extend this concession.

TALK.START.PARA: —So do we.

—Good. I am glad to hear that. There are also some technical amendments in respect of the clawback provisions when cooperative research centres receive grants or other expenditure recoupment. In addition, there are some further anti-avoidance amendments which seek to strengthen the law to deal with foreign companies and trusts being used to avoid Australian taxation.

PARA.TAB: Relief from half of the Medicare levy is to be restricted to blind pensioners and sickness allowance beneficiaries. At present, this relief is available to all health card holders. The gift provisions are to be amended to reflect the change of name of the World Wildlife Fund Australia to the World Wide Fund for Nature Australia. There is also an exemption for the pay and allowances of members of the Australian Defence Force allotted for duty with the various United Nations missions in Cambodia.

Out of all of those items there are two major ones I would like to discuss. Firstly, the majority of the accelerated depreciation measures contained in the One Nation statement are implemented in this legislation—and this was long overdue. We had been calling for this for two years, once it became obvious that the decision in the May 1988 economic statement to abolish accelerated depreciation and simultaneously to cut the company tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent simply worsened the habit of Australian business to under-invest in productive capacity and to concentrate on speculative investments which relied to a large extent on inflation. This is the real tragedy of the 1980s—that a lot of money which was sacrificed by workers under the accord, was not reinvested in productive industry but squandered.

We welcome these changes. They are simply a reversal of a bad mistake. Nonetheless, it must not be forgotten that the company tax rate is now very low. Given the fact that New Zealand had to raise its company tax rate from 28 per cent—which prompted the March 1988 changes—to 33 per cent, the rationale for keeping the rate at 39 per cent in Australia seems to have diminished substantially.

The other matter is the question of deductibility of contributions to superannuation funds where the contributor is a member of more than two funds. We welcome the amendment which protects the members of multiple funds who would otherwise lose most of their tax concessions simply because of the receipt of a small amount of additional income and some superannuation benefits as a consequence. I wish to clarify this position by stating again that the Democrats believe that the current taxation arrangements which apply to superannuation are not fair. Even though these arrangements are too generous, it is not fair to deny the current concession to some people because of an anomaly.

Finally, we welcome the deferral of the initial payment of company tax for small business. The deferral is only minor—only for nine weeks—but it will benefit small business and, as such, is supported by the Australian Democrats.

The other piece of legislation in this cognate debate is the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). A variety of matters are covered. Again, the majority of the items arose from the One Nation statement. This legislation is also supported by the Democrats.

There are a series of measures which improve the depreciation regime further in respect of traveller accommodation—by that we mean hotels and motels, et cetera—industrial buildings and income producing structural improvements. The Democrats support these measures, although we believe that they could have been vastly improved if correct sustainability principles had been applied. For example, the Democrats believe that the more generous depreciation arrangements for new buildings should have been contingent on energy efficiency design and other features being incorporated into the buildings.

As we have said so often, we should be using the taxation system to encourage sustainable development and we should make a number of improvements. The bad debts provision is not opposed by the Democrats, although there is no evidence that it has achieved the avoidance of bankruptcies and foreclosures as was claimed at the time of One Nation. Whether the infrastructure bonds will prove very effective is still a moot point at this stage. However, we hope that they prove popular and that they will facilitate more privately funded infrastructure projects and, hence, jobs for many Australians.

I have to comment on the position taken by the Opposition in respect of major matters in this legislation—that is, the pooled development funds proposal and the Development Allowance Authority proposal, which Senator Sowada will be dealing with. The Opposition's attitude is still totally ideologically nineteenth century laissez faire driven. It is now a definite liability to this country. There is no point in trying to outdo the deregulationist policies of this Government. Community sentiment has really turned around and has started to reject the worship of the free market. It just goes to show that the Opposition needs to rethink its approach to tax, not gloat about its superiority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that why you got only a 2 per cent vote in the recent election?

—Senator Knowles would not know what she was talking about. Earlier this year I gave notice that we were proposing to address the anomalies which confront primary producers in respect of the expenses of fruit trees and other producing vines and trees not allowable as tax deductions at the time they are planted. They cannot be written off for income tax purposes. Senator Bell is on a parliamentary delegation overseas and, hence, is not here to move an amendment to this legislation. I simply ask Senator McMullan to comment on this anomaly and tell us whether the Government will do something about it.

—I will be addressing my remarks to the two other Bills not covered by Senator Kernot's speech. Before I do so, I would like to make a few remarks about Senator Short's introduction to his contribution to this debate. I agree with him that the Government could have managed its legislative agenda a lot better. It is deplorable that we are now in a situation of having to deal with—this is what I counted on the list—57 Bills in the next two weeks. It is really terrible that we should be in a position of having to consider some extremely important measures and major changes to government policy in such a short time.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, as a relative newcomer to this place, it has been fascinating to watch what has happened over the last few months. I would say that one of the reasons why we are in this situation is that the Opposition has wasted a considerable amount of time using devices to stymie debate in this place, to prevent Bills from coming on and to debate issues which have, in our opinion, simply wasted time.

For example, at the beginning of this session we saw a whole litany of debates on Fightback. Over and over again, the Opposition brought on debate after debate about Fightback as it attempted to get its agenda back onto the Senate Notice Paper and back into the public mind, as it had literally died over the Christmas recess. We have also seen the increasing tendency of the Opposition to use the device of taking note of Ministers' answers during Question Time. In the last fortnight of sitting, each day we saw some 2 1/2 hours taken up by the Opposition taking note of answers. It is our belief that this device has been used increasingly to waste the time of the Senate and prevent the debate of Government legislation.

I was very interested to hear Senator Short's remarks about managing the Government agenda. As I said earlier, I agree that it could have been managed a whole lot better. But I recall having heard the coalition in New South Wales saying very much the same thing as this just before it came into government in 1988. I recall having spoken to senior members of the New South Wales coalition shortly after they had won the 1988 election. They promised me—they swore blind—that, yes, they would manage government business far better than the Labor Party had in the dying days of the Unsworth Government; no, they would not be rushing through legislation at the eleventh hour; and, no, there would not be any late night sittings.

But I can tell honourable senators that it did not take very long for the coalition to break that promise. In New South Wales we very shortly—in fact, within a year of its first term of government—saw the late night sittings; we saw the sittings until 6.00 a.m.; and we saw the agenda lengthen with legislation towards the end of the sitting, as in fact this Government is attempting to do now in this place.

I suggest to the coalition that if it is promising to manage government business better when it becomes the Government after the next election—if in fact it becomes the Government—I will be recalling to Senator Short his very words during this debate today and ensuring that the coalition likewise keeps its promise to manage government business a whole lot better than the Government has done in this fortnight of sitting.

With those opening remarks, I will now confine myself to the two Bills in the package before us for which I am responsible. Those Bills are the Development Allowance Authority Bill 1992 and the Pooled Development Funds Bill 1992. Through these measures, the Government is attempting to encourage investment in industry and lower unemployment rates, as it indicated in the One Nation statement earlier this year.

The Australian Democrats broadly support the thrust of these two Bills but have concerns that some of the parameters are too constricting to bring about the upsurge in investment on which the Government is pinning its hopes for Australia's economic recovery.

The Development Allowance Authority Bill 1992 will establish a statutory authority—yet another statutory authority, as Senator Short has quite rightly pointed out—called the Development Allowance Authority. It will have a fixed life, terminating on 1 July 2002, and will consist of one member. The DAA will assess the eligibility of projects with gross expenditure of $50m or more for the development allowance, which is the deduction against income equal to 10 per cent of eligible plant expenditure in the first year that the plant is used or installed ready for use. This is provided for in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

Definite criteria have been set out to evaluate eligibility. Projects must obtain a pre-qualifying certificate to claim the development allowance. Specific criteria must be met. For example, the project must be able to provide a sufficient and achievable contribution to Australia's competitive standing and plant expenditure must be for legitimate primary use in the eligible project. Important trigger dates are to be set against each step of the DAA's assessment of an application to reinforce the object of the allowance, which is to bring forward investment in new plant and equipment.

The cost of this new measure will be $40m in 1994-95 and a further $70m in 1995-96. The cut-off date for pre-qualifying certificates is 1 August 1996. The plant must be in use or installed ready for use by 1 July 2002, as assessed by the Commissioner of Taxation. We note that industries whose nominal and effective rate of assistance is greater than 10 per cent will not be eligible for the development allowance. This means that investment in textile, clothing and footwear industries and the passenger motor vehicle industry will not be eligible. However, manufacturing investment in capital intensive, high tech industries will be able to take advantage of this short term concession.

The Australian Democrats have some concerns about the trigger dates. The Bill requires that an applicant must have applied for registration with the DAA for plant expenditure incurred, or proposed to be incurred, by 1 January 1993. Given that it is already nearing the end of June, we believe that this timeframe may be too short to allow for full publication and dissemination of the scheme in the business community. We understand, however, that this deadline is fuelled by the Government's desire for projects to begin as soon as possible to bring forward new investment and stimulate the economy.

We have been advised that the secretariat is already established and is ready to start as soon as this Bill has been passed and that many companies, such as Price Waterhouse, are already informing their clients about the development allowance. Nevertheless, many projects may lose out because they have not been able to meet this tight timeframe for various good reasons. In this respect, the Australian Democrats believe the eligibility criteria may be seriously flawed.

On environmental grounds, of course, project applications must meet criteria from all levels of government, including State and Territory environmental laws. The Australian Democrats applaud the fact that certain environmental projects, for example, a mining company undertaking to prevent water pollution, will be considered as eligible for the development allowance.

An amount of $200,000 has been set aside for consultants' fees during the next financial year. We have been advised that consultants are being used to assess application forms for such things as legality, clarity, and assessing world best practice aspects of the scheme. I ask the Minister to ensure that the Parliament is provided with full details of all consultants used, their services and the cost, when the Development Allowance Authority reports to the Parliament next year.

The Pooled Development Funds Bill 1992 establishes concessionally taxed investment companies, called pooled development funds, to provide patient equity capital for eligible activities in Australian companies with total assets not greater than $30m. The Bill aims to strengthen the program announced in One Nation to alleviate the lack of development capital. The pooled development funds board has five members from the private sector with one ex-officio DITAC member. Capital will be raised through the issuing of shares and gains by shareholders will be tax exempt. PDFs will be taxed at only 30 per cent, not the company tax rate of 39 per cent. There are also various criteria to be met and restraints.

The Australian Democrats will support this Bill as the potential benefits to Australia's high technology export industries are too great to be put at risk by the whim of a self-interested Opposition. Australia has a long and depressing record of marketable innovation and inventions sent overseas through lack of local development funds. We believe that the development and marketing of new technologies and industries will be much more attractive to superannuation fund investment managers under the new arrangements.

The Australian Democrats have long been advocates of an improved method of delivering venture and development capital to new projects and high tech research. Development capital investment is often seen as too risky by conservative investment and fund managers and therefore researchers and scientists have often faced tremendous difficulties in commercialising research. In this respect, I draw honourable senators' attention to Memtec's difficulties which were exacerbated by its inability to access venture capital and nearly saw it take its ideas offshore through want of local investors.

However, this Bill still does not provide an adequate incentive for seeding capital for new business ventures. A PDF is restricted from committing more than 5 per cent of its capital to new business enterprises which, in our view, is too narrow a criteria when start-up venture capital is so often sorely needed to get new ideas off the ground. Whilst the focus of this Bill is directed at providing equity capital for existing projects, it is our belief that this focus should be widened to improve the access to capital by new ventures through the PDF scheme.

The venture and development capital industry has strongly lobbied for major changes to tax and other arrangements for PDFs, as it believed that the original scheme signalled in One Nation was inflexible and unattractive to investors. However, the use of the imputation system to give the superannuation funds a franking credit, therefore effectively reducing the proposed 30 per cent tax on PDF income to their current rate of taxation of 15 per cent, will remove a huge impediment to super fund investment.

The Government is attempting to improve access to equity capital. We are pleased that it has taken advice from industry and has allowed individual investors to take up to 20 per cent of a PDF, and that PDFs are now allowed to invest up to 20 per cent of funds in a single project rather than the 10 per cent previously allowed in both cases. Further, PDFs, although primarily required to invest in newly issued shares, may now be allowed to buy pre-owned shares as a supplement to existing shares, provided they can prove to the board that the value of the investee company will be increased as a result.

We are disappointed that all the major recommendations of the development capital forum have not been included in this Bill. In the light of these recommendations, we would like to have the opportunity in 18 months time to reassess the scheme and make any necessary alterations to improve it. In particular, some of the investment criteria of the pooled development funds scheme could be too narrow and may need revision.

As Senator Kernot has already pointed out, we are disappointed that the coalition has chosen to oppose these Bills as we believe that the measures outlined in this legislation go some way to providing very much-needed venture capital to struggling small business in Australia. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

—Yes.

—I have been a bit concerned since I came into the chamber this afternoon and heard Senator Sowada and Senator Kernot flapping their gums about all the responsibility that the Opposition should take for the backlog of some 57 Bills in this chamber. TALK.START.PARA: —It is like sitting in the middle of the canary cage with those two going. Let Senator Sowada stand up and apologise to this Senate for misleading the Senate by saying that it is the Opposition's responsibility that these 57 Bills are here, guillotined in front of the Senate today. I will bet London to a brick on that Senator Sowada does not have the courage to stand up and apologise. She has all the courage in the world to lay the blame and the accusation in one corner because her kissing cousins over there, the Labor Party, have done the dirty.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator J. Coates
