Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Coates

During the Committee's consideration of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) 1992 on 5 June 1992, I agreed to the Australian Taxation Office providing Senator Short with information in writing on the potential revenue implications of extending infrastructure borrowings as requested in submissions made to the Committee by Mr A Proctor of KPMG and Mr J McMeckan of Macquarie Bank.
Briefly, the submission by Mr Proctor was that:

PARA.TAB: (a)limited partnerships should be able to issue infrastructure borrowings;
(b)infrastructure borrowings should be able to be used to acquire partly completed infrastructure facilities;
(c)they should be able to be used at any time to re-finance the ongoing operations of the business, including expenditure which is incurred prior to the date of issue of the borrowings; and
(d)transmission facilities in the electricity generating industry should be able to be financed using infrastructure borrowings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Paper prepared by Macquarie Bank submitted to the Committee requested amendments to the Bill to allow limited partnerships to issue infrastructure borrowings and to allow them to be used to fund all construction commenced subsequent to 1 July 1992.

Contrary to the assumption in the Macquarie Bank's submission, infrastructure borrowings will be able to be used to finance new construction work on an eligible infrastructure facility performed on or after 1 July 1992. The fact that construction of the facility commenced before 1 July 1992 will not prevent infrastructure borrowings being used to finance work done on the facility on or after that date. The only condition in relation to the work is that it is not done under a contract entered into before 27 February 1992.

A limited partnership is a partnership which has both general partners, whose liability is unlimited, and limited partners, whose liability is limited to the amount of capital they have invested in the partnership. Even though the liability of limited partners is limited to their contribution they may have access to losses in excess of that contribution, and for which they may not be liable.

Limited partners do not participate in the management of the partnership and are therefore similar to investors, such as shareholders in a company. The issuer of a direct infrastructure borrowing must intend to "own, operate and effectively control the use of, the facilities on which the money will be spent" (proposed subsection 159GZZZZB(1). A limited partner is not in a position to exercise that kind of control and is not exposed to the risks associated with ownership.

The estimated revenue cost of concessionally taxed borrowings to finance the construction of infrastructure facilities was based on the level of debt that might be used to finance the construction of infrastructure facilities of the kind specially targeted for assistance. If infrastructure borrowings were to be available to re-finance existing debt, to acquire partly constructed projects and to finance transmission facilities in the electricity generating industry there would be a considerable increase in the level of debt that would be eligible for the tax concession, and a corresponding increase in the cost to the revenue.

If the borrowings were able to be used to re-finance existing debt and to acquire partly constructed facilities the revenue cost would commence in the 1992-93 year. In later years the increased revenue cost would be significant because, if Mr Proctor's submission was adopted, eligible borrowings would not be confined to the cost of constructing infrastructure facilities and acquiring related facilities, but would be available to finance the "on-going operations of the business". This increase in the scope of the concession could be expected to translate into a massive increase in the revenue cost.

Infrastructure borrowings are a targeted tax preference recognising that the Government considers electricity generation, land transport and seaports high priorities and areas where private sector involvement can best be encouraged. Infrastructure borrowings are designed to promote private ownership, operation and control not just private finance of infrastructure. It is not clear that the transmission stage of electricity is amenable to such a private role. Also, transmission does not have the scope for operating efficiencies as generation does.

A rough estimate of the cost of infrastructure borrowings is around $5m for each $100m raised in terms of tax on lenders forgone. Most of that amount will be recovered in around 5 years when the borrowers may generate sufficient income so that the fact that they have forgone their tax deductions results in their paying more tax. The possible costs of the Bass Link project, or whether it would satisfy the "private" tests of infrastructure borrowings, is not known. The cost of extending the concession to electricity transmission is impossible to estimate as it is critically dependent on the number, scale and timeframe of possible private transmission projects and the extent to which they are financed by infrastructure borrowings.
BOB MCMULLAN
Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us an important package of legislation. In many ways the debate on these taxation Bills has reflected their significance—not the last few minutes of the flurry, but, in the main, honourable senators were dealing with matters of substance and dealing with them substantially. I do not of course agree with a lot of the things that were said, but that is a different question. I would normally make a fairly lengthy contribution to this second reading debate because this is important material, but that would be using up a limited amount of time, so I will not do that. I do wish to respond in some detail, but not as much as I usually would.

PARA.TAB: I should formally indicate, firstly, as the Senate is aware, that there will be two Government amendments to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, which we will deal with at the committee stage. I understand that at least one of those amendments is supported by the Opposition, perhaps both, but I am aware from Senator Watson's contribution that he supports one of them.

Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) contains some important substantial matters. In all the hue and cry about timing, guillotines and amendments—including the Government's amendments—which are secondary issues, we cannot take our attention away from the big questions that are involved in that Bill and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). Between them they constitute a very important package of tax reform which substantially reflects the initiatives of One Nation. They form a substantial part of the package to give stimulus to the Australian economy in a way that will also encourage investment that will make the Australian economy more efficient in the long term. I refer, for example, to the depreciation amendments and the capital gains tax goodwill exemption in the Taxation Laws Amendment (No. 3) Bill in particular.

The No. 3 Bill, in a sense, is more substantial in that regard with PDFs, the tax exempt infrastructure borrowings, the capital expenditure on traveller accommodation and the development allowance as examples. There are others. Different people have different priorities, and in the time available I do not wish to deal with them all. Taken together they constitute a major contribution to the economic well-being of this nation. They are a significant element of One Nation.

One Nation is a package essentially designed to do two integrated things that are necessary for our economy: first, to give short term stimulus to the economy. Tax measures are not, on the whole, well suited to the task of giving short term stimulus, because by definition they are designed to encourage investment, and the lead times tend to be long. They tend to fit more in the second element, but some parts of these Bills are more short term and for that reason have tight timetables. The obvious example would be the development allowance. It is designed to bring forward investment to ensure that we have that necessary stimulus for the economy. In the main, it is the expenditure element of One Nation that provides the short term stimulus, although there is some of that here.

The second and interlocking element of One Nation is its intention to stimulate the economy in the medium term by directly making, on the expenditure side of the Budget, and encouraging through tax measures, investments that will not only create jobs in themselves but that will, in the process, make the economy more efficient. For those reasons they are particularly important. This is an important part of the continuing economic debate between the competing packages of the major parties—One Nation and Fightback—with the alternative propositions put forward by the Democrats. This is a very important contribution to that debate and it is a very important part of the Government's agenda for economic reform in Australia.

I come back to the detail of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. I do not want to do now what one could and should do in the committee stage. I have referred to the two Government amendments and I will deal with them in more detail then. There is one Opposition amendment which I understand will be proceeded with which relates to the situation in Cambodia. All I will say in the second reading stage is that there is no disagreement about objectives. The Government is of the view that the amendment is entirely unnecessary to achieve the agreed purpose. I will deal with that further in the committee stage, but that is the essence of our position which I will expand upon.

Senator Kernot raised a particular question which I understood at one stage may have been the basis of an amendment. I think quite appropriately at this stage she has simply raised the issue and invited me to respond to it. I will do so now. This relates to what I called in my shorthand notes which were prepared for this speech the `fruit trees' amendment. The Democrats are concerned about the depreciation arrangements for investment in orchards in general and fruit trees in particular. Within the question raised by Senator Kernot on behalf of the Democrats, there are some interesting questions about the most appropriate treatment of such expenditure, the most appropriate treatment of what is currently regarded as capital expenditure by orchardists and how that might most appropriately be regarded. I do not want to make a final, definitive response here today on it. I simply say it raises some important questions and the Government is prepared to examine any submissions people want to make about how that might best be modified.

We do not want to amend the legislation on the run, and therefore I welcome the fact that we are not dealing with a precise amendment on this occasion. I am almost certain we would have been in a position where we would have had to oppose that amendment, because there are a lot of issues, not all of which have been fully considered. I do not want to say that there is no merit in the concerns that have been raised. It is a question of substance and we will seek to deal with it accordingly.

There was a substantial amount of discussion about Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992 in the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and it would be inappropriate to duplicate that here. There were a number of issues outstanding, many of which were dealt with in my letter to Senator Coates which I have incorporated. Once again, in order not to take up the Senate's time unnecessarily, I will not repeat that here. It fits within the broad framework that I outlined of these packages taken as a whole as part of One Nation. There are a large number of important issues.

Senator Watson raised in particular again an issue that was raised and debated at some length during the Committee hearing. This was a concern about the potential retrospective effect of the amendments concerning research and development and exploration expenditure. For people who want a detailed consideration of the Government's position on that—it is essentially a technical matter—I refer them to the Hansard of the Committee hearing where a very detailed discussion took place about the general principles of what was intended to be achieved, why we were proceeding to amend in this way and our view that the amendment merely makes clear what is the existing legislation. Our view is that it is an amendment that does not change the rights or obligations of any taxpayer; it merely makes it clearer. Therefore, if there is no burden, there can be no problem of retrospective application of that burden. I think that argument was pretty broadly accepted, but if people wish to pursue that in more detail they should refer to the extensive debate which has already taken place on that matter.

In conclusion, I turn to the two associated Bills, the Pooled Development Funds Bill 1992 and the Development Allowance Authority Bill 1992. These have been very inappropriately denigrated. I am somewhat surprised and particularly disappointed that we find ourselves in some conflict over these important Bills, because they both seem to me self-evidently to be proposals with a significant capacity to enhance the economic well-being of Australia, particularly in the medium term but also in the short term.

There is a common theme in the evidence that is put forward by small to medium size business to politicians of all political persuasions, I am sure. I cannot comment on the suggestions that are made to Opposition, Democrat and Independent senators when they visit business, but I can certainly comment on behalf of government members and I can certainly speak for myself. One of the concerns most frequently expressed—it was made clear by Senator Button and the Minister on his behalf in the House of Representatives, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free)—is the failure of the Australian capital market to provide long term development capital for productive investment. It came up again explicitly in the extensive and important consultations that Ministers had with business prior to the One Nation statement.

It is difficult to prove that there is this lack of development capital. There is not a database that one can point to that says that is what proves the problem exists. The anecdotal evidence is very strong. The concern of business is very real. The Government accepts that we should act to improve the flow of development capital to revitalise and restructure mature industries, to assist the growth and development of new industries and firms, and to provide the sort of enhanced expertise in important new technologies which will be fundamental to competitiveness in the 1990s. It is from those small and medium size firms that much of the growth for the economy will come in the recovery stage that we are entering now. It is very important that we enhance and encourage those companies.

I do not share the view of the Opposition. I understood—although, listening from my room, it seemed somewhat more stridently put by Senator Short today, but it may be that I did not pick up all the nuances of his position—that the Opposition's position essentially was that the PDF proposal was insufficient and that more needed to be done. If the argument about PDF was that it is the beginning and the end of the requirements of small business, then I suggest that would be a valid criticism. As an element in an armory of measures to enhance economic performance, I think one has to say that, at the very least, it is a small plus. I think it is more than that.

The most important thing to the success of small business is that the economy is growing. That does more for the success of any small business than any particular tax measure or any other measure. To be a participant in a growing economy is the best mechanism for having a successful business because the market is there.

TALK.START.PARA: —As long as you don't tax them out of existence at the end of it.

—It is self-evident that, if we are taxing business out of existence, there is not a growing economy. A growing economy is the most important element for small to medium size business. But, within that, one needs an interlocking range of other mechanisms. It is not the Government's job to make those businesses efficient. We do not want to go in there and try to run them. We do not want to teach individuals how to run their business, but it is desirable that we provide a framework within which they can make the sorts of investment decisions that will enhance their business. That is a very broad summary of what the PDF is designed to do.

PARA.TAB: The Development Allowance Authority Bill has been debated a lot. Essentially I made my comments about that in my discussion about the tax Bill which provides the benefit which flows to people who have the approval of the Authority and who meet the other requirements. But I note the comments made by Senator Sowada about that Bill. It is something that I will refer to the Treasurer and ensure that, when we are reporting back, her comments are taken into account.

I do not wish to take up the time of the Senate any longer. Other than matters we might debate further in the committee stage, there are no other points that I wish to make. As I said at the beginning, I believe that this is one of the more important packages of Bills that the Senate will deal with in this session. It is very desirable that we give speedy passage to this legislation because it has the capacity to significantly enhance the economic performance of Australia, to make some contribution to that short term impetus and to make a very significant contribution to that medium term restructuring that will give us a more efficient and competitive economy. For that reason, I thank the Senate to the extent that it has supported the legislation and I look forward to the speedy passage of the Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short explanation on a matter I mentioned previously in this debate.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer has closed the debate. Could you make your explanation in the committee stage?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no problem with a short statement, but if you perceive that it is not appropriate, Mr Acting Deputy President, the Senate can hear it later.
—No, it is just as easy to get it out of the way now.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you may remember that in my speech I referred to the number of Bills that have been introduced late. My calculation is that 53 Bills were introduced into this Senate after 27 May 1992, 19 of which were introduced after 1 June 1992. Those figures should put paid to any suggestion by the Australian Democrats that time was wasted on the Fightback package and that these Bills should not be in front of the Senate now.
—The question is that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and related Bills be agreed to.

—As we foreshadowed in the second reading debate, the coalition will be opposing two of the four Bills: the Pooled Development Funds Bill 1992 and the Development Allowance Authority Bill 1992. I wonder whether we could procedurally split the vote so that we can have a division.
—Two packages of two Bills?
—Yes, I think that two packages of two Bills will be okay.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson—Would it be possible to deal with Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) first, separately, and then Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) separately?

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is the wish of the Committee. The Committee is dealing with Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992.

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary memorandum relating to the Government amendments to be moved to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5, page 2, after paragraph 5(a), insert the following paragraph:
"(ab)by inserting after subsection 23AC(2) the following subsections:
`(2A)A certificate issued in accordance with paragraph (2)(cb) shall cease to have force only in accordance with a certificate of revocation signed by the Chief of the Defence Force.
`(2B)A certificate of revocation made in accordance with subsection (2A) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.'.".

The Opposition is concerned about some ambiguity in the legislation relating to the tax-free status or otherwise of entitlements for Defence Force personnel serving in Cambodia. I understand that the Government believes that the Opposition amendment is not necessary. We, however, would prefer to err on the side of safety. The Government has not always given the interests of servicemen the highest priority. In fact, even now the senior Australian officer serving as a peacekeeper in Cambodia has been without his pay and allowances for six months. So it is in the light of items like that that the Opposition wants to be very careful that the i's are dotted and the t's are crossed on anything to do with the conditions of service of Australian peacekeepers.

PARA.TAB: I draw attention to the fact that in Namibia the peacekeepers were treated differently from the way it appears they will be treated in Cambodia. Regarding the exemption which the Government is proposing for the tax-free status pay for Cambodia, while it is to be backdated to 9 June 1991—and properly so—it will apparently be terminated once the UN declares a cease-fire in Cambodia. I can see some advisers' heads shaking. It will be on the certificate to be issued. The entitlement of Defence Force personnel is in accordance with a certificate from the Chief of the Defence Force.

We are concerned that, if that is the motive—and of course I would not want to claim the Government has an ulterior motive—it would be perfectly possible for the Government, so as to be seen to be protecting the revenue, to decide that certificate from the Chief of the Defence Force could be revoked at a time when it suited the revenue rather than the interests of Defence Force personnel.

Therefore, in our amendment, we require the certificate of revocation, signed by the Chief of the Defence Force, to be a disallowable instrument. In other words, we believe it is proper that the Parliament should be entitled to scrutinise very carefully when the Government, with the assistance of the Chief of the Defence Force, determines that eligibility for tax-free pay will end. When one thinks about it, Cambodia is such a fluid and difficult situation that, even now, when the cease-fire should in fact be in existence, when we should have moved perhaps to a slightly less dangerous period of the peacekeeping, we still have only token disarmament from three of the factions and a refusal to disarm by the fourth faction.

We also have to recognise that people in Cambodia, civilian or military, are facing an extremely difficult situation with regard to land mines—perhaps even worse than was feared when our troops went to Namibia. Therefore, they are going to be in a very dangerous situation for a long time to come, and what is operational and what is not is going to be very much in the eye of the beholder. We do not believe that this should just be a matter for the Government to decide. We believe it is very important that the Parliament should decide when our peacekeeping forces are no longer on operational service in such a dangerous mission as they are quite clearly facing in Cambodia.

So we do not accept the Government's view that our amendments are overcautious or unnecessary. Anything that can be put in place that properly protects the conditions of service of our servicemen should be put in. I really do not understand why the Government would quibble at accepting this amendment. If it says it is simply unnecessary, it certainly cannot be seen to do any harm. I would have thought that the Government would not object to the Parliament scrutinising its actions as to when Defence Force personnel are no longer on the service for which they have become entitled to tax-free pay. It is also of course of moment to servicemen in their entitlements under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

So quite a great deal rides for a serviceman on what his status is at any given time, whether it is purely peacekeeping or whether it is operational. I do not think I need to labour the point. I urge the Committee to support the Opposition's amendment, which is not designed to take political points off the Government but simply to give extra protection—if protection is needed; and we believe it is—to our servicemen. I urge the Government, and of course the Democrats, to support our amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to say that there is a shared purpose in the chamber with regard to this matter. It is a question of best method, not objective. We share the view that, for as long as Australia's personnel are involved in the difficult circumstances of the type they are at the moment in Cambodia, they should continue to have the benefit of the provisions with which we are dealing.

PARA.TAB: The Government has not fixed a determination date in relation to the Cambodian tax exemption for the obvious reason that nobody can be certain when the involvement of the members will end. The exemption, as the explanatory memorandum says, will apply until a termination date is specified by the Chief of the Defence Force. The only way in which this can be a cause of concern—that in some way the interests of the defence personnel will not properly be taken into account—is if there is a concern that the Government, through either, I assume, the Treasurer or the Minister for Defence, will force the Chief of the Defence Force to sign a certificate that he would not wish to do and that he might quietly comply without kicking up some sort of a ruckus.

Many people here probably know the Chief of the Defence Force better than I do, but I know him a little and I would have thought that was a highly unlikely position, to put it politely. It is not a concern that I share. I do not want in any way to criticise the intent of the amendment. As I say, I think we have a shared purpose; we are only talking about process. I am advised that this is the standard process and that there is no need to go further. For that reason we are not proposing to accept the amendment. I cannot get passionate and say that there is some outrage involved. I believe the amendment is unnecessary and that the prevailing provisions will discharge the requirement in the normal way, as they have on previous similar occasions, I am advised, and as they should on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer, but I really do not feel that it is a very satisfactory one. All he is saying, as I suggested when I spoke earlier, is that he just does not feel it is necessary. It gives us no assurance that the best interests of the servicemen will be paramount. It also does not recognise the fact that, for example, when we sent our personnel to the Gulf, they were on operational service while they were there and took on a different status when they were removed physically from the danger area.

PARA.TAB: We are not talking about that situation here; we are talking about where people will stay on, doing virtually the same job in the same place. It will be a very difficult, fluid thing from day to day to decide that their service is no longer an operational service. I cannot understand why the Government, if it is to be

SPEECH.PARA: seen to be protecting the interests of the servicemen, would not say, `All right, we will allow the Parliament to scrutinise that decision'. Is it such a dreadful thing for the Government to allow the Parliament to scrutinise a decision?That would not be a criticism of the Chief of the Defence Force or a criticism of the Government, but it does not mean to say that all wisdom resides with either the Government or the Chief of the Defence Force.

PARA.TAB: We were very much involved, and wanted to be involved as a parliament, when we dispatched our people to the Gulf. Should we not be equally concerned about the well-being of our troops in Cambodia? As I mentioned earlier, we have not been all that crash-hot in making sure that these people we send away get their entitlements, either at all or in a good and timely fashion. Why is it too much to ask of the Government to put this extra protection in place?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister says that it is unnecessary, but I need to know from him whether it would cause any problems if it were passed.

—It is pretty hard for me to answer that straight away. I understand the concern that Senator Kernot has. I would have thought that in the normal course of events the Parliament—and the Senate in particular—has been very unwilling to put into the taxation legislation things that might not do any harm, even if they do no good. That has not met with much favour. In fact, I keep being berated—including by my colleagues in the Opposition who do so all the time—because the tax legislation is too big and there are too many bits in it.

PARA.TAB: As a starting point I say that this is not a proposal that would normally be well received, if all we are saying is that it does not do any harm. A lot of things do not do any harm, but if they are all added together they may end up not exactly enhancing the simplicity of our legislation.

I do not want to make a big issue out of what is and is not. I cannot see the crisis in making it disallowable. I do not see why we should have the view that the Parliament is, firstly, better placed to know whether the circumstances are appropriate for a termination date than the Chief of the Defence Force.Within the constraints of the reasonable requirements of executive government I am a defender of the rights of the Parliament. I am not one to say that, if some wise, external person makes a judgment, Parliament should not interfere. That is one of the reasons why our enthusiasm to run off to get judges to do all the sorts of things that parliamentarians ought to do is a bad idea.

If I were asked to pick an issue on which it might be reasonable to say that an independent officer of the Crown is better placed than the Parliament to make a judgment, I would back a decision made by the Chief of the Defence Force about whether certain military and security issues have been resolved in Cambodia more often than I would back most of us. If Senator Kernot is asking me whether I think the outcome is going to be any different whether we carry this amendment or not, as I said right at the start of this debate, the answer is no. I do not want to make a Federal case out of the jargon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Support it and it will be over and done with.

—Honourable senators opposite set three hours for this debate; I would hate to disappoint them by finishing so early. If that happened, they would ask for a bit of extra time. I am simply saying that I do not think it is a very good idea, nor a very wonderful precedent, but I do not want to exaggerate and say to the Committee, `This is a terrible crisis'. When I think some other proposed amendment is a crisis, I will come in here and say so, but I do not intend to invent a crisis when one does not exist. I think that is undesirable and it is preferable not to do it. But I think the net change to the outcome ffrom whichever side one looks at it—either for Consolidated Revenue or for the individual—is nil. Therefore, I think the amendment is a waste of time, but I do not want to pursue it any further. If everybody else wants to vote for it, so be it. The Government will not divide on it, but I hope the Democrats do not vote for it.
—I would like to ask Senator Newman how Parliament will make this judgment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will simply be a question of disallowance. Is that what Senator Kernot means?
—How will you judge it? What facts will you use? Where will you get the information from?

—I remind Senator Kernot that during the Gulf war the Democrats wanted to have a say about how, when and in what manner our people were committed. I would have thought that, in relation to how and when our people remain committed in a situation which is dangerous, this Parliament would have a continuing interest in whether our peacekeepers stay there and continue to be shot at or whether there is any requirement on them to be withdrawn. That in itself is surely a matter for this Parliament to take a close and careful interest in.

PARA.TAB: I would have also thought that the Government, through the Chief of the Defence Force maybe, would make a decision as to whether the personnel involved should no longer be given special protection under the Veterans' Entitlements Act of operational service. Whether they get a tax free status is surely something which relates to compensation for the commitment that these personnel make. Surely we have their lives and their well-being in our hands. It is not unreasonable if we, as a group of representatives of the people, have the opportunity to decide these matters which are of such moment for these people, who could be sacrificing everything for us and for the peace of the world.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before responding to Senator Watson, I table a correction to the explanatory memorandum relating to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992. With regard to Senator Watson's question, I have to confess a terrible sin: I do not have a copy of One Nation with me. I realise that honourable senators opposite will be shocked by that. I rarely walk anywhere without it, but on this one occasion I am naked in the chamber.
—Gareth carries nice letters in his pocket, so the least you can do is carry a copy of One Nation.
—Perhaps I should stand up and do a quick recitation of some of the more wonderful letters that have been sent to me.
—Just get back to the point.

—I will get back to Senator Watson's serious point. I do not have the words in front of me. My understanding, which has been confirmed by the advisers, is that the acquisition to which One Nation refers is ancillary acquisition to construction. That is, if we are constructing an infrastructure project and, as part of that construction, to complete the project we have to buy some equipment to go into that infrastructure, that was intended to be and is covered by the legislation. It was never intended to cover, and does not cover, the acquisition of an existing project. It may be—I do not have the document in front of me—that One Nation could have been expressed more unequivocally. That is my understanding. The intention has been confirmed as the intention that was conveyed to the officers responsible for developing the legislation. The legislation reflects that understanding.

—There is a difficulty where there is a variance between a statement as important as the One Nation statement and a Treasurer's press release. To most people, the words were quite clear—`acquisition or construction of facilities'. I appreciate the dilemma in which Senator McMullan finds himself in not having the One Nation statement in front of him. The words that appear in the legislation have a significant impact in terms of raising quite substantially the cost of capital.

PARA.TAB: I also query whether infrastructure bonds should be able to be used to refinance temporary project debt. When going to the market at the riskiest time of the project—that is, the construction stage—funds will naturally be more costly than when the project is up and running. Accordingly, I draw Senator McMullan's attention to an increased cost of financing as a result of what might have been an unintended consequence of not acknowledging the situation of temporary finance project debt which could qualify for infrastructure borrowing. It appears from the wording that it is excluded at the present time. I draw the Committee's attention to the fact that a lack of roll-over relief will put additional lead in the saddlebags and make it much more difficult for such projects to get off the ground.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an important distinction—and I am not sure whether this meets Senator Watson's concern because there are two separate issues, one which does not fall within the legislation and one which does. I am not absolutely clear which of the two Senator Watson is referring to. He may be referring to both. There is refinancing of debt which exists prior to the impact of this legislation. It may be an ongoing project but the debt itself would not qualify. Then we cannot refinance that debt to make it qualify because that does not serve the purpose that One Nation is driving towards. But my understanding and advice is—and this is what I thought was Senator Watson's concern—that, if we have what I will call for the purpose of our discussion across the chamber `qualifying debt' and we refinance that qualifying debt, it remains qualifying debt.

—I draw the Minister's attention to the possibility, perhaps, of an omnibus Bill amendment later on in terms of section 63E and eligible investment business. I just make the suggestion that perhaps this could be redrafted in future for where `a debtor is a company or a unit trust'. I believe this would simplify people's understanding of what was actually intended.

PARA.TAB: Also, I raise one matter which perhaps we should explore a little more thoroughly. I did have the opportunity of speaking with one of the Minister's advisers before the commencement of this session and I take the point made about the objectivity of the matter, but it might be beneficial if this was put on the record. I therefore ask: is it appropriate that the amendment relating to research and development in the mining industry be retrospective to the commencement time of the research and development concession? The Minister may wish to take advice and respond accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I thank Senator Watson for his first remark. At this stage, I can only note it, take it on board and look at it subsequently. I think that is all he had in mind, and I will do that.

PARA.TAB: When summing up on the second reading, I responded to the point that Senator Watson is making about the retrospectivity with regard to research and development, and exploration. We dealt with it in some detail before the Committee; I do not want to do so again here. But, because it is our view that the change does not affect the rights and obligations of any taxpayer—it merely clarifies them—we believe that there is no problem with the date of operation.

The problem with retrospectivity arises when we retrospectively change any rights or obligations for a citizen or taxpayer. Our view is that that does not occur on this occasion. We think the Bill after its amendment will mean exactly the same as the Bill before its amendment—if Senator Watson does not mind my saying so, like the amendment we just carried to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I ask for clarification of that last point that Senator Watson raised. We did discuss it in the Committee, but I want to be absolutely sure that I understand it. Mr Chairman, as you are aware, the Committee had presented to it correspondence that some Committee members had received on this question of the R&D allowance. One of the points made in the correspondence which was discussed by the Committee was, to quote from one particular letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Some claims which are known to have been allowed as tax deductions will now have to be disallowed retrospectively by the Tax Commissioner.

I do not have the transcript in front of me, but my recollection is that the Minister or his officials said that they were not aware of that but that they would go and check it to see whether that was factually correct.

PARA.TAB: I think this is the point on which I have had oral advice today that, in fact, according to the Tax Office, there are no claims which are known to have been disallowed as tax deductions but will now have to be disallowed retrospectively. I just want confirmation that my understanding is correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Short, my advice is that there are no such claims. I will reiterate that because it exemplifies my point. No claims have been allowed which will have to be retrospectively disallowed as a result of the effect of this clause, and there should not be, given the explanation I have made. It is valid to say that, on the basis of a misunderstanding of the provision, there was a view that it meant something more than it did for a short while. I think the letter was generated by that. Nobody has come to me since the Committee and raised any concern. The officers have checked since the Committee in response to Senator Short's request and confirmed to me that advice.

—I will now turn briefly to section 159GZZZZE, which deals with certain allowable deductions. It is limited to deductions allowable under section 51(1), which deals with borrowing costs. SPEECH.PARA: POOLED DEVELOPMENT FUNDS BILL 1992
DEVELOPMENT ALLOWANCE AUTHORITY BILL 1992
