Bills (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 1 June, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss the Taxation Laws Amendment (Self Assessment) Bill 1992—a most important Bill as far as the taxpaying community of Australia is concerned and one that is well overdue.

PARA.TAB: Although consultation with the business sector and other relevant parts of the industry has been widespread—and I acknowledge the Government's willingness, and particularly that of the Taxation Office, to participate in extensive and widespread consultation—I am concerned that perhaps in the last couple of months the whole process has become rather concentrated and rushed. Today is but another example of that process being unduly rushed in that it has taken years to come to this conclusion, but the Senate has but one hour to debate fully some of the very important ramifications of this Bill.

It is indeed a milestone in our nation's taxation history and a milestone which will affect all taxpayers. I draw attention to the fact that this taxation Bill is under a guillotine of one hour. Seminars on this issue organised by the Taxation Office often run for one day, and even that is quite inadequate and insufficient to deal with it. Yet in this most important forum—or what should be the most important forum—the Parliament, the debate on this Bill is restricted to just one hour. I think that is a most unhappy situation.

I would like to emphasise that the Liberal-National Party coalition has been pressing on government the concept of an adequate legislative base for very many years. We do acknowledge the wide community consultation over the last three years. In particular, I would like to acknowledge the work of Mr D'Ascenzo from the Taxation Office who has just come into the chamber. I acknowledge his enthusiasm and help, both to the parliamentarians and to taxpayers generally. I think this is the sort of consultation that is certainly giving the Australian Taxation Office much greater public recognition.

This Bill is but a further stage in the implementation of the self-assessment scheme, where the onus is on the taxpayer to supply the correct information and to comply with the law in a very complex area of tax administration. The review of self-assessment was announced in December 1990 and the information on the proposed changes was released in August 1991. The amendments contained in this Bill are the result of that initial process.

The Bill will establish a system of public rulings by the Commissioner which will determine the Commissioner's position on a given arrangement or type of arrangement. In fact, private rulings may also be made in which a person may request the Commissioner's opinion on a matter before entering into an arrangement. I believe this is a major plus for taxpayers. Unlike the current rulings, I emphasise that the new public and private rulings will be binding on the Commissioner and, if followed, the taxpayer cannot be put in a worse position by a subsequent change in interpretation. I believe these measures will add a great deal of certainty to tax planning, and naturally the coalition welcomes this.

The range of penalties will be changed from the current position, where a 200 per cent penalty is usually available, to three main classes—25 per cent, 50 per cent and 75 per cent—depending on the intent of the person entering into the arrangement that gives rise to the penalty tax being payable. The Bill also covers the procedures for objections, payment of interest, elections and notifications.

However, there is one disturbing aspect of that rushed last couple of months, which is the fact that the contents of the Bill before the Senate today were widely distributed and debated before they were available to parliamentarians, and I believe that was unfortunate. I certainly think it was unintended and the fault lies not with the Tax Office but with the Government because this Bill should have been introduced a lot earlier. The presumption was that the Bill was available to parliamentarians when, in fact, it was not. So it is certainly no reflection on Mr D'Ascenzo or his staff who conducted those seminars in the belief that the Bill had been distributed. It is a matter that needs great care in the future because we may not necessarily be quite as lenient on other issues.

The Bill has also left untouched a number of other concerns. One concern which appears to have general consensus among industry is that of seeking private rulings during a tax audit. I raised this issue in the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration to which the Bills were referred. Again, I commend to listeners the Hansard of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration of 5 June this year. The tax officer in attendance at that Committee hearing stated, at page 74 of the Hansard:
Under the Bill, where the audit covers an issue on which the taxpayer wants a ruling, then we are asking the taxpayer to have that issue resolved through that audit process.

SPEECH.PARA: Industry has expressed the opinion that a person undergoing the audit should not be disadvantaged or unnecessarily deprived of any entitlement which he had prior to the commencement of the audit. A former member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and perhaps Australia's foremost tax authority, Peter Roach, the noted writer and participant in the priority task force on self-assessment at the invitation of the Tax Office, notes:

Another contention. . . was that it was undesirable, inefficient and unfair that the resolution of some point arising early in the audit which, by its resolution might greatly influence the course of the audit and which could be resolved by a ruling, undetermined. . . until the close of the audit. (page 18, Charter, June, 1992)

The Government should reconsider this matter, which was raised by Mr Roach in the Charter magazine, although I am pleased to note that during the Committee hearing on 5 June, Mr D'Ascenzo stated, at page 74 of the Hansard:
. . . if the taxpayer wanted to know something in the future that was not covered by the audit, then the taxpayer is fairly able to ask for the ruling in those circumstances.

It is important that that go on the record because it could be a supporting comment. Concern has also been raised by the industry that the Tax Office presently has a dual approach to the administration of part IVA, which contains the anti-avoidance provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This should really be reconsidered in the context of the current self-assessment legislation because the Tax Office is saying that the imposition of a high and relatively fixed culpability penalty is appropriate in circumstances where part IVA applies to cancel a tax benefit.

PARA.TAB: The reason for this, according to the Tax Office, is that part IVA is confined to blatant, artificial and contrived schemes which were prevalent in the 1970s and were referred to by the then Treasurer, Mr John Howard, in his second reading speech. There is concern by the industry that the sober and appropriately restrained approach referred to by Mr Howard in his speech for part IVA has been adopted temporarily and only at the level of interface between the ATO and the Parliament for the purpose of securing the passage of the self-assessment legislation. I realise this is a serious accusation but, unfortunately, it has been based on industry experience. Professional firms have found that at the branch level of the Tax Office, part IVA has been applied to circumstances which are no more than examples of legitimate income tax planning measures.

Comments that I have received from the industry are that it feels the actions of the branch office personnel in invoking part IVA cannot be dismissed as simply erroneous or overzealous attempts to apply official ATO policy. This comment is based on two reasons. First, despite the fact that part IVA was introduced over 10 years ago, the ATO has made no attempt to provide comprehensive guidelines as to how part IVA should be administered. Rather it is selectively referred to in an ad hoc way for various rulings and public statements. Having now established self-assessment in a legislative form, I call on the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) to give consideration to a ruling, which will now be a binding ruling, for the application of the general anti-avoidance provision of part IVA.

Secondly, in an Administrative Appeals Tribunal case decided in 1989, case W58, counsel for the Commissioner submitted that in interpreting part IVA it was not permissible to seek guidance from the explanatory memorandum or the speech made during the second reading debate by Mr Howard. This was a bit of a worry because when we sought confirmation about the status of the explanatory memorandum and the status of Tax Office deliberations at committee hearings, we were led to believe that they did have a certain status. In the context of self-assessment rules and the fixed culpability tariffs at 50 per cent and 25 per cent, there is an obligation on the Tax Office to issue a clear and comprehensive statement on part IVA, the anti-avoidance provision. Therefore, I ask the Government to agree to this request for a ruling.

Another contentious issue within the Bill is the question of defining the standard for what is a reasonably arguable position. Perhaps this is the most contentious aspect of the whole self-assessment legislation. The overall proposal is that, if all reasonable care has been taken and the tax avoided does not exceed $10,000 or a specified percentage of the taxable income—in other words the threshold test—there will be no culpability penalties. The new concept of a reasonably arguable position as a defence for a taxpayer getting his tax sums wrong is a fundamental protection for the taxpayer. While I have received very strong submissions that we should be amending this, there are equally good arguments on the other side. Under the circumstances the Opposition will not be seeking an amendment, but we believe we do need certain clarifications on this issue.

As these penalties of 25 per cent apply where reasonable care has been taken, it is important that the threshold be set at a respectable level. The provisions have been modelled on the US concepts. However, in broad terms the threshold in the United States is 10 times that set in Australia. This, together with the fact that the US penalty for underpayment of tax in these circumstances is only 20 per cent of the underpayment, the proposed Australian position can be seen to be substantially more stringent. There is no clear reason why the Australian tax officials need to be armed with a blunter instrument of enforcement than their US colleagues. Why are Australian taxpayers to be treated more harshly than taxpayers in the United States?
Again I come back to the oracle on tax issues, Peter Roach. He very clearly and succinctly states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the question that arises with the reasonably arguable position—
known as the RAP position—
can only be relevant to unsuccessful arguments...

I repeat, unsuccessful arguments, not successful ones. If the taxpayer's argument succeeds, there is no liability in tax. The question is: how good does an unsuccessful argument have to be to merit the description of being reasonably arguable? I refer those who are interested in following this concern to Peter Roach's article at page 18 of the Institute of Chartered Accountants' magazine, Charter, of June 1992. As a member of the priority task force in self-assessment and in contact with the industry tax professionals, he states:

A point well made by a number of commentators was that the higher the standard (ie the more difficult it is for taxpayers to succeed in their contention) the greater will be the resulting instance of requests for private rulings. The consequence will be a move away from self-assessment.

This is contrary to what we are arguing. Again, this concept of a reasonably arguable position will have the Government clawing concepts out of other jurisdictions, for example, the US revenue laws, but unfortunately applying harsher provisions without the hindsight or the experience of the overseas counterparts which may represent perhaps a more reasonable position. They may have been to the United States and the United States revenue authorities may feel that, in hindsight, their revenue laws have been a little harsh at 25 per cent rather than 20 per cent and in having a higher threshold before qualifying for this reasonably arguable position.

PARA.TAB: We have been advised that, provided that the Australian Taxation Office acts in good faith and with goodwill and commonsense, the reasonably arguable position is quite acceptable despite the fact—I must stress that this is a real worry in this concept—that we are not treating all taxpayers in the same way. I think this is unfortunate. Certain taxpayers have a stronger obligation in terms of reasonable care than others and I think that, based on an amount of money, this is an unfair criterion for distinction.

It has also been argued by one sector of the taxation industry that the phrase `reasonably arguable position' should be rejected and replaced by `reasonable care'. The concept of reasonable care comes up quite frequently. The reasonable care position is based on unfairness to the taxpayer and the tax agent. Many a taxpayer may not be in a position of being aware of all the circumstances relating to his or her case, which could be complicated by rebates and rulings in terms of when this threshold of $10,000 will apply.

Not all tax agents are as aware of all the information and rules as others. Further, the everyday taxpayer would not be as knowledgeable as tax lawyers or tax agents. However, I think it will be interesting when the Tax Office issues its first culpability penalty. That indeed will be the subject of a proliferation of articles in legal and tax agents' journals. That will expose this whole concept of the reasonableness of this position, about which we do have some doubt.

I must say that good arguments on both sides come to light. It is to be hoped that the Tax Office will adopt a reasonable approach, and that the sort of argument that John Howard put forward when he was first introducing part IVA provisions about 10 years ago will prevail. I believe that not only should the taxpayer, as the information paper of August 1991 states, `be acting in good faith', but also that the Australian Taxation Office itself will need to act in good faith. Because the system is so new, it is expected that there will be many defects in it. Therefore, in Peter Roach's words, the entire situation can be summed up by noting:

SPEECH.PARA: Once the new regime has been initiated it will then be important that high priority be given to monitoring the system, to engaging the full consultation with all those able and willing to make input; and doing so with a willingness on the part of the ATO to recognise the inadequacies and propose appropriate remedial action with as high priority given to effecting remedies as is being given to initiating the changes which will generate the need for those remedies.

In conclusion, I draw the Senate's attention to what I believe will be a proliferation of requests for rulings from the taxpaying community. I ask the Government to ensure that adequate resources are given to the Taxation Office so that taxpayers will not be disadvantaged by undue delay. I have drawn attention previously to what I regard as a very unfair system working in the Taxation Office, in terms of the quota of high level staff that it is permitted to employ under some union arrangements within the Public Service administration.

PARA.TAB: Given the fact that the Taxation Office will be required to shed staff as part of its modernisation program, given that it has to pay efficiency dividends and the like, there is the strong possibility that it could lose personnel at the technical level, particularly in the national office, where there is a need to strengthen the resources of the Taxation Office. This current lack of resources, amongst other things, has delayed the implementation of self-assessment and is further putting back the clock in terms of the ability of the Taxation Office to proceed with the simplification of income tax. Simplification of the income tax law must go hand in hand with this self-assessment process. Self-assessment is one step forward.

So again I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to review the quota arrangements. I know the Parliamentary Secretary has global budgets for wages and expenses, and there is certain interchange between the two, but there are definite problems in the technical categories, level A and the Senior Executive Service where restrictions are imposed on Mr Boucher in terms of his ability to recruit high level staff to cope with an increasing area of complexity in tax administration. I make this final appeal to the Parliamentary Secretary for the need to issue rulings in the light of self-assessment in terms of the application of part IVA of the general anti-avoidance provisions. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some things that I want to say, and say rather forcefully. I am afraid my voice is not going to be as strong as the points I want to make. Nonetheless, I shall persevere because they need to be put on the record.

PARA.TAB: A graphic illustration of the complexity of the law that we are dealing with is the fact that the Act itself is only some 68 pages long. The explanatory memorandum is 142 pages long. The explanatory memorandum, in itself, leaves a lot to be desired in that it shows very simply how harsh many of these provisions will be on the taxpayer.

There is a general feeling in the community and that feeling has been reinforced by the amount of mail I have received since I drew the attention of the Senate to the fact that we have on the public record evidence of the uneven-handed dealing of Mr Keating on the one hand, who received a polite note, `Please put in your tax return', and Mr Phillip Smiles on the other hand who has been prosecuted under the Crimes Act. We have been told that there is no other precedent for prosecuting under the Crimes Act on a matter of apportionment.

I might say at this point that I am doubly angry because I have just received a letter from the DPP which I can only say, upon reading, I consider to be an attempt to be intimidatory. I have considered whether or not it is a breach of privilege as, in my view, it attempts to impede my actions as a senator carrying out my proper duties. Nonetheless, I will simply read that letter further and decide what to do about it. However, I will say this: it is a matter of public importance to know how the Tax Office, and the Taxation Commissioner in particular, make decisions and why it is that we have on the public record the fact that Mr Keating was treated in such a friendly and nice way when he was Mr Boucher's boss, yet Mr Smiles has been treated in a way whereby, if the Commissioner is successful, it will bring down the Greiner Government. I find that quite unacceptable.
Senator Watson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague, Senator Watson points out, the Government wins either way. The sort of legal expenditure it has forced Mr Smiles to incur is just outrageous.

PARA.TAB: When I look at these provisions, I see that we are again considering the process of strict liability, with the imposition of the self-assessment scheme on top of the old legal framework which was designed to have a person put in his return for it to be considered and an assessment issued. As honourable senators are fully aware, under the self-assessment system, once the return goes in, that becomes the assessment.

I would describe the penalties system which is to be put in place as harsh, if not unconscionable. I direct the Minister's attention to an excellent article written by Professor Bob Baxt which he published in the Australian Financial Review. His final comments were:

SPEECH.PARA: Genuine and well thought out business decisions, based on sound advice received from tax practitioners given with reasonable care, should not be subject to a 25 per cent penalty.

I think that is a very reasonable statement. There are lovely little graphs in the explanatory memorandum. The test that is first to be applied if there is a tax shortfall is: did the taxpayer take reasonable care? What is the test and how is that test to be applied? The second test to be applied is: is the taxpayer's position reasonably arguable? The explanatory memorandum sets out the sorts of things that may be considered in determining, in a very subjective view, whether or not the taxpayer's position is reasonably arguable. Those things include virtually anything and everything that is said in this Parliament, previous rulings that have been made and future rulings that will be made. But the one thing that may not be considered is the opinion that the taxpayer may produce that has come from tax experts or senior counsel who have practised for years in the field. That is the sort of advice which this system says the taxpayer may not rely upon.

PARA.TAB: My colleague Senator Watson has pointed out that there will be a much greater requirement for both public and private rulings to be made, but particularly private rulings. We do not know whether or not the Tax Office is geared to handle this. As I have said personally to Mr Boucher—and I will say it again now—there are too many examples of officers in the Tax Office giving wrong advice. His response to me when I said it last was, `You give right advice, too'. My response to that is, `Near enough is not good enough'. We should be able to expect that right advice is always given, and it is not.

We have just been through a farcical situation in dealing with the modernisation program of the Tax Office, where $1.2 billion of taxpayers' money has been spent to buy hardware and software and to supposedly `modernise' its system of operation. The Auditor-General has been extraordinarily harsh in his criticism of the way that records are being kept in the Tax Office—just criticism.

This modernisation program was undertaken on the basis that an efficiency dividend would be declared; in other words, that the taxpayer ought to be paying out less for the administration of the Act. When we visited the national office, we found out that it will take 1,000 fewer officers to collect the revenue; that is, 1,000 officers will be surplus to requirements. But those officers will not be leaving the Tax Office, because there is a nice cosy arrangement with the unions that nobody actually loses his or her job. It was relying on natural attrition which was, prior to the recession we had to have, running at somewhere between 8 and 9 per cent. But we are in a recession, and it is now running at 3 per cent. Where is the adjustment? There is not one.

Where are these 900 to 1,000 people going? Quite a lot of them—surprise, surprise—are going in to do a PR job to make the people think more kindly of the Tax Office. We are not taxpayers any more; we are told that we are clients. The word `client' to me indicates that we have an opportunity to choose. There are many taxpayers who, given the opportunity to choose another Commissioner of Taxation, would do so. There is no choice. We are not clients; we are taxpayers, and we are at the mercy of the discretion of the Tax Office.

My colleague Senator Watson has very well outlined the problems in invoking the provisions of part IVA. Indeed, someone who felt very strongly on this issue expressed those feelings by saying that, in the sales tax assessment Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is currently rushing through Parliament, the Keating Government is attempting to give Trevor Boucher legal powers exceeding that of God. Under section 92(2) of the proposed Act, Trevor Boucher will have the power to change the past: which theologians agree, even God cannot do.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said `sales tax'.

—I beg your pardon. I do not mean sales tax. Perhaps I am preoccupied with the next debate that is to come on yet again. I am talking about the provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Self Assessment) Bill. I thank Senator Kernot for that.
—Same principles.

—One could say that. Another interesting statistic on that matter is that I understand we still have 740 public servants administering the 70,000 people who pay sales tax, but we will wait for debate on that Bill before I go further.

PARA.TAB: This person who was so incensed at this provision describes this power in the following way:

SPEECH.PARA: This is arbitrary Executive power at its most outrageous: a complete and utter denial of the rule of law. Indeed, this outrageous provision will enable the Tax Commissioner to tax transactions which never actually took place.

A whole lot of other fairly devastating comments were made on the proposed legislation. The provisions that will invoke these two tests and the standards that have to be applied are, indeed, harsh. If we look at the new provisions to introduce binding rulings, we find that many questions are raised rather than answered. One asks oneself, in relation to a private ruling, what sort of test the Commissioner is going to use in determining whether or not there is a material difference between one case and the next.

PARA.TAB: One asks oneself whether that will become a known guideline and whether it will be forced to be applied. There are so many grey areas that one cannot simply say that we are moving to a situation where the law is to become more certain. I refer the Senate again to the excellent article of Professor Baxt which sets out very clearly the impediments to taxpayers that are still within the legislation and will cause hardship to taxpayers.

I said that I thought that my voice may not last my sense of indignation and I am afraid that is going to be prove to be true. I am sure that there will be many more debates and discussions on things that will flow from this legislation. One thing that I do believe is important is that, with regard to taxation laws and the administration of the tax laws, there must be confidence within the Australian people not only that things are done properly but also that things appear to be done properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment (Self Assessment) Bill of 1992. This is the Bill that the coalition raised with the Government as soon as self-assessment was introduced. I do not quite remember when self-assessment was introduced, but it was quite a few years ago because I can remember former Senator Stone, as well as myself, commenting at the time that the horrendous legislation gave the taxpayer no protection whatsoever. We pointed out time and again that, with self-assessment, there were no private rulings. I do not know whether there were public rulings at the time, but there were definitely no private rulings. It was far too grey an area. I remember former Senator Stone at the time making a very big point about that.

PARA.TAB: This system of self-assessment without private rulings led to many taxpayers paying too much tax. To prevent penalties, they had to err against themselves. The Senate does not have to take my word for that; it can take the word of those in the accounting profession around Australia which, if I may say, is a very noble profession. I believe that it is the right of all taxpayers to pay only the tax that is justifiably due and no more. As a result of the grey areas, they should leave a margin for error so that they do not fall into the net of the Commissioner of Taxation.

There has been uncertainty on top of uncertainty. The Commissioner was definitely collecting too much tax. With this new system, at least we will be able to get private rulings. Through this legislation, taxpayers will be able to obtain private rulings if they are entering into a new business arrangement, partnership or company. I commend the legislation for making that ruling available. Providing that one abides by the ruling, one is pretty safe.

There will also be new public rulings, which probably will give a person a good guide as to what to do with their accountant and taxation lawyer. It can give a person a good idea of where he is going, but I believe that the only way to put a person in a safe position is by a private ruling on new business. I understand that both the Commissioner and the taxpayer will have to stick to this Bill. I am also happy to see that there are reviewable private rulings in the legislation by which, if a person believes that the Commissioner's ruling is not correct, they can have the ruling reviewed. I am happy to see that in the legislation.

I am also happy to see in the legislation that objections against assessments can be lodged up to four years after the assessment is done. If my figures are right, the Commissioner is able to object to or reassess an assessment up to four years after the initial assessment. I presume that is correct, provided there has been full disclosure. I believe beyond that that things are different. So I commend the Government for bringing this into the legislation.

I want to leave a bit of time for Senator Kernot to contribute to the debate, but I must mention briefly that the legislation introduces a new system of penalties for understatement of income tax liability. The liabilities will be based on the requirement that taxpayers exercise reasonable care in carrying out their tax obligations. A more rigorous standard, the reasonably arguable position test, will apply to items which affect tax by more than $10,000.

Senator Bishop asked what is a reasonably arguable position. I believe that if a taxpayer does not have a reasonably arguable position the book should be thrown at him. I presume that if a taxpayer has a reasonably arguable position he will go into a scheme with the best advice. So, if a taxpayer receives good advice and can document this advice from a reputable professional person, why should there be a penalty?

Moving on to the penalties, on reading the schedule of penalty rates I found that they are quite horrendous and also leave quite a few grey areas. I will just run down the summary of rates of penalty. I have no argument with `deliberate evasion' which has a penalty rate of 75 per cent—then there are decreases and increases and that sort of thing. `Recklessness' has a penalty rate of 50 per cent. `Tax avoidance profit shifting' has a penalty rate of 50 per cent. `No reasonable care' has a penalty rate of 25 per cent. Where is the fine line between `recklessness' and `no reasonable care'? I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to tell me that in his summing up. `Private ruling disregarded' has a penalty rate of 25 per cent. I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to tell me why that is 25 per cent. I believe that if a private ruling is disregarded it is far worse than having no reasonably arguable position and taking no reasonable care. Then the schedule refers to hindrances to disclosure, which I suppose is fair enough. I just cannot understand that summary, and I would like the Parliamentary Secretary to comment on the issues that I have raised. I believe the schedule leaves far too many grey areas, though they are less grey than before.
I know that time is running out and we have to get this Bill out of the road, so in conclusion I want to refer to consultation. The Parliamentary Secretary's second reading speech stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In determining the final form of the changes the Government, through the ATO, has consulted extensively with taxpayer and tax professional representative bodies.

We have been telling the Government that. If I had had time tonight—I did not think the debate was coming on so early—I would have brought second reading debates with me from about three or four years ago, I think 1988. Not only I but also Senator Short and former Senator Stone told the Government that at that time but it took no notice. Now the Government tells us that it has had a heap of consultation. The Government ought to take a bit more notice of the things that we say on this side of the House.

PARA.TAB: Before I conclude, I apologise to Senator Kernot if I offended her in what I said earlier about her not being here to speak. But, by the same token, if I am on the speakers list and decide not to speak, I generally send a message down so that the next speaker can be ready.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will resist from responding. The Taxation Laws Amendment (Self Assessment) Bill proposes to revolutionise and rationalise the system of penalties and rulings and the objection and amendment processes. Rising to Senator Panizza's challenge, I intend to be extremely brief in my comments. The Government has consulted widely on this. There have been a number of press releases and an information paper. The issues have been canvassed in great detail. The Australian Democrats support the legislation because it generally grants benefits to taxpayers. In particular, I commend the Government for finally introducing the concept of—
—You supported no private rulings, too.

—I think Senator Panizza has misunderstood what I have said. I commend the Government for finally introducing the concept of legally binding rulings, both public and private. This is a long overdue step, and I acknowledge that I understand that it is a very major step for a government to take. The current situation is that rulings are an indication of the practice of the Commissioner of Taxation, except in some celebrated circumstances such as in respect of the Adelaide Steamship Co., but they do not have any legal effect. This meant that the Australian Taxation Office would give a ruling on a matter, often of great complexity and importance to the viability of a particular project, but with a caveat that the ruling was legally useless. This contributed to business uncertainty. This legislation will introduce the concept of legally binding rulings, both public and private, which will greatly assist in projects requiring certainty in taxation matters. This is particularly opportune at a time of low economic activity.

PARA.TAB: There are also some radical changes in respect of the length of time in which taxpayers will be able to lodge objections to taxation assessments. There is a complete rewrite of the amendment provisions. We think that taxpayers will be generally advantaged by the new system of penalties, in particular the allowance of a tax deduction for interest charged on underpayments and late payments. The non-deductibility of these interest penalties, which has existed at the same time as payments made by the Commissioner to a taxpayer have been taxable, has been a matter for resentment by taxpayers for many years. I commend the Government for finally addressing this running sore.

As Senator Watson has said, this legislation is the continuation of the process of self-assessment which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) initiated during his time as Treasurer. The general policy is one of accepting the claims of taxpayers and redirecting resources to the audit function. The Democrats support such a policy and we think it has resulted in a large amount of revenue being raised from the auditing of big business. But I acknowledge to Senator Panizza that there are risks in such a strategy as the recent debate within the Taxation Office, which was leaked to the public, has highlighted. Some senior taxation officials expressed concern, I understand, about a possible overclaiming of refunds of several hundred million dollars because returns are not being assessed in the old manner. I do not know the current status of this concern. No doubt there are some people who cheat on their tax responsibilities; but there are very administrative savings from this system.

The Commissioner of Taxation stated in a speech to the Taxation Institute of Australia on 30 May this year that he would need an extra 13,400 employees to undertake the tasks that were formerly performed in the assessment stage. So in this Bill we have made a choice between those numbers and improved auditing resources. With good timing, I commend this Bill to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I share with Senator Watson and some other senators the view that what we have here is a milestone piece of legislation and I want to join with him also in thanking in particular the staff who have been involved in its development—those who are present here and those who have worked with them. I ask those present here to convey the thanks of the whole Parliament to their colleagues for their very industrious and competent work which has led us to be able to implement this milestone.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its cooperation in this matter. The second group of people I would like to thank comprises those involved in the extensive consultative process. On some occasions I had the opportunity to meet with those people briefly. There were many senior people from the private sector and tax officers from the academic community who gave a large amount of their time voluntarily to assist in the development of this legislation. At the end of the day some of those liked the outcome, some did not. That is not the point; the point is that I appreciate, as does the Government and, I am sure, the whole Parliament, the effort which those individuals made to improve this piece of legislation and the nation's tax system.

PARA.TAB: Milestone as it is, I think the most important thing to recognise in the brief time available—there are many things I would like to say about the detail of the Bill; but I will not do that as they have been said in the speeches at the second reading stage and it would be a waste of time—is that this system is inevitable in any event. There is no way we could have continued to run the growing tax system under the mechanisms imposed by the previous legislation. In fact, we are not. It is simply that this Bill enables a proper legislative framework within which the inevitable and desirable self-assessment process might operate.

Notwithstanding the comments of some honourable senators—I think most were positive and constructive—I do think this legislation goes a long way to providing the level of certainty which is important to taxpayers in any environment, but it is particularly relevant in a self-assessment environment. I do not have the time to make much of a discourse upon Senator Bishop's vindictive little vignette; however, it is worth while noting that in the middle of a recession one of her criticisms was that the Government was not prepared to sack 1,000 people. I have to say: we are not.

I share the view expressed by Senator Panizza that under this system, as under any other, the taxpayer should be obliged to pay only that which the tax laws require, and no more. I would put it in the more conventional sense: they should pay no more and no less. I am not implying that he suggested anything other than that, but that is the format in which I would express it. I do think that is an important point, and I do not disagree.

Mr Deputy President, I apologise. At the beginning of my remarks I should have tabled a letter from me to Senator Coates, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which relates to a matter raised with me at the Committee meeting, and I do so now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it might have been an Evans letter.

—No. In the fine print it may say what a good person I am; but it probably does not because I signed it. Before we conclude, I want to make a couple of other comments in response to a concern about the threshold that is set in this legislation. On the face of it, it can cause some concern. I draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that that threshold was settled through the process of consultation and it does exclude the vast majority of cases. That is what it is intended to do, and that is what it does. While all honourable senators broadly supported the legislation—I thank them for that—it is important that we get this Bill passed. I thank the Senate for its cooperation in enabling us to do that this evening. I thank the Senate for its support, and I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I challenge the view that the position of the Australian Taxation Office is superior to that of outside experts. Perhaps that issue can be acknowledged in the evaluation that I understand will take place later this year about the immediate implication of self-assessment.

PARA.TAB: I have a number of concerns. The Commissioner of Taxation is empowered to withdraw a private ruling without the consent of the rulee, even if the arrangement subject to the ruling has begun to be carried out where great disadvantage to a third party is likely to follow. I refer particularly to proposed new section 14ZAU(2)(b)(i), which refers to another person who will be disadvantaged if the ruling is not withdrawn. There is no guidance in the explanatory memorandum as to the type of person who might suffer detriment as a result of the private ruling having been given to the rulee. For example, can the Treasurer be another person for that purpose?

For the purpose of the record, I might go through each of my questions because, if we do not have time, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) may have to take them on notice. We only have four minutes left for this debate and I have four more questions. There should be guidance in terms of the meaning of proposed new section 14ZAX. This relates to the effect of the withdrawal of a ruling deemed never to have been made. Can we have either an explanation or a ruling on that? I have a problem with page 5 of the explanatory memorandum, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner is obliged to amend the taxpayer's assessment where the Commission is satisfied that the amendment is necessary to reflect the correct tax.

While true from one perspective, this statement is at odds with section 170, which states, in express terms, that the Commissioner is merely empowered to amend; he is not obliged to do so. We have something of a conflict there. Finally, under proposed new section 14ZAN, the Commissioner does not have to deal with certain applications for private rulings. Proposed new section 14ZAN(d) deals with an application for a private ruling where a tax audit is being carried out. If a tax audit into a taxpayer's affairs does not cover a given year—for example, a year of income that has not yet commenced—being the year of income to which the application for a private ruling relates, then the application should be considered. Accordingly, it could be necessary to reword paragraph (d). I ask the Tax Office to look at that. I have a form of words, but I believe that the time for this debate has now expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not quite expired but it has so nearly expired that all I will say is that I note the four points that Senator Watson raised. I will pick them up from the Hansard. I will take what he is recorded as having said in Hansard with any additional information he wants to give me and get him an answer as soon as I can.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly this evening on the Audit Report No. 41, tabled in the Senate today. This report is the project audit of the disability services program, concentrating on employment grants, community participation grants and protective security. This report is timely, given that the Government is in the midst of amending the Disability Services Act to extend the transition period for prescribed services, and drafting guidelines for the administration of funding under the Disability Services Act as well as national standards which will apply to all services in receipt of funding under the Disability Services Act.

PARA.TAB: This report provides the Senate with an insight into the administrative difficulties entailed in implementing the Disability Services Act. Since its inception five years ago the Act has remained totally bereft of section 5 guidelines and concrete national standards for service providers.
The project audit of the employment subprogram conducted by the Audit Office sought to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . assess the effectiveness of the systems and procedures used by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services to fulfil the requirements of the Disability Services Act. In particular, the audit focused on the adequacy of monitoring procedures and reporting requirements, including performance indicators and outcome standards, as well as the adequacy of departmental procedures and control over the payment and acquittal of grants.

The Australian National Audit Office has concluded that aspects of the administration of employment grants could be improved in a number of respects, particularly the procedures for determining whether grant recipients are meeting legislative requirements of the Disability Services Act. This is hardly surprising in the light of the fact that there are still no guidelines, despite the fact that the coalition has been calling for them for many years. In addition, given the ongoing confusion that has characterised the transition phase of this Act, I am sure that the vast majority of service providers, consumers, parents and advocates to whom I have spoken would wholeheartedly agree with the conclusion of the Audit Office.

PARA.TAB: I will turn to a number of the specific findings of the Audit Office in relation to the disability services program. In terms of the Department's efforts to attract appropriate applications from service providers, the ANAO found that grant recipients consisted mainly of groups with an historical association with the Department and questioned the manner in which the Department stimulated innovation and the establishment of new services, which is a key aspect of the Disability Services Act.

This is a telling remark from the Auditor-General considering that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) and the Department have long placed the blame for a lack of innovation and forward thinking on the service providers, particularly sheltered workshops. I have moved around sheltered workshops in a number of States. The complaint and concern expressed to me by the providers of those services is that they are the ones who have always been apportioned the blame.

Secondly, page 6 of the Audit Office report states that a number of the applications for funding support showed no indication of `adequate information gathered to establish eligibility, application and agreement forms, and grant approvals'. Such sloppy paperwork is totally unacceptable. I am sure that service providers who are forever complaining about the mountain of paperwork received from the Department would be aghast at this finding.

Thirdly, and directly related to the need for national standards, the Auditor found instances where agreed outcomes were generic and not sufficiently specific, and where outcomes were expressed in terms of desirable goals rather than definite outcomes as required by the Disability Services Act.

Again, the major concern expressed to me by employment services providers has been that they are never certain whether they are complying with the requirements of the Act and the Department during the transition phase. Time and time again, I have been told that the goal posts have been moved without due consultation and good reason. The introduction of minimum enhanced and eligibility outcomes cannot come quickly enough for the majority of service providers.
Fourthly, and directly related to the need for the national standards, is the Auditor-General's recommendation on page 8 that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . assessment guidelines and written administrative procedures be developed to facilitate and standardise the assessment of the extent to which organisations are meeting the objectives of the Disabilities Services legislation.

This recommendation was made in light of the fact that there were no guidelines whatsoever to indicate how reviewers from the Department would undertake evaluations of the various activities and achievements of the recipient organisations. Hopefully, this totally unacceptable situation will change with the formulation and implementation of the guidelines and standards.

PARA.TAB: However, the Auditor-General's report and findings again highlight the environment of uncertainty and the administrative laxity in which the disabilities sector has been forced to operate since the enactment of the Disability Services Act—and this is a long time during which these service providers have been operating under a great deal of stress in the recession we had to have which Keating gave us, trying to find—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Patterson, you should use the proper form of address.
—I am sorry, Mr Deputy President.
—I may have misunderstood you.

—Mr Deputy President, I do not know in what way I offended the Chair but, if I used the wrong form of address, I apologise. I might have said `Keating' instead of `Mr Keating'. I am very sorry—the recession that Mr Keating said we had to have. These service providers have been operating, trying to find contract work for the workers in the sheltered workshops to undertake, and that has been a challenge for them. They have been trying to do that in this environment of uncertainty and administrative laxity.

PARA.TAB: Much has been said both inside and outside the Parliament about the difficulties entailed in meeting the transition phase by 30 June 1992. Last November the Minister recognised that this deadline was totally unachievable due to the vast majority of services not being able to meet the criteria of the Act. He announced that there would be continued funding for services which have achieved certain specified minimum standards of service provision.

The Auditor-General has found that reviews of employment services in relation to their fulfilling the transitional arrangements of the Act were backlogged in each of four States in which his audit was conducted. He quite rightly expressed concern that services are not being satisfactorily investigated and evaluated in relation to their achievement of the eligibility criteria required for continued funding subsequent to the transition phase. That is also a very telling finding from the Auditor-General as the Government has claimed that the reasons for the extension of the transition phase related to the minuscule number of services which have achieved eligibility status. What is being said is that we are going to have to extend the date because only a minuscule number of groups and organisations have achieved the standards. But the Auditor-General's reporting gives us to understand that the whole story was not told because the finding begs the question: is the extension of the transition phase due solely to the reasons put forward by the Government, or is it in fact that many services have actually complied with the Act but have simply not been properly evaluated by the Department?

In the four States the Auditor-General looked at, there was a backlog. So on one hand the Government says, `We need to extend this because there has been only a minuscule number who have reached the standards', but on the other hand the Auditor-General is telling us that we have a backlog of organisations that have not been evaluated.

Finally, the Audit Office noted that the DISCUS database, which has been established to record details of grant recipients together with financial information and data needed for the administration of the program, was deficient in a wide range of areas. I will list them because they are valuable. They include: errors in database information; inadequate recording or manual grant payments; no controls to detect or prevent duplicate payments of grants; the process of reconciling financial information in DISCUS with the financial ledger system is difficult and complicated; ongoing formal training for users of DISCUS as well as those responsible for input does not appear to be adequate; and, finally, the DISCUS system was inadequate in terms of detailing the achievement of outcomes and the undertaking of inspections.

In recognition of the importance of Disability Services Act guidelines and national standards, the coalition will move amendments in the Senate to the Health, Housing and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill to ensure that these standards and guidelines are given appropriate parliamentary scrutiny. At this time, negotiations are proceeding in relation to whether these guidelines and national standards should be amendable by the Federal Parliament, as has been proposed by the coalition. If ever there was evidence that these important standards and guidelines require the most careful and proper parliamentary scrutiny, this report is that evidence. We should not have a situation where the providers of those services are left with any uncertainty about what is required of them under the Disability Services Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The largest international event ever held in the Northern Territory took place in April this year when Darwin hosted the fourth Pacific School Games. The games were an outstanding success, and I would like to record my appreciation to all those who organised and participated in this great supporting event as well as to more than 1,000 local families who billeted young athletes and the many hundreds of Darwin citizens who gave of their time voluntarily to assist in the organisation.

PARA.TAB: Launched in 1982, the Pacific School Games were first held as a lead-up to the Brisbane Commonwealth Games, with competitors coming from as far afield as Fiji, Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands and, of course, the Northern Territory. The event was a rousing success, prompting Victoria to pick up the Games for its 150th birthday celebrations in 1984. In 1988, Sydney marked its bicentennial year with a similar display of sport and sportsmanship. The fourth Pacific School Games in Darwin this year attracted 1,934 competitors from countries around the world, including the People's Republic of China, Russia, Thailand, Vanuatu, Canada, Hong Kong, Fiji and Japan.

As the shadow Minister for community services, I am pleased to report that disabled athletes participated in the 1988 Games and again in Darwin this year. For example, in the athletics arena, 39 people with intellectual disabilities competed, 15 were visually impaired and 10 were wheelchair athletes. Similarly, in swimming, 31 were intellectually disabled, four were visually impaired and 14 were wheelchair competitors.

The Pacific School Games aim to give students who excel in athletics, gymnastics and swimming the opportunity to develop their skills in the international arena. The significance of the Games for the Northern Territory was best summed up by the Northern Territory Minister for Education, the Hon. Shane Stone, when he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: In many ways the 1992 games are a celebration of the achievements of Territorians as we grow toward Statehood and an increasingly important role in the Asia Pacific region.
It is especially fitting that these games, the biggest sporting event seen in Territory history, should focus on children and young adults in education.
Darwin prides itself as a multicultural city close to the hub of Asia and over the years, our school students have played leading roles in developing close ties with our near neighbours.

I certainly acknowledge the important leadership given to the Pacific School Games this year by the Northern Territory Government under the very generous and special assistance of the Minister for Education, the Hon. Shane Stone. As I said in my initial remarks, I also acknowledge the contribution of thousands of Northern Territory families who acted as hosts, volunteer officials and transport and other support agencies. This was an important contribution.

PARA.TAB: I also acknowledge that the management of any event like this draws on the skills of particular individuals. I pay credit to the hours of work and the services of the executive management committee—in particular, the Chairman, Brian Deslandes; the Vice-Chairmen, Russell Totham and Brian Chase; the General Manager, Les Rauert; the Assistant General Manager, Helen Taylor; and the Administration Manager, Dean Dempsey. Of course, these people were assisted by 20 members of an important portfolio-related board of management.

In addition, major contributions were made by way of sponsorship and special acknowledgments. I note from the various programs and reports of the Pacific School Games that over 40 companies provided, in one way or another, active and financial sponsorship. Of course, this includes the important primary sponsorship of Colgate-Palmolive, which gave over $250,000. With the acknowledgments of all the various agencies, government departments and organisations, a total of some 60 groups made a major contribution.

As I have said, this was an important event. I seek leave to table the various souvenir programs, handbooks and pictorial souvenirs of the Games, together with a statistical summary of the various sports and State and country contributions.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be as quick as I can. It is the second time in five years that I have used the opportunity to speak during the adjournment debate, but because we are getting close to the end of the session I would like to put a few remarks on the record.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators would be aware that on previous occasions in this place and during the Senate Estimates committee process I have raised a number of concerns regarding the proposal by the Attorney-General's Department to introduce a law enforcement access network, commonly known as LEAN. LEAN will provide the Attorney-General's Department and a number of other Commonwealth and State government departments with access to data concerning property ownership and company involvement of individuals throughout the community.

Whilst it is readily acknowledged that this information is already publicly available, this is the first time that the opportunity will present itself to, first of all, match this information; and, secondly, gain such ready access to it. Understandably, many people in the community are concerned about the privacy implications of the LEAN proposal and, with this in mind, I believe it is appropriate that I bring the Senate up to date with details that have come to my attention recently.

I am somewhat disappointed that I have as yet been unable to obtain any estimate as to the likely cost of the system. Officers from the Attorney-General's Department indicated to my office that they were reluctant to provide this information because the provision of the expensive computers necessary to run the program is currently the subject of a tender process. Whilst I appreciate that it would be unwise to prejudice the tender process, I trust that the Government will appreciate that it is very difficult for those of us on this side of the House to make some preliminary judgments about the system when we simply do not know how much it will cost.

On the more positive side, I am pleased that the general estimate of the number of terminals appears to have been over-exaggerated during Senate Estimates, when a figure of something like 10,000 terminals was touted. However, it appears that a more reasonable estimate is something like 2,000 terminals. I am aware also that the whole subject of LEAN has been a matter of negotiation between the Attorney-General's Department and the Privacy Commissioner.

Honourable senators would appreciate that the LEAN system opens up the prospect of speculative data matching. Naturally, this causes concern for the Privacy Commissioner. Essentially, speculative matching would be simple random matching, which means that it could be possible for individuals who were not under investigation at all to come under scrutiny. LEAN opens the whole issue of re-use of publicly collected data for intentions other than the original use for which it was provided.

As a parliament, I believe we need to ask ourselves the question as to whether publicly available information should be made accessible for a purpose other than that for which it was originally collected. Surely individuals have a right to know the full extent of how information which they provide on themselves willingly for one purpose may be used for another purpose. This is an area of the Privacy Act which requires reassessment by the Government.

Another area where the Privacy Act is inadequate in relation to LEAN is that State police forces and State tax offices who will have access to the LEAN information on individuals may not in fact be strictly bound by the Privacy Act. Although the participating State authorities will be required to sign a memorandum of understanding regarding the use and access of LEAN information, they nevertheless will not be strictly bound by the Act, and here again there is the potential for misuse. There is also the potential which will exist for departments, such as the Department of Social Security, to pull together information from their own sources and also from the LEAN network to create huge databases on individuals. Again it is a matter which needs to be clarified.

I understand that the Attorney-General's Department and the Privacy Commissioner are yet to reach full agreement on a number of the issues which I have previously outlined tonight. I also believe that the Attorney-General's Department is yet to give an unequivocal assurance that the Privacy Commissioner's proposed data matching guidelines will be fully applied to LEAN. I have had the opportunity of discussing this issue with Senator Tate and he has undertaken to get back to me on the matters which I have raised. I think he is also aware of my private concerns relating to one or two matters I have raised with him about the misuse of information.

I look forward to receiving a copy of a letter sent to the Attorney-General by the Privacy Commissioner which covered his concerns. Senator Tate has said that he will get that to me when he can. I certainly urge the Government to immediately enter into consultation with the Privacy Commissioner so that amendments to the Privacy Act covering the concerns I have raised tonight can be drafted in the near future. It is evident that, as technology advances at such a rapid rate, instances will or may occur which will be outside the original umbrella of the Privacy Act. These should be the subject of public scrutiny by the Parliament.

In closing, I thank the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, Mr Peter Roberts and Mr Garry Ryle of the Attorney-General's Department in Canberra, and the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, and his staff for the courteous assistance they have provided my office to this date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much criticism is directed against unions. Too often it is unfair, unbalanced and defamatory of a great many workers. Critics condemn employees and their organisations for seeking better conditions, for fighting to preserve their rights, for striving to keep their unions strong. Rebukers paint workers as greedy, irresponsible and aggressive. Unions are regularly blamed for industrial disputes. Those who make these accusations generate much ill-will towards a great many honourable men and women. They cause authorities charged with the keeping of law and order to misdirect their endeavours. They help create an industrial culture where workers become scapegoats, where people are wrongly charged with offences, where witnesses are persuaded to give false evidence.

PARA.TAB: Matters to do with the Camperdown abattoir in Victoria supply a most unhappy example of what I am saying. Members of a picket line established outside those works were treated quite outrageously. They were subjected to the terror of facing a criminal court; they were reviled and denigrated; they were made to suffer for actions of which they were innocent. Camperdown is in the western part of Victoria. Police there were used by others for perverted purposes, and I use the adjective advisedly. There was an attempt to pervert the machinery of the law. An article headed `Police Anger', published in the Warrnambool Standard on 30 May 1992 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Western District's highest-ranking policeman yesterday said that witnesses in court cases against Camperdown abattoir picketers had `used' the police.
The article continues:

PARA.TAB: Asked whether he—

SPEECH.PARA: that is the superintendent, Mr Neil Patterson—
had any regrets about the outcome of the earlier cases—
they are talking about court cases here—
and the decision to withdraw unheard charges, Mr Patterson said: "I wish the whole thing had never happened.

PARA.TAB: "We felt as though we were used in some ways.
"We got bad publicity and we were not the instigators in most of the matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —The same as at APPM in Burnie.

—As Senator Tate has said, it is reminiscent of the sorts of things that happened at APPM in Burnie. Charges laid against members of the picket line at the Camperdown abattoirs failed to lead to the conviction of any. Six of the cases were dismissed with costs of over $18,000 awarded against the police. The rest were withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: People charged with offences must be happy when they are dismissed, but that does not save them from the anxiety and the distress brought to them by the service of information on them. Why were the picketers and the police used in this way? Who sought to employ the anti-union, anti-worker culture in some parts of society as a vehicle to gain some advantage for themselves? The resolution of those questions appears to be a sad and alarming one.

The picket line was legal and its members had every right to be where they were. It was established by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, a duly registered organisation under the Industrial Relations Act. Its purpose was to protest against the use by the abattoirs of contract labour supplied by Troubleshooters Available. The abattoirs was run by a company called Famicorp Pty Ltd. The person who controlled it was a Mr Farouk Fami. A firm of solicitors, namely Kroger and Kroger, was instructed to act on behalf of the corporation. A Mr Warwick Leeson, who described himself as a private inquiry agent, was in turn engaged by or through the lawyers to work at the Camperdown Meat Works on behalf of their client.

The first of the picketers brought before the court was Shane Francis Reilly. He was charged with hindering police. Mr Leeson, a Constable Bowman and an Inspector Meehan gave evidence against him. A film of the event involved showed their testimony to be false. The case was dismissed with costs against the police.

Matters worthy of profound concern arose during the cross-examination of Mr Leeson. It appears he was sent to Camperdown to gather evidence for use against the picketers and the union in legal proceedings along the lines of Mudginberri or Dollar Sweets, as he himself said. It was suggested in cross-examination of Mr Leeson that he was to provoke the picketers into action which would then form the basis for such proceedings. He denied this, but his testimony supports the validity of that suggestion.
Mr Monti, who appeared for Mr Reilly, asked Mr Leeson the following questions:

SPEECH.PARA: MONTI: Do you give a report to Kroger & Kroger of offenses at the picket line?
LEESON: Yes. All offenses.
MONTI: Including that you threw an egg at JIM BRITTAIN?
LEESON: Well, probably.
MONTI: You've done more than merely throw eggs haven't you?
LEESON: I don't recall that I have.
MONTI: There are some possibilities aren't there?
LEESON: Well, as a result of provocation then there would be abuse between both groups.
I think he is saying that the provocation probably came from the other side.
MONTI: How many times have you thrown eggs?
LEESON: Well, 1/2 dozen if I guess.
MONTI: You've thrown eggs at the tent?
LEESON: In the general direction of the tent.
A little further on the evidence reads:
MONTI: You've told picketers that you hate picketers haven't you?
LEESON: I've stirred some up, yes.
To be fair to Mr Leeson, the following was said:
MONTI: You told them that you hate picketers?
LEESON: Yes, but I believe that should be in context.
Later he was asked:
MONTI: Did you say to JIM BRITTAIN—
who is the union organiser down in this area—
"How's BEATON's head. Its like a busted egg"? Did you say that to JIM BRITTAIN?

Mr Beaton was a picketer who was attacked and hit on the head by an instrument which caused him to have a number of stitches put into his head. An effigy of Mr Beaton with his head split open was put in the window of the place where Mr Leeson worked.

PARA.TAB: Putting that in context makes sense of the next question. Having been asked whether he said to Jim Brittain, `How's Beaton's head. . . Did you say that?' Mr Leeson said:

SPEECH.PARA: I could have. I can't recall specifically saying it.
MONTI: Did you say to Jim Brittain `They tell me you're the next mark, Jimmy'?
LEESON: I deny that.
MONTI: And did you just laugh when he asked what that meant?
LEESON: I don't recall.
Mr Monti then asked:
You were part of a scheme by Kroger & Kroger to provoke trouble at the meat works, to bring an action for damages against the Union aren't you?
LEESON: No, I'm not.
MONTI: This is because of a large damages action?
LEESON: I don't know about what Kroger & Kroger want to do. All I know is that the matters may have been kept to be used in future Court proceedings.

It is cause for some alarm that these events took place. I want to make just a short comment because it is the end of the day and people want to go. It is right and proper for a person to take legal proceedings seeking remedies for the unlawful acts of others. It is wrong to seek an ulterior end through the perverse use of manufactured evidence whether that be obtained by provoking actions that would otherwise not take place or, as seems to be the case here, by simply giving false testimony.

PARA.TAB: Features of Australian industrial culture brought to light by the events surrounding the picket line at the Camperdown abattoirs should be erased. It is a most unhopeful prospect if the sorts of things within the industrial relations milieu of this country which have been demonstrated by what was done in respect of picketers at Camperdown should be allowed to flourish.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 April 1992:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

TAB.TAB: The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not compile statistics classified by the citizenship of non-Australian citizens. However, it collects and publishes information relating to country of birth.

PARA.TAB: (1) The preliminary estimate of the Australian resident population born in New Zealand, at 30 June 1991, is 287,478 persons.

(2) The estimated number of New Zealand born employed persons was 164,000 in March 1992. The estimated total number of New Zealand born persons at that time in the civilian labour force in Australia (including 26,600 unemployed persons) was 190,600.

(3) At 30 June 1986 there were 156,878 New Zealand born persons in Australia who were not Australian citizens. (Not all of these would necessarily be citizens of New Zealand.) Of these, 96,639 had been resident in Australia for five years or more (and would therefore appear to be eligible for Australian citizenship by satisfying the qualifying period of a total of two years residence in Australia). The remaining 60,239 persons had been resident in Australia for periods up to five years.
