TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 26 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What superannuation opportunities are available in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme (CSS) and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme (PSS) for Commonwealth employees in the following categories: (a) part-time employment; (b) casual employment; (c) contracted employment; and (d) consultancy employment.
(2) If there are superannuation opportunities in any of the above categories, what level of contribution is made by each employee in each category.
(3) What contribution is made by the Commonwealth to each employee in each category.
(4) What level of taxation is levied on contributions to employees in each category.
(5) How many Commonwealth employees are in each category.
(6) Can Commonwealth employees in any of the above categories have superannuation contribution paid into personal superannuation schemes of their choice; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

PARA.TAB: It should be noted that where a civilian employee of the Commonwealth is not a member of either the CSS or the PSS, he or she would be entitled to a minimum level of employer superannuation support, currently the three per cent productivity benefit. Generally such employees have this support provided through the Australian Government Employees Superannuation Trust (AGEST) or another industry fund approved by the Minister for Finance. AGEST currently has around 55,000 accounts of which around 25,000 are active accounts.
However, the question refers to the Commonwealth's two main schemes for civilian employees, the CSS and the PSS, and therefore the answer is based on those schemes.
(1) The CSS was closed to new members from 1 July 1990. Before CSS's closure:
(a)(i) permanent part-time employees were required to join;
(ii) temporary part-time employees were not eligible to join;
(b)(i) temporary full-time employees who had completed one year of service and had the prospect of three more years of service (as determined by their employer) could elect to join if they wished;
(ii) but casual employees, which for CSS purposes would not include persons in temporary full-time employment but would include temporary part-time employment, were not eligible to join;
(c) employees who were employed under a contract of employment of one year or more; Ministerial consultants and staff of Members of Parliament and could elect to join if they so wished; and
(d) persons who were engaged on a contract for services were not permitted to join.

Even though the CSS is closed, some former members who have rights under the CSS (eg those who elected for preservation of their benefit on resignation) would rejoin the CSS should they resume Commonwealth employment in one of the eligible categories above. They then would have three months in which to decide whether to remain in the CSS or transfer to the PSS.
In respect of the PSS which commenced on 1 July 1990:
(A) permanent employees (part-time or full-time) are required to join;

(B) all other employees (part-time, full-time or casual), at their option, may elect to join after completing three months service. They may aggregate separate periods of employment over the preceding two years in meeting the three months qualifying period;
(C) employees who are employed under a contract of employment of three months or more, at their option, may elect to join; and
(D) persons who are engaged on a contract for services are not permitted to join.

(2) In the CSS, all members are required to contribute 5 per cent of their salary but, at their option, may elect to pay additional contributions (in multiples of one per cent) up to a total of 10 per cent of salary. There are no differences in contribution rates required from members because of their employment category. Some former members of the 1922 CSS are able to maintain former levels of contributions under that scheme which could exceed 10 per cent of salary.

In the PSS, members, at their option, may elect to contribute between 2 and 10 per cent of salary. As in the CSS, there are no differences in contribution rates required from members because of their employment category.
(3) Neither the CSS nor the PSS provide different levels of benefits because of a member's employment category.

Under both schemes, the Commonwealth since 1 July 1990 has made ongoing fortnightly "three per cent productivity benefit" contributions for its employees. Some Government Business Enterprises with CSS members provide the productivity benefit in their own schemes.

In both schemes, the Commonwealth's productivity contributions are skewed, ie an arrangement which, while averaging three per cent of salaries, provides a greater percentage contribution for lower-paid staff and a lower contribution for higher-paid staff. The rates applicable to full-time employees for the financial year 1991-92 are set out below:
FortnightlyFortnightly
SalaryContribution
Less than $904$27.12
$904 to $1441.993 per cent of salary
$2163 or more2 per cent of salary
Part-time employees receive a pro rata amount based on their equivalent full-time salary and the proportion of full-time hours worked.

The balance of the employer-financed benefit is unfunded, ie no contributions are set aside in a fund and invested but rather the benefits are paid from the Consolidated Revenue Fund when they fall due.

Because the PSS is a fully defined benefit scheme and the CSS in part defined benefit, it is impossible to specify the total employer subsidy in respect of each employee. The subsidy would depend on a number of factors, such as age of entry, age of exit, rate of salary increase, earnings on funded contributions, etc. By making assumptions as to the unknown factors, actuaries estimate the overall employer rate that might be required to fund the benefits.

At the time of the review of the CSS, the employer contribution rate that would be required for new members if all the benefits were funded was estimated to be 22.8 per cent of salaries for CSS members (ie assuming it was not closed to new members) and 15.4 per cent of salaries for PSS members.
(4) The taxation of contributions and benefits does not depend on a person's employment category.
The Commonwealth's three per cent productivity contributions are taxed in the hands of the CSS and PSS Funds at the rate of 15 per cent.
The unfunded component of the employer contribution is not taxed at the Fund level.

Benefits (or part thereof) may also be taxed in the hands of the recipient. The taxation of benefits in the hands of recipients is very complex. However, a very broad generalisation for lump sum retirement benefits (excluding the contributions paid by members) in respect of membership after 30 June 1983 received on or after age 55 is:
(a) where benefits have been taxed in the hands of the fund, the first $73,776 is tax free and the balance is taxed at 16.25 per cent (including Medicare levy); and
(b) where benefits have not been taxed in the hands of the fund, the first $73,776 is taxed at 16.25 per cent and the balance is taxed at 31.25 per cent (both rates including Medicare levy).

(5) The scheme administrators have little need to record employment status because, once a person becomes a member, employment status is largely irrelevant for scheme purposes. However, where the employment status affects the calculation of benefits, eg pro rata benefits for part-time staff, it is possible that some presumption of employment status could be made by examining each record held. The number of part-time employees (including part-time casual employees) in the CSS and PSS would constitute less than 10 per cent of the combined 218,000 member population. The other types of employment status are not relevant for superannuation purposes and so are not recorded in the scheme administrator's records.
Alternatively, it would be possible to check the status of each member with each department/agency.
The possible benefits of conducting these checks do not appear to justify the costs of doing so.

(6) Certain persons in the above categories have available to them personalised superannuation arrangements with an employer contribution. Such arrangements generally apply to persons whose employment, either full-time or part-time, is of a temporary nature and of a duration (or possibly of a duration) that would not enable them to receive the full employer benefit under the CSS or the PSS were they required to join the CSS or PSS.

Persons in this category include Senior Executive Service (SES) personnel and SES equivalents in certain agencies employed on fixed term contract, and staff of Members of Parliament. Such persons have the choice of joining the PSS (formerly the CSS) or taking out personalised cover.
Like other temporary employees, such persons may opt to be covered by only the "three per cent productivity benefit".

There is also provision whereby persons employed while on leave without pay or secondment from their permanent employer to work for the Commonwealth can continue their membership of their permanent employer's scheme, with the Commonwealth making the appropriate employer contribution to that scheme.
In general, however, Commonwealth employees are not able to have the Commonwealth's contributions paid to a personal superannuation scheme of an employee's choice. The reasons for this are:
(a) the savings in administrative costs that result from having centralised superannuation arrangements;

(b) the defined benefit nature of the Commonwealth's main superannuation scheme does not lend itself to individual choice of scheme. (Defined benefit arrangements provide members with protection against inflation by linking benefits to salary at or close to retirement, rather than contributions and interest, and as such are pooled arrangements rather than individual accounts for members.)

While it would be possible to alter the arrangements to be contribution accumulation arrangements, defined benefit arrangements provide greater security for employees and have been preferred by the majority of employees;

(c) as far as PSS members are concerned, the investment performance of the invested moneys has only a minor impact on their superannuation benefits. The bulk of any investment gains would accrue to, and investment losses would be borne by, the Commonwealth which has to provide a benefit which is fully defined in terms of average salary over three years.

The Commonwealth, therefore, has a legitimate right to have its interests taken into account by the trustees who invest the funded contributions. The PSS Board of Trustees comprises equal numbers of employer and member nominees together with an independent chair, so that members' and employers' interests can be balanced in making investment decisions.
However, were members able to choose their superannuation scheme for the funded contributions, the Commonwealth's interests would not necessarily be taken into account by the trustees of that scheme;

(d) as far as CSS members are concerned, the members bear the bulk of the investment risk on the funded contributions in most cases. However, the employer guarantees the capital amount of the funded contributions and interest and also bears some of the investment risk on invalidity retirement where additional pension is taken in lieu of a refund of contributions and interest.

Therefore, as for the PSS, the Commonwealth has a legitimate right to have its interests taken into account when investment decisions are made and this may not be the case where members have a choice of scheme;

(e) even if contribution accumulation arrangements were adopted for Commonwealth employees, it is inevitable that, where employees were allowed to choose the superannuation fund to which their contributions were paid, some would later regret their decision on the choice of scheme and its investment performance.

Whatever the reasons for later regretting decisions, the Commonwealth would be put in the invidious position of wanting to see that former employees received an appropriate contribution for their retirement for their years of service, but not able to supplement those who made poor decisions without departing from its long-established principle of evenhanded treatment for all employees and incurring additional costs; and
(f) personalised superannuation arrangements would have to be fully funded. Therefore, to permit employees to be able to elect for employer contributions to be paid to a personalised superan

ANSWER.PARA: nuation arrangement could have a significant impact on Budgetary outlays.

PARA.TAB: Non-permanent Commonwealth employee who choose not to join the PSS (and formerly the CSS) are not prevented from making personal contributions into personal superannuation schemes. Likewise, members of the CSS and PSS are not prevented from taking additional private superannuation cover. However, there would be no employer contribution in these circumstances.

Moreover, where private arrangements were made, retirement benefits from the private arrangement and the CSS or PSS would be aggregated for the purposes of the reasonable benefit limits. Any part of the total benefit that exceeded the reasonable benefit limit would be taxed at the rates applicable to excess benefits.
